In the year 2010, Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder) is captured by the United States government and held at the Crystal Lake Research Facility. Government scientist Rowan LaFontaine (Lexa Doig) decides to place Jason in frozen stasis after several failed attempts to kill him. A breach is made, and Rowan is frozen alongside Jason for 455 years. Now aboard a ship in the far future they are both regenerated, and Jason continues his killing.
This is the tenth film in this series, and it's the 21 Century. Why can we still not get good actors? That's not to say the acting was bad, it was like it is in all of these movies, cheesy but suitable for what the actors are trying to accomplish. It's sad to see Kane Hodder leave after his fourth and final appearance in this film, he is my favorite Jason by far, really bringing this character to new levels.
I know that this isn't the best movie, and it does have a lot wrong with it realism wise and with continuity. God is it entertaining though! There's so much to love. The claustrophobia of the spacecraft, the tongue in cheek humour, the nerdy aspects of the film's vision. If nothing else, you need to appreciate the boldness in Jim Isaac to do a movie like this.
Overall, this may just be a guilty pleasure of mine, I know critics hated this one even more than 'Friday the 13th: A New Beginning' which I do not understand at all. If nothing else, this movie is so entertaining and true to the character of Jason you can forgive all the cheesy humor and unnecessary scenes that should have been cut. Watch this movie and have fun, that's what it's for.
3.5/5

reviews.review_title: A festival of the ridiculous that turns out to be unintentional entertainment (or not?), Jason X is a bizarre turn for the Friday The 13th series
reviews.content: Every successful franchise, especially the 80s horror ones, has its movie that symbolizes the rock bottom. Nightmare Hour 6: Freddy's Death (1991) was from the Freddy Krueger series Halloween 6: The Last Revenge (1995) was from Michael Myers and well... Jason X (2001) was from the Friday franchise -Fair 13. Once the most prolific of the genre, the series started in 1980 reached its tenth film already tired and lazy. The penultimate film had been a bombshell and New Line's official plans were to produce the long-awaited Freddy vs Jason (2003) clash. However, the crossover was a long and time-consuming process.That's when Sean S. Cunningam, the franchise's producer and director of the first movie, said they needed a new movie to keep the character in people's mouths, but no one had an idea for the tenth of Friday the 13th. Not until Todd Farmer arrives, giving the idea of taking the Hockey Mask Killer into space. He forgets Jason is in hell alongside Freddy Krueger. In this space incursion by the antagonist who murdered more than a hundred people in Crystal Lake (and in New York as well), there is no direct connection with Jason Goes To Hell - Last Friday, the previous episode of the franchise. We don't know how and why, but Jason seems to have escaped hell and bitter his last days at a Research Facility in Crystal Lake.At the site, the young man is under the supervision of Rowan (Lexa Doig), but his superiors want to move Jason away because of some financial investments. This sovereignty appears in the skin of the exceptional David Cronenberg, filmmaker responsible for classics such as A Mosca and Scanners, who here makes a point to give credibility to his film colleagues. What we expected happens: Jason manages to escape and Rowan will have to face him, until after an unsafe procedure, both end up in a cryogenic suspension compartment, becoming two frozen specimens found only in 2455, thanks to the incursion of the archaeologist Lowe (Jonathan Potts) and his troupe of students. They inhabit Earth 2, given that our planet is destroyed.Jason is taken into space along with Rowan. Both go through the resuscitation attempt. With the girl, the process is successful. Jason, as the killing machine we've known and loved since the 1980s, also resurrects, throwing the party right at the arrival ceremony, attacking researcher Adrienne (Kristi Angus), a character created in honor of the final girl of the franchise's first film. Death became one of the most talked about in the series: he first freezes the girl's face, then smashes it into several pieces, like a crystal. Insane, but no less fun.Jason Voorhees' tenth film has a certain quality to its making, almost like an old episode of Stargate or Andromeda; not by chance, the actress Lexa Doig is the protagonist. It's more of a sci-fi parody B than a horror movie itself, so much so that Jason X doesn't make much sense within the official chronology, after all, Jason should be in hell and not being used as a guinea pig for scientists in the future, so when one of the character's comments that "a creature that can't be killed would be too valuable to dump," we know that Todd Farmer's text is a metalanguage about the franchise itself and its endless sequels.Jason X has everything fans of the series would want to see: violent deaths, beautiful women, tributes to the franchise's movies (including a sex scene), really strong enemies and even an updated look for the famous killer. Kane Hodder, highly inspired, brings a strong Jason, with his deep breathing and quite menacing. Here, he has hair, but not the ridiculous strands from the previous movie. He also no longer lets out the grunts that destroyed the ninth part, nor does he throw his victims everywhere. He kills without mercy, rips his head off, cuts it into pieces and even faces a virtual monster, in one of the funniest scenes in the movie.Taking advantage of the futuristic environment, Jason faces the agility of a cyborg extremely prepared for a fight with the assassin and also participates in a virtual reality, set in 1980, in Crystal Lake. With the repetition of the famous little song (reedited in the second film), Jason beats the sleeping bags with the girls against a tree, mercilessly. The scene was inspired by Friday the 13th - Part VII, where Kane Hodder ended up getting very tired of carrying the heavy bags over and over again. According to the original screenplay, the idea was to make Jason reunite with his mother in 1980 and kill her, showing his total irrationality and malice. The scene ended up not being filmed.It's fun and bizarre to see how Farmer mixes typical space exploration movie characters with the banal clichés of the Friday 13 slasher movie. Where else would you imagine seeing horny teenage scientists on the deck of a spaceship? Or maybe that the ship's officers all wear tops? Again, it's more of a parody than a serious movie, and Farmer really pushes the envelope by exploring an android character (played by Melyssa Ade), but it's fun when the story requires a heavy fight between artificial intelligence (with machine guns and costumes from leather) and Jason. It's a guilty pleasure of the big ones.But the quotes don't stop there: one of the characters in the film is called Adrienne, in direct reference to the actress Adrienne King, who played the heroine of the first film. At a certain point, Jason finds his old machete and decides to use it again on Prof. Lowe, the movie's comic relief, as well as the cyborg herself. Jason repeats several classic deaths from the series in this film, such as the traditional slit throat and the knife thrown from a distance; Jason's mask is removed at one point, featuring a deformed Jason who closely resembles the character in the original film.It's obvious that not everything is perfect in the film ("perfect" in the sense of "fun"). The final sequence, with Jason flying and everything, is ridiculous. The quick transformation of the assassin into "Robocop" is blamed on the bad editing (where the machine managed to develop the new mask, no one knows); and even the script fails to say that they tried to kill him anyway and failed, without mentioning the character's supernatural characteristics. Why, sometimes, he came back by macabre luck indeed; when Jason blows the ship apart from the outside and depressurization takes place, the effect ends after a victim is sucked out. Jason keeps breaking down the doors, but no one else gets pulled...among other nonsense.As Sean S. Cunigham points out in Donald R. Beck's documentary Secrets Behind the Massacre, the magic show involving the first night of horror at Crystal Lake was replaced by the special effects and CGI of this episode, which made it easier to be conceived in aesthetic aspects. The filmmaker also claims that the production was a step forward, after all, unlike the camp, it is more difficult to imagine what will happen in a plot located in a space totally different from the traditional one. It's a movie that reminds a lot of Syfy's productions. James Isaac creates a believable and sufficiently futuristic world without ever drawing much attention to himself. Of course the CGI used in some sequences (like the bizarre ant treatment) has aged terribly, but the sets and settings work. Seeing Jason in such a different context is heartening, especially when the killer uses some improvised weapons (see head freeze) to execute his victims, and some sequences involving dark places are almost capable of reminding us of Alien - or, at worst, from Alien: Resurrection.A festival of the ridiculous that turns out to be unintentional entertainment (or not?), Jason X is a bizarre turn for the Friday the 13th series, and it explores well the mix of the slasher genre and science fiction. Open-minded and unpretentious, the viewer can find plenty to enjoy.

reviews.review_title: In space, no one can hear you suck
reviews.content: If you're looking to make a Friday the 13th movie and you come up with the idea of sending Jason into the future and into outer space....maybe it's time you just stop making Friday the 13th movies. This one's a stinker, obviously. It spends more time borrowing from the Aliens movies than it does trying to make a good Jason movie. One thing it does have going for it is that it's more fun than Jason Goes to Hell. There's a lot of comedy, both intended and unintended. The intended is pretty lame but the other is good for some chuckles. It also stars sexy Lexa Doig. Both to her credit and shame, she takes her part seriously. What's there to say about it? If you like the '80s Friday the 13th movies, you'll probably hate this. This is right down there with the Leprechaun series. Oh and I can't believe David Cronenberg does a cameo in this. He must have lost a bet.

reviews.review_title: Fast-paced sci-fi horror packed with incident and bloodshed
reviews.content: So Jason is back, and in a big way, with possibly the most expensive movie of the series so far and certainly the most special effect-filled one. Following on from JASON GOES TO HELL, which changed the core concept by having Jason becoming an evil slug that jumped from person to person, here we have the traditional hockey-masked killer back, but the setting is a futuristic spaceship in the style of many recent B-movie sequels. Thankfully, the film is still violent at heart, and for a 15 certificate film it offers some of the most imaginatively gory moments I've seen in a long time. People are decapitated, cut in half, thrown onto enormous drill-bits, get impaled, electrocuted, have their throats slit, and plenty more. Certainly the film's most notorious sequence is also the most inventive, having a young blonde lady getting her face frozen in liquid nitrogen, then smashed apart on a work surface – this is without a doubt the most disgusting thing I've seen on screen in a long, long time.The formula is predictable, involving young good-looking heroes and heroines narrowly evading Jason at every turn, but the special effects are better. Certainly the kills are authentic-looking and the CGI shots are fun if not particularly convincing. Set design is spot on, and elements of the traditional Friday the 13th music are more than welcome. Like it or not, things do become very cheesy as the film progresses, introducing the 'Uber-Jason', a nanobot-modified killer who looks more like the Terminator than Mr. Voorhees, and the climax, set in space, is totally off the wall and utterly unbelievable.The main thing, though, is that this film is fun, and a whole load of fun at that. There's plenty of self-knowing humour, black comedy and the young cast do a lively job. The film introduces a new hard-assed action hero in Tony Todd-lookalike Peter Mensah who I'd certainly like to see more of (and thankfully I did, when he took a lead role in the smash TV series SPARTACUS). And it wouldn't be the same without stuntman Kane Hodder, as huge and hulking as ever, who positively delights in a return to his famous role. So, fans of the series will delight in this entry which is both predictable and unpredictable at the same time; it never lets up from the start and offers enough blood and guts to satisfy any horror fan's appetite. An absolute delight.

reviews.review_title: Friday the 13th: fast and furious style
reviews.content: As Alice COOPER sang it during the end credits of JASON LIVES: "He's back, the man behind the mask" for his best carnage since FRIDAY THE 13TH: THE NEW BLOOD that introduced the stunt man Kane HODDER as the definitive incarnation of Jason VOORHEES.For the second time, Jason returns after what was supposed to be the final chapter of the never-ending saga, and for the second time, he gets an upgrade.In JASON LIVES (the real follow up to THE FINAL CHAPTER), he became a living dead with an increased strength and an invulnerability to fire and bullets.Now, we get the Uber-Jason, a cross between the TERMINATOR and the killer of Crystal Lake.After the disappointment brought by JASON GOES TO HELL: THE FINAL FRIDAY in which the killer was represented as a parasite with the ability to possess bodies and, as a result, allowed us to see Jason in his real shape for only two minutes at the beginning and five at the end, it's good to see that the hockey mask's back during the entire movie. When you watch a FRIDAY THE 13TH film, you want to see Jason, his mask and his big knife, not a guy trying to imitate Kane HODDER. It's good to bring fresh blood to a story that reaches its ninth entry but turning Jason into the cousin of "THE HIDDEN" wasn't the appropriate way to do it.So here's JASON X, a film where the star is the man behind the mask. More than in any other FRIDAY movie, Jason is treated as a myth, a horror legend. Jim ISAAC has made very cool shots of him where he looks very threatening. The opening sequence, with the close-ups on Jason's eyes when he's watching the lab-assistant are superb as you feel all the inner rage of the monster. This is one of best sequences that ever appeared in a FRIDAY THE 13TH movie, really impressive.However, the film isn't very scary but I don't think it aimed at making you jump out of your seat with terror. No, JASON X is to FRIDAY THE 13TH what BRIDE OF CHUCKY was to CHILD'S PLAY: a fun,fast and wildly furious adventure built around the main character, really seen as an icon, that both respects and wants to break free of the other episodes. In a nutshell, FRIDAY THE 13TH fans might be a bit disappointed, but if their main interest wasn't gratuitous nudity and "serious" gore but Jason VOORHEES, then it should be a dream come true.The screenplay's very simple but shows a real sense of rythm. There's plenty of very exciting situations with lots of gore and action. Here, there's no endless chases: Jason's more brutal than ever and doesn't waste his time with his victims.But the real gift of this film is its sense of humour, very respectful toward Jason and the slasher movies in general (unlike SCREAM) that is aimed essentially at the fans of the series. Some dialogues are bound to become cult and a scene involving Uber-Jason and a virtual Crystal Lake is a pure jewel. It made me laugh so hard...There's even a little reference to John CARPENTER's DARK STAR at the end.As a conclusion, let's say that although it's not a typical FRIDAY THE 13TH movie, JASON X stands along with JASON LIVES as the best entry in the series. It's a wild ride every Jason fan should enjoy. Don't listen to bad critics, this film really rocks: JASON'S BACK!!!

reviews.review_title: where no Friday the 13th movie has gone before
reviews.content: this 10th installment in the never ending Friday the 13th series of films is is a blend of science fiction,action adventure and comedy.it's set in space in the year 2455,and is pretty much ignores the rest of the films,other than still having a hockey masked Jason slaughtering people.it's somewhat entertaining, and funny on occasion,with a fair amount of action.and Jason gets an upgrade of sorts,so that was kinda interesting.it also has its slow moments where it's a bit too talky.and i feel the acting in this one is worse than in any of the others.but the idea to set it in space is fairly novel,if nothing else.for me,this 10 movie in the series gets a 5/10

Jason X is lots of fun & is basically a silly fun B movie Jason film & it's Awesome!!! Jason killing in space in the future IT'S pure crazy late night fun nothing else to say but a fun slasher thrill ride not brilliant but good.

slight spoilers#Its honestly not that bad. I've seen worse in the series than I have in this movie. I actually got some enjoyment out of it. it was funny and Jason was bad ass as usual. I didn't get the whole cyborg Jason thing though. they could have kept him the same. I'm glad the series is over though. I sat for two days trying to watch them all and I'm glad this was the final one. its not as bad as Jason goes to hell or a new beginning. I just think it's a classic slasher; a group of people trapped in one place and a mad man trying to kill them. So please don't judge it before you see it because no matter what anyone says its not that bad even though he's somehow in space.

JASON GOES TO HELL:THE FINAL Friday was a landmark to me, because they bring something fresh to the series. Flashforward 8 years later, me hearing JASON in space sorta bothered me a lot. I mean where's FREDDY V.S. JASON. I soon found out that this takes place after the battle, which explains the scratches on the mask. But what writer Todd Farmer and director Jim Isaac gave what I think is the best in the series and JASON entrainment.In 2010, JASON(Kane Hodder) has been captured and studied on for a while by now, only planing the perfect escape. When so everybody dies except for Rowan(Lexa Doig), who freezes herself and JASON for the last 445 years. Now 2455, a school on a field trip from space has found both bodies and unthawed them. On there way to Earth 2, JASON awakes to weak havoc upon the ship, only to be rebuild to the ultimate killing machine...literary!This movie is not meant to take itself serious as the last one, but to have fun with what they got. It's death scene are among the best I've seen in a long time. My favorites are the freezing head and screw, although the gore is tone down since the last one. The relationship between the robot K-M(Lisa Ryder) and her creator Tsunaron(Chuck Campbell) is cute and funny, something missing since PART VI:JASON LIVES. Full of fun surprises and a kick a$$ costume JASON has when he becomes UBER JASON. You will also say this is the best one in the series. So view with an open mind as I did and you'll appercite it too!

Jason X is the second Friday the 13th movie I ever saw, while the movie isnt perfect I can still enjoy the movie some problem that I have about the movie is the CGI, it's terrible, I don't know why people hate this movie much I like how this movie tried something different with the franchise and it succeeds in that this movie isn't just a couple of teens go out in the woods and get killed this movie doesn't do that. So anyway you should check this movie out

So it's been a long time since the romp that Jason Goes To Hell was and now we have this arguable piece of clever self-spoofing hysteria nearly a decade later and I have to admit that it is not one of my personal favorites...but I am proud to say that at least the hockey-masked splatter-zombie himself gets hefty screen time this go-round.Jason X opens at the Crystal Lake Research Facility(I'm not sure what year it opens in but I'm sure it's supposed to be the future)where Jason has been contained until he can be cryogenically "frozen in time" by modern technology(wow, now we can freeze people and bring them back even 400 years later)!!! This project is led by Rowan, our beautiful heroine from this entry, who runs into Dr. Wimmer(Cronenburg)who has "gone over her head" and comes to take Jason and doesn't want him "frozen". What follows is predictable:Jason escapes restraint, kills all of Wimmer's men and then Wimmer himself, and proceeds to pursue the beautiful Rowan who ultimately gets him into the cryogenic unit and gets the freezing process underway. However, as if she was born yesterday, she lingers in front of the unit just so Jason can thrust his machete through the steel and into her gut causing a "cryogenic breach". The unit then leaks and freezes Rowan as well....wow, this is tough!!! We cut now to the year 2455 and a team of students has come to what is now Earth One to....explore, I guess, and they discover these two beings in perfect condition. They take them aboard their ship with intentions of bringing at least the female out of 'stasis. But the Professor on the ship gets greedy, realizes Jason is worth a fortune, unfreezes him, and voilà!!! We have our new Jason movie. I had to end the plot cause it would have gone forever...Now, there are several corny yet clever lines which include one about what is on Jason's face and someone replies, "A hockey mask!" and another girl(Janessa, who is completely ANNOYING)replies,"What's a hockey mask?" and the robot-chic Kay-Em 14 answers, "Facial armor used in sport outlawed in 2024." It just kind of makes you wonder whether or not hockey would still be around in that time...no reason that it shouldn't, it just makes you question the future a little bit.The deaths were a disappointment this time, yet some were great like the Virtual Reality with the two guys and the one involving a large drill!! Nevertheless there are a couple of suicides and a couple of off-screen deaths which didn't do anything for me. At this point in the series that just does not meet my standards. The acting is sometimes so bad that you grimace or grind your jaw, especially from the actress playing Janessa(who also has a memorable death). The kinky thing with her and Professor Lowe was sexy, to say the least, but other than that I really couldn't wait for her to relieve us of her presence. Her line "What? ARE YOU HIGH?!!" was downright repulsive and awful in so many ways. Oh, the mistakes....Still I am happy with this entry over Jason Goes To Hell and HAVE watched it several times and even watched it on the big screen. It had a promising "open door for a sequel" ending that centered around a lake....yay, maybe we can get back to basics now. The Crystal Lake simulation used to distract Jason is something to look forward to if you haven't seen it yet...oh yeah, and I DO recommend it...you just have to suffer through some of its unnerving acting. I was sad to learn that Jason X was the only entry in this franchise to not make back its budget in ticket sales :( Oh well, I'm sure Freddy vs. Jason made up for it...5/10

I'm writing this review in first person because I'm fully aware that is impossible to convince people to view a movie of the Friday the 13th franchise when they already have a negative point of view of Jason and his world. I saw this movie at least twice and what can I say? I loved it, I really enjoyed every second of it. Mr. Kane Hodder is the Ultimate Jason, and Jason X, has it portraying two versions of Jason. JX is the classic FT13 tale with the futuristic twist that introduces a lot of sci-fi extravaganza. Jason Voorhees is one of the most interesting monster of cinema, due to his origin, his killings are somehow justified (not like M. Myers or Freddy) because he died as a child when some horny teens didn't take care of him when he was in Crystal Lake Camp. Throughout the years he has become a modern myth. Some of the movies of Ft13th were great others not so great, but I think Jason X is among the best. JX shows how much cinematic language changed in this years, has an agile modern montage, the actors are well... unknown actors but they do it great, and the script has some clever and ironic lines, and finally the cinematography is stunning, JX doesn't appears to be a $20 million dollar flick it looks like a more expensive movie. If that is not enough, two celebrities of Horror met in the first scene.

reviews.review_title: I like the idea if not the actual movie
reviews.content: In 2010 - 9 years in the future! - Jason is captured by the U.S. government but can't be killed, so government scientist Rowan LaFontaine decides to place the killer is suspended animation. Of course, a bunch of soldiers screws the whole thing up and Jason kills everyone in his path before he stabs Rowan and freezing both of them.445 years later, Earth is ruined so everyone moves to Earth 2. So why not send some students back to the old Earth on a field trip? Why not send their professor and an android, too? While exploring the Crystal Lake facility where Jason was experimented on? And why not put the still frozen bodies of Jason and Rowan on the Grendel, their ship? Nothing bad can happen, right?Well, it turns out that Jason is dead and his body could be worth plenty. The Professor calls his money man, Dieter Perez (Robert A. Silverman, who has been in five Cronenberg* movies and the two episodes of Friday the 13th: The Series that he directed, too) and they discuss how Jason's body could be worth something to collectors. Luckily - or maybe not - they bring Rowan back to life.Of course, kids keep having sex around Jason, which brings the maniac back to life. He wipes out nearly everyone on the ship, including all of the soldiers that are on board. He even takes out an entire space station!The teens upgrade their android, KM-14, who wipes out Jason. Or so everyone thinks - a medical station brings him back as Uber Jason, filled with cybernetics so powerful that he can punch the android's head off. Not even a holographic simulation or a shuttle crash can slow him down! It takes flying him through re-entry and burning him up to take him out.That said - two teens see his mask land on Earth 2, so he could always come back. He can come back, right?This was written by Todd Farmer (Drive Angry, the remake of My Bloody Valentine) and directed by James Isaac (House 3). I have a real weakness for this film as it really goes places none of the others did. It's the Abbott and Costello school of running out of ideas and just doing something completely off the wall.*Cronenberg shows up in a cameo as Dr. Wimmer, too!

After the abysmal "Jason Goes to Hell," anything seemed better. And why not make a movie so the amount of instalments is an even 10? Luckily, this goes back to same non-serious fun Jason films of previous instalments. And after watching the previous Jason movie, it really elevated Jason X.After being sent to hell in "Jason Goes To Hell," Freddy obviously resurrects him and his body-count in growing. It is the mid 2000s and Jason has been captured and cryogenically frozen. They freeze him because they can't figure out a way to destroy him forever. Only the supernatural can do it! But Jason's brutish strength messes things up and he gets frozen with one of the researchers. Fast forward 450 years. A group of college students are travelling on a spaceship and stumble upon Jason and the girl. Both are thawed and then the movie turns into Alien with Jason as the monster. When we get to see the students and their professor, its pretty silly. Good for laughs. When Jason awakens and tries to destroy all, we actually become invested. When Jason gets upgraded into the most powerful he could ever be, it's pretty kick-ass.In the year 2455, some of the futuristic things we see is pretty cool. And a spaceship is cool to see in general. And add one of cinema's coolest monsters to wreck havoc. The way all this is added up makes the movie totally bad-ass. Sure the acting is dull and its not very smart, but the fights and Uber Jason are all so fun!I gave some earlier instalments thumbs up just because they were fun and they didn't demand to be taken seriously. Jason X is one of those.3/4

I loved this movie.  In my opinion, this is the best of the JASON movies. Jason in space?  What a great concept!  This movie combined two of my favorite genres, horror and science fiction.  The movie delivers on all counts.  It has a great story line, and terrific special effects.  The movie is non-stop action and the killings are very creative.  This movie is very gorey, and in fact, I would say it is the most gorey installment of the FRIDAY THE 13th movies so far.  And without a doubt, this is the funniest movie of the series.  It has some really great laughs.  The director definitely seems to have a well developed sense of humor and a true love of action, horror, and sci fi.  This movie is awesome.  I loved the part when the space ship crashes in to the space station and then the space station explodes.  Also the part when the grunt gets cut in half and the next shot you see is the poor guy dragging half his body across the floor.
The characters are all likable and memorable.  Not to mention, this installment of the series definitely has the HOTTEST girls.  There are not too many other movies in general to come to my mind that have women of this calibre.In particular, I have to mention Melody Johnson.  She played the character "Kinsa."  I think she is absolutely gorgeous.  A modern day screamer-movie beauty.  She is incredibly sexy throughout the movie.  She kind of looks like Anna Paqin, but I think Melody is better looking.  She is just exactly my type.  I own JASON X on DVD and I put it in every once in a while just to check out Melody Johnson.  It seems unfortunate to me that Melody has not really done too many other movies.  She is so beautiful I would like to see more of her...A LOT more of her!If you are a fan of FRIDAY THE 13th, or just a sci fi or horror fan, you absolutely have to see JASON X.  The hologram sequence at the end where the "upgraded" Jason returns to Crystal Lake and encounters HOT co-eds is priceless.  The two girls offer Jason beer and pot, and then exclaim "We love premarital sex."  Then Jason beats them to death by wrapping them up in their sleeping bags and smashing them into a tree.  Its creepy, violent, and super funny all at the same time.You really have to see this movie.  It is top notch from start to finish. Check it out and you will not be disappointed, you will be thoroughly entertained.

reviews.review_title: This is the reason I hate Horror movies
reviews.content:
The horror genre has no class.  I hate horror movies and will continue to hate them as long as movies like Jason X continue to come out.
Easily the worst movie of the year. And I don't want to hear "What were you expecting, this is JASON we're talking about," or any crap like that. There is no excuse for something this dumb when millions of dollars are being spent.  With this movie's budget, New Line could have probably made a decent, and original, sci-fi movie.  But NO!  Some exec was like "We can just make another Jason movie and market the hell out of it and make it look cool!  The teeny boppers will love it!"There are so many things about this movie that don't make sense.  Fist of all, in the beginning, Jason is somehow captured.  This must have been a pretty difficult task, seeing as he's the deadliest killer the world has ever known.  So you think they'd have about a hundred guards watching him right?  No! Of course not!  That would make sense.  Instead, they have ONE guy watching him.  So of course Jason escapes and mayhem ensues. Etc, etc. Fast forward to four hundred and fifty years in the future (!) to a highly advanced society that doesn't know what a hockey mask is, but they still know what DVDs are, and everything goes downhill from there.Look, I don't expect every movie to be a magnificent work of art.  But I do expect a little effort and a story that is consistent and logical to some extent.  Jason X has absolutely nothing going in its favor.  I would sooner poke my eyes for 90 minutes than to sit through this crap again.

I'm not a huge fan of slashers. I just don't like the idea of movies that are all about killing a bunch of nonames. But I've heard that Jason X is pretty ridiculous, so there we go :PSo it's pointless to be mad at poor characters development, crap story and all that good stuff. Because it's the movie about an immortal psychopath killing people. Using a machete. Wearing hockey mask. In a spaceship.It's cheesy, cringeworthy, poorly written mess, but it doesn't matter, because... strangely enough it's fun to watch. It's that kind of mindless fun, but hey!There are even 2 unforgettable scenes in this crap! 1) crazy fight between Jason and cyborg lady - Jason loses an arm, a leg, half of his torso and the head :P 2) possibly the best death scene in the cinema history - Jason smashing frozen head of the future science lady against the table.All in all, I can't give it more than 5/10 though, because it's still C class cinema :P

I suppose the virtue of this movie is that it delivers exactly what you expect it to. And the downside is that it's pretty dumb. But then, so were the others.Maybe I'm not the best person to comment, because I find the whole Jason Vorhees saga irritating in that the killer is implacable, unstoppable and unmotivated, and therefore devoid of all credibility. Being killed by Jason makes as much sense, and carries as much emotional weight, as being run down by an avalanche.Accordingly, I can't get behind these movies at all - they simply become a cynical exercise in imaginative slaughter and guessing the order of victims, with no rhyme or reason about it.Oh well, the sci-fi setting in this one makes a change, Lexa Doig is pleasingly decorative, and the fact that the whole thing is considerably sillier than usual (which is saying something) might be considered a bonus.

After JASON Goes to Hell,which many people dislike,I didn't.Fans were craven for a FREDDY v.s. JASON.While the studio was working on that,someone wanted to make another JASON movie,but not following the same story as the last one.So many ideas were up,including the one that was going to be made JASON in L.A,which JASON will be up against gangbanggers.So then somebody came up with JASON in space.JASON X was born.    You can tell this takes place somewhere after the battle between FREDDY and JASON,because you can see claw marks on JASON's mask.Jason is frozen because they can't find a way to kill he,but before a murder spree happens JASON is frozen,then unthawed in the year 2455.That means trouble,trooouble.    I like that they did something really new to the series and made it had a space like 80's feel to the original Friday the 13th.The death scenes were great and invented to give JASON more space than that campground.And that short new look at what JASON is going to look like is brilliant.Kane Hodder is JASON and forever will be.So a great installment to the series.Really it is.

Jason Voorhees is finally captured by the U.S. government and held at the Crystal Lake Research Facility. They can't find a way to kill him. Scientist Rowan LaFontaine (Lexa Doig) decides to freeze Jason in cryogenic suspension. Jason escapes and Rowan is just able to freeze both him and herself. 455 years later a scientific team returns to a desolate earth and finds the frozen bodies. They bring the two on their ship, but the reanimated Jason just can't stop killing.This movie borrows heavily from Alien, Blade Runner and many others. It just does it without the tension or style. It is cheesy camp. The only good thing is that director James Isaac knows it. He's made a hopeless B-movie with a high cheese factor.

OK, I read the other reviews and don't violently disagree with most of them. It is a cheesy space-monster movie but it's also an hour and a half of good, gory fun. As one reviewer pointed out you shouldn't expect "Gone with the Wind" when you're watching a Jason movie. Some of the corny, out of context lines were quite funny. It didn't drag; there was lots of action; it kept moving. It's also more entertainment than the average Netflix flick which I why I gave it a seven.

reviews.review_title: Jason V's Alien  better than the usual Friday 13th standards but still not anything great
reviews.content: After multiple attempts to kill him, the decision is taken to cryogenically freeze the mass murderer Jason Voorhees to contain him for all time. However the advice of Dr Rowan is ignored and the military decide that he is too valuable for science to lose. Of course it all goes wrong and it is only the sacrifice of Rowan that gets Jason frozen again. Jump forward a few hundred years and a student expedition uncovers the frozen bodies of the Jason and Rowan. They revive Rowan but start to cut up Jason as all scans show him to be dead; of course Rowan is brought back to life too late to warn the others and before you can say "sexy teenagers in peril", Jason Voorhees is back to his old tricks on board the spaceship as it heads towards Earth II.Although I have yet to find any real value in the Friday 13th series, I decided that I'd give this a try since it had had many positive reviews. I quickly realised that this film was just going to push all the usual buttons but do it slightly differently by essentially crossing the series with the alien series (not really of course, but I couldn't shake the feeling that this was the closest it could have got). Looking back I can only assume the kind reviewers were a reflection that at least this film wasn't as bad as some of its predecessors rather than being reviewed by critics on its own merits. Despite being set in deep space, the film still manages to pull together a cast of nubile young actresses alongside some other genre clichés before setting out to pick them off one at a time in a series of rather nasty but yet unimaginative set pieces. In fairness it is distracting and fans of the series will probably enjoy it but personally I just felt like I was plodding wearily through overly familiar ground and the fact that it crossed over into a different genre didn't change that.The gore is reasonably good I suppose (I'm not really a horror fan) and those who like this sort of thing will probably not be bothered by the fact that the scares are obvious and don't really have a consistent or significant tension to them. The cast are all very pretty and buy into the material pretty well. Doig makes an unconvincing scientist but is sexy and gorgeous enough to fill the main requirements of the script. Hodder does his usual slow plodding stuff without having the opportunity or ability to add to it. The rest of the cast are a collection of soldier clichés, sexy young things, geeky guys and other genre staples. None of them do anything special or interesting but in fairness none of these films have ever been about the cast as performers  just about them as eye candy and fodder.Overall this is better than the general standard of the Friday 13th films if only by crossing over into another genre to provide the same old same old with at least a fresh appearance. It is of course nothing of the sort and just repackages the same old stuff as usual. Better than the usual slasher fare but just don't expect it to be good.

reviews.review_title: A hugely entertaining blend of science-fiction and horror
reviews.content: I'm not really a fan of the Friday the 13th movies - in fact, I consider the first five films to be interchangeable, almost instantly forgettable, and pretty worthless. However, from Friday the 13th Part 6: Jason Lives onwards everything starts to improve, and in my opinion it must be the only long-running movie series that actually gets better as it goes along.Jason X is my favourite film in the series: it works on all levels, as a slasher film, as a science-fiction movie, and as an action thriller. Just as the preceding entry Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday (which I also enjoyed) was a celebration of the '80s horror genre, with nods and winks to Halloween, the Nightmare on Elm Street series, The Evil Dead, The Thing, etc, so Jason X cheerfully includes elements from numerous sci-fi action movies, such as Aliens, The Terminator, Virtuosity, The Lawnmower Man, Robocop, and Predator. But it doesn't do so to rip those films off. Instead, the producers simply know that if you put Jason in a future setting, movie-savvy audiences are going to be annoyed if he doesn't encounter such sci-fi standards as androids, virtual reality, nano-technology, cyborgs, and space-marines.The producers even have the courage to play Jason for laughs towards the end of the film, as Kay-Em 14 takes him to pieces (a terrific sequence!!!), plus the hologram scene where he's confronted by two hilariously stereotypical topless cuties. But the film never tips over into farce, and successfully ensures that Jason remains as menacing and lethal as ever.Full marks also to the writers and cast, for making the various potential Jason fodder candidates amongst the most well-rounded individuals in the series. One complaint often made against Jason X is that it lacks a strong Final Girl, but I think that's merely because so many of the characters register so strongly.

After Jason Takes Manhattan and Jason Goes To Hell my expectations dropped tremendously, and while this story is way out there, I think they handled this one pretty good. I wasn't really a fan of Jason's new look and I don't really get how he could've come back or "regenerated" if he went to hell but those are my only complaints. I also really liked that ending, the way everything came full circle was a pretty suitable conclusion.

reviews.review_title: If there's no more space (for Jason) on Earth ...
reviews.content: His victims will walk .. a spaceship? Not sure that famous line Ken Foree uttered is ripe for this Jason remix/update, but hopefully you'll take this attempt at humor with a pinch of salt. I would argue that this is fun, but while we seem to have really gone everywhere (maybe it would have been fun to follow Jason to Hell and see what he'd be up to there? How about meeting Ted and Bill and ... ok maybe now I lost you with that silly idea) ... but are we willing to follow him? This will be up to you.The makers made clear they were just a stepping stone to the Freddy vs. Jason movie everyone was expecting ... which came and ... unfortunately didn't do too much either. And we'll probably will never see the one I wanted even more: Ash vs. Freddy vs. Jason ... man that would have been a hoot. But it's always about balance. And talking about that, the kills here are quite good, but the aged CGI will probably put some people off. It is not entirely bad, but you can see most of the effects clearly as that ... will be up to you, if that bothers you. Finally this is the last outing of Kane Hodder as Jason on film ... which is a shame! I always liked that Freddy was played by one person (except the reboot that is).

This is no doubt the most unique setting Jason has appeared in the big screen. He's been put in a suspended animation and wakes up 450 years in the future.Jason is trapped in a cryostasis until a scientific scout ship consisting of school students and a teacher finds him, and not knowing his immortal nature, bring him back to life within the space ship. The unsuspecting (in the beginning) occupants of the space ship gets hacked and maimed in the usual way you'd expect from Friday the 13th movie, but this one is bit more imaginative because there are more props of the future that can be used to add gory ways people get snuffed by our antihero.For a relatively low budget movie, the special effects are surprisingly good. The actors are all good looking which adds to the quality of the story.Out of all the Friday the 13th movie (so far), this one is my favorite for the action and the visuals this movie has to offer. This was good entertainment, and although it's not for everyone, it appeals to both horror movie, and sci-fi movie affectionados. It's high quality entertainment looking from both genre, and is recommended for viewing.

'Jason X' is not your average 'Friday the 13th' film.It takes the series and adds something entirely different.Jason Voorhees has been to Camp Crystal Lake and even Manhatten.Now, he's somewhere that no one would ever expect him to go.Is he in the North Pole? No.Is he in the desert? No.Is he in space? As corny as it sounds, yes.I actually enjoyed 'Jason X'.The kills are entertaining and Jason is still fun to watch.If there is anything bad about this film, it's the acting.Not every line of the movie is bad, but some are just ridiculous and unnecessary.Still, I found 'Jason X' to be a fun and entertaining slasher film with a great performance by the machete wielding maniac Jason Voorhees.

This movie here is pure gold. Jason takes his reign of terror a step farther by taking on a research facility, and then a crew aboard a spaceship in the year 2455. The characters in this movie were great. I got to like some and really hate others. They were very convincing. Jason is played yet again by Kane Hodder (thankfully!). There were some very good kills, and this was a whole new setting for Jason. But it worked very well. I personally liked Uber-Jason, although many hated him. Come on people, it had to be done! Its not like a permanent new thing for him, seriously. The effects were very good for a movie such as this. There were some very interesting scenes as well. And Jason always managed to come back on top here. 8/10 for a great Jason movie.

reviews.review_title: This Sequel is Fun for the Fans and Something a little new for once.
reviews.content: In the year 2009-Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder) is still breathing, still indestructible and still the essence of evil. When a hard working female scientist (Lexa Doig) tries different ways to destroy him but he keeps coming back alive. When the lead scientist trapped Jason to be frozen but she ended being frozen with the undead murderer. 446 years later, when a group of young students on a routine training mission come to discover, when they accidentally discover two frozen bodies and learning that one of them is the legendary killer of Crystal Lake but little what they know, when Jason is defrost. He comes back to life but his new environment and when technology has changed, he goes on a killing rampage but this time on a moving space ship! Directed by James Issac (The Horror Show, a.k.a.-House 3) brings an lively, sometimes funny sequel to the seemingly never-ending series to the Friday the 13th films. Director:Issac and first-time screenwriter:Todd Farmer (He also has a small role in this). The writer added some clever and exciting moments with an delightful fun in the last half hour. Although knowing that the plot is silly and wondering how did Jason come back to life after Jason Goes to Hell. Although fans would like to think of it, it happened after Freddy Vs Jason. Still, the film is surprisingly entertaining with clever visual effects (Some of the CGI effects are quite lame, which some of it is unintentionally hilarious) and Harry Manfredini's music score isn't bad, either. Jason X is actually better than some of the Friday the 13th sequels and it's also less violent or bloody than most.DVD has an great anamorphic Widescreen (1.85:1) transfer with an strong-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound (Also in DTS). DVD has an fine commentary track by the director, writer and producer:Noel Cunningham. DVD has an entertaining 30 minutes documentary on the history of the Friday the 13th films. DVD also has an 17 minutes behind the scenes featurette, trailer and more. Executive Produced by Sean S. Cunningham (Who directed the original-Friday the 13th) and director:Issac. Watch for Canadian filmmaker:David Cronenberg and actor:Robert S. Silverman in cameos. True Fans of the Series will love this one. Filmed in 2000. (*** ½/*****).

This is definitely one of the best Friday Movies. It's the least New Line Cinema could do after releasing the bad Jason Goes to Hell. This is nothing like Leprechaun 4 or Hellraiser:Bloodlines. This is just basically your standard Jason slasher, only difference is, is that it takes place on a spaceship and he gets an upgrade. The cyborg Jason only lasts for about 20 minutes of the movie, so don't get too excited. But overall, its great, just wish the writers would give some explanation or take off from the Friday film before.

reviews.review_title: Like "Alien" but with Jason and a sense of humor
reviews.content: Released in 2001-2002, "Jason X" starts in the year 2010 where the government decides to finally stop Jason by putting him into frozen stasis. He and another person are revived in the year 2455 by a professor and his students who are on a field trip from Earth Two to Earth One. Jason is unleashed on their spaceship and havoc ensues.This entry is like 1979's "Alien" except with Jason as the monster and a sense of humor. You'll also notice that it's a great departure for the series putting Jason in space in the future. Most Friday fans look down on 1993's "Jason Goes to Hell" and "Jason X" because the producers tried something new. It's obvious that they felt the series had become stale and formulaic with an incredible eight-installment run from 1980-1989. I felt "Jason Goes to Hell" had a refreshing concept (ripped off from 1987's "The Hidden") and a great intro & opening act, but the tone was distasteful and the flick eventually spiraled out of control with its cartoony quasi-horror gobbledygook; still, it featured a couple of the best women in the series (Agent Marcus and Deborah), which should be commended.I heard negative comments about "Jason X" over the years, but the first half is sci-fi at its best with some amusing elements thrown in for good measure. It's stunning how well the filmmakers handle the sci-fi aspects of the plot and F/X. The second half, unfortunately, becomes too cartoonish as Jason systematically annihilates most of the crew, particularly when he gets his new futuristic look, basically morphing into SuperJason (rolling my eyes).As usual, this installment features an impressive assortment of women, but it's only Kinsa (Melody Johnson) that I find appealing, except for the cameo of the campfire teen #1 at the end, played by the stunning Mika Ward. They should have included her in the main cast.To be expected in light of the spaceship plot, the film was shot mostly on sets (in Toronto) with a couple of outside sequences in Ontario.The film runs 91 minutes.GRADE: B-

~Spoiler~ Jason X is the most unexpectedly hilarious movie ever made...and, without a doubt in my mind, the best Friday the 13th film.  That's saying a lot for a part 10.  I laughed almost nonstop and was amazed by the kills, the humor, and the humorous kills.  This time around, Mr. Voorhees is brought to outer space and is given brilliant ways to kill teens and scores of others.  I believe this has the highest body count of any 13th film.  Kane Hodder (his fourth time wearing the mask) is at his best and the death scenes are truly jaw-dropping.  People are stabbed, beheaded, broke in half, skewered, and they brought back the sleeping bag kill.  I personally can't praise Jason X enough.  It corrected the mistake of Jason Goes to Hell; it actually had Jason in the movie.  It proved many things to horror audiences.  You can take a horror franchise to outer space and make a kick-ass movie at the same time (unlike Leprechaun 4 and Hellraiser: Bloodline).  It also proved that Todd Farmer is a writer to watch for and that James Isaacs was deserving of a second chance (his first film wasn't exactly the best).  My words will fall on some deaf ears, however, because this movie seems to split fans down the middle.  Some think the movie is utterly ridiculous (which it is) and others love the tone and direction that it took.  Some people are tired of Jason and think they need to retire him.  I say as long as they keep making these films, I'll keep watching them.  Brodski rules.Note for genre buffs: David Cronenberg cameos in the beginning of the film.

There's a saying when it comes to horror franchises that, when you've finally jumped the shark and you've run out of ideas, you send the villain to space. I guess after he went to Hell and took Manhattan, there was nowhere else for Jason to go.In the distant future, a bunch of students discover the frozen bodies of two people and one of them happens to be notorious serial killer Jason Voorhees. They decide to take them both onto their ship and thaw them out which, of course, leads to Jason hacking his way through most of the passengers.A lot of the CGI is spotty, the script is a mess, and most of the acting feels porn-level at best, but Jason X doesn't want to do anything but entertain and it does that well. I don't think it's possible not to enjoy a film where someone's head is frozen and then smashed onto a table into a million pieces. It's creative where it needs to be - the kill scenes.Jason X has to be about as dumb as slasher movies get (and some slasher movies can get really dumb), but damnit if it didn't win me over by the end. This is a movie that knows it's dumb and it's not trying to be high art. I can appreciate that.I was also amused by the David Cronenberg cameo. Didn't expect to see him here.

reviews.review_title: Gets my nomination for the Ed Wood movie of the year
reviews.content: When a picture goes out of its way (or rather along its usual route) to be absolutely terrible in craftsmanship and style and yet goes for big unintentional laughs, like Jason X, it garners my nomination for the Faux Ed Wood award which should be given to movies that bring bad horror to a tee. So stupid is this movie that if it tried to be a parody and not a gore fest in space it could rank with the likes of Scary Movie.  The plot is as thin as rolling paper and delivers what you'd expect from a part 10 in a 22 year saga.  Kane Hodder deserves credit for going once again for one of the most dredded characters in horror and yet the film tries to have some fun along it's stomach churning way.  Best scene- the crystal lake dream sequence. D+

reviews.review_title: Jason knows no limitations in space.
reviews.content: Just another rhythmic 'Friday the 13th' sequel yeah, but I do enjoy them with the exception of 'Goes to Hell'. Hey that was my first, well complete experience of the franchise before I went on to see 'Jason X' at cinema the week after. I liked it, and borrowed the rest of the films off a friend. The series isn't a masterpiece of cinema, but they remain entertaining.I hadn't watched 'X' since I last saw it at the cinemas, and seeing it again it was just as fun as I remembered it, although the smarting puns (with those self-referential one-liners before being dispatched in a thoughtlessly tacky script) they seem to spit out got a little too much. The manner of the humour seemed to share a common style with 'Jason Lives: Friday the 13th Part VI (1986)', with quite an amusingly clever gag involving a hologram trip back to Camp Crystal lake for early 80's goodness. Anyhow Jason leaves his traditional Camp Crystal setting (even though he's 'kinda' still in the area when the film opens) to receive the space treatment (being better than other entries including 'Critters 4', 'Leprechaun 4: In Space' and 'Hellrasier: Bloodline') and a revamp look to go with it. Was that a good choice? I don't know but it still delivered on creatively vicious violence and shocks, a beautifully disposable cast and healthy body count (plenty of meat for the slaughter) despite the change of environment and mechanisms. It's the same-old, same-old, but done with enough aplomb. Director Jason Isaac gives the film a metallic gleam and provides a rapid pace never letting the clock slow up. The special effects by Stephan DuPuis are above-par and the production design is polished. Mark Manfredini gives his score an updated touch that works with the new backdrop.The acting isn't anything to write home about; however they do fill nicely to their roles. The stunning Lexa Doig makes for a reliable central performance and David Cronenberg chips in with nifty cameo in opening scenes. Kane Hodder brings the right intensity to Jason, and has truly made it his own. Peter Mensah and Melyssa Ade were fun in their parts too.

reviews.review_title: Part 10 is scarier then part 1 2 and 5
reviews.content: This is a very scary movie. There are scarier movies Friday the 13th III is scarier. Friday the 13th final chapter is also scarier. Friday the 13th VI Jason lives is also scarier. Friday the 13th VII the new blood is also scarier. Friday the 13th VIII Jason take Manhattan is also scarier. Jason goes to hell the final Friday is also scarier. Still this is a very scary movie. It is scarier then Friday the 13th (1980). It is also scarier then Friday the 13th II. It is also scarier then Friday the 13th V a new beginning. This is a great movie. It has great acting. It also has a great story line. It also has great special effects. This movie a must see. Jason is a zombie so I consider this horror fantasy. And this movie take place in space in the future. This is the only Friday the 13th movie that does. Freddy vs Jason is a prequel to this movie. Freddy is a ghost. Both of these character get kill of and come back more then three time. See this movie. It is a get movie. I knew people like this movie it the ratting it got 5 out of 10. People who like this movie need to speak up. And come on really Freddy vs Jason is a good movie but Freddy vs Jason is not better then this.

As weird as Jason in space may seem, his fans finally got what they asked for - something new - when, after four false starts, this movie was finally made. Four hundred and fifty five years in the future, earth is dead and the recently defrosted J-Man finds himself aboard the Grendel, a field-trip vessel carrying students from Earth 2. So, basically, Jason + teenagers = mass death. Something old and something new. Something borrowed, or nicked, are the best bits from the Alien movies. You know what's in store, long scenes of creeping around dark corridors before being carved up.What I don't get is the fact that the filmmakers knew that we didn't want Camp Crystal Lake AGAIN and so decided to take us as far away as possible from the previous nine movies. Why must they give us the ancient and decrepit stalk'n'slash scenario yet again? Fresh zazz, or zing, or fizz, or even pop could have been added. But no! It threatens to get very dull and the only thing that saves it are the gorgeous SFX, stronger production values and more determined than usual characters (slabs of meat).James Isaac has had plenty experience in the horror genre and, along with his cinematographer, has given this movie a far more sophisticated look than most other horror flicks. Lighting is provocative and the colour palette is well thought out and bright. It's a shame that nothing of real genius, or imagination, occurs within this unique environment.Plus, I'm getting real sick of Kane Hodder, as Jason. At first, I liked him - F13, Part VII, was his premier outing - but now he's changed the character too much. Instead of an evil, worm-infested zombie, with incredible strength, he's a massive brick shithouse, who moves slower than your average glacier. How can these kids not escape him? The acting, by a bunch of Canadian TV folk, is tolerable. None has enough skill to bring any real humour, or depth, to roles. Who cares when they die? The only interesting character is a female robot, or Fembot, as the Austin Powers movies put it, with no feelings - how ironic! There's no good excuse for Jason X being so average. Even the presence of Uber-Jason - Robocop, only not friendly - is too little too late, although he, along with Janessa's cleavage, doesn't get enough screen time.If you're having a beer blast, or a stein-hoist, then Jason X is worth the rental. If you're after classical entertainment then...probably not.

The name Jason Voorhees could make the strongest stomached individual feel quite queasy. Some of his other outings have involved, Gut ripping, Heart eating, People ripped in half by a machete and the list goes on.Although quite tame compared to his previous works, Jason, Now in the future has the chance to leave his mark on a peaceful civilization. Not as much blood and guts in this one yet, I believe this is one of the best i have ever seen.Finally the Jason series gets a good story with a reasonable budget and some reasonably good acting. I really like this one, It's very different from the other Friday the 13th series and it has a lot more fun factor as opposed to just gratuitous violence and sex!I would rate this movie as 8/10 and i think any open minded Friday fan would enjoy it too.

Kane Hodder and Lexa Doig star in this 2001 horror sequel. Killer, Jason Voorhees terrorizes a space crew after he and a scientist are thawed from being frozen. This starts with Jason (Hodder) being held at a research facility where a young scientist, Rowan (Doig) studies him. He escapes killing some people and Rowan is chased by him. She traps him in a cryogenic freezer, but accidentally gets locked and frozen outside the room. About 400 Years later, a space crew finds them and thaws them out aboard their ship. Rowan wakes up learning it's the future and that Jason is still alive. Jason begins his killing spree and Rowan helps the remaining crew members fight against him. This could've been better, but I like Jason's look later in the film. I still recommend this for your Friday the 13th collection.

reviews.review_title: Let the bodies hit the floor...
reviews.content:
The trailer for Jason X excited me so much, it looked really cool. Then after watching it I felt satisfied. Like I've said in other reviews...this hasn't got a great story but what you do get is a known horror character doing what he does best, kill, kill kill!Jason racks up an enormous body count in this film and makes it look cool (don't go killing people though). Nice death scenes and some funny one-liners make this film quite enjoyable. Some of the characters were annoying but maybe that was intentional so we could cheer Jason on to kill them.I think this movie would make an excellent video game. You could be Jason trying to kill everyone or you could be a human character trying to stop Jason by setting traps and stuff. I wish they would make a game of it.I loved this movie.
P.S. People who tell the plot of a film in their reviews must be pretty stupid because the plot can be found at the top of the screen. Which means whoever does it is just wasting their time in typing it out. You really should be telling how you felt about the movie.

reviews.review_title: a good slasher but a cheesy end
reviews.content: i think this a thoroughly good horror films which obviously will not match up to the shocks of the first in the series still does what is supposed to and in a fun way. the only problem i have with the film is the cheesy ending in which Jason is ridden into the atmosphere which just looks so cheap it is unbelievable, apart from that i would recommend it to fans of the series and of the genre. there are clever parts in the film and i particularly like the way Jason freezes a woman's head in ice before smashing it on the table, the way he falls back onto the regeneration table is kind of convenient yet this still does not ruin the film, obviously it could do better but it could also do a hell of a lot worse

reviews.review_title: Fun slasher flick, if nothing else
reviews.content: I enjoyed Jason X a little more than other people did because it was fun and it was a cool idea to put Jason in outer space, because the victims can't get off the ship.A bunch of critics hated it, and I have one question for them: "What can you expect from a slasher flick?" It's not gonna be Oscar-worthy, you're not gonna find any Shakespearean acting, and the plot is similar to other slasher flicks. Just take it for what it is.There is no need to really explain the plot, because its just like the other Friday the 13th movies, the acting is a little one-dimensional, and the movie is formulaic and predictable at times, but it's not the "classic of the century", it's a fun slasher flick, nothing more, nothing less, and it serves its purpose.Overall, if you're a hardcore slasher flick fan, you will love the gore, and if you are craving a movie with a story and incredible acting, then you're not gonna find it in this movie. Rating: 6.5/10

reviews.review_title: In the past or in the future it all the same for dumb people
reviews.content: For the fan Jason X was the worst thing that has ever happened to Friday the 13th series but as a guy that find Camp Crystal Lake freaking boring the idea of taking Jason Voorhees to outer space where he can slice dumb futuristic teenager into pieces sound bloody genius to me.All characters in this movie is just an object for Jason to testing his new workout location and upgrade beside Kay-Em 14 an android girl who pull out while a fight with Jason that both incredibly stupid and awesome at the same time.Of all the Friday the 13th movie I really can find myself watch Jason X again if i want a quick fun slasher time

Listen... A Friday the 13th installment isn't gonna take home a bunch of Academy awards so the criteria I have for the franchise is: does it entertain? And this sure as hell does. See this with a couple of good friends, grab some beverages of your choosing and just have a really fun time! It includes one of the coolest (oooops!) kills of Jason's career and it still looks pretty damn fine some 20 years after it's premier.

Jason Ten (2001) takes place in an unspecified time period. Jason Ten and a female scientist (the very hot Lexa Doig) are frozen in time and are put into an inadvertent suspended animation (Jason V was put in "special custody" by the United States Government, they wanted to study is inhuman healing power so they could create a army of super soldiers). A team of salvages were snooping around a "dead" Earth searching for valuable relics. The crew picks up Lexa and Jason. The crew doesn't know what to do with Jason. Insteadof keeping him on ice. He's reanimated. After putting in some work, Jason is trapped and thrown into a room that is used to accelerate medical conditions. When he emerges, he becomes uber Jason and rips apart the spaceship looking for people to kill. The shocked crew tries everything to stop him. But nothing seems to work. In a desperate move, the destroy the ship. Lexa and the surviving crew members flee to safety whilst one crew member sacrifices himself (in a funny homage to DARK STAR) to eradicate Jason once and for all. Does it work? That's for you to decide.An entertaining entry in the Jason Vorhees Saga. this film is also known as Part Ten. Since this movie takes place in "The Future", we don't know what time period this film takes place in. Let's just say it's WAY after Jason versus Freddy. Not a classic film, take it for what it's worth.Recommended for Jason fans.

It is 2455 and Tellus is an inhospitable place. A few researcher found two down-frozen bodies. They try to wake up the bodies. The first one is a girl and the other one is a serial killer called Jason Voorhees which is very danger and they try to stop him.The acting is mediocre in this horror-film. It is also a very cool and a well-done horror-movie, because it up in the space. You can also see very brutal and bloody special-effects.Jason Voorhees is very cool in his mask and he which act Jason is a very good actor.Recommended!

"Jason X" is the tenth installment in the "Friday the 13th" series. This time, it's 25th century and earth is no longer an inhabitable place for the human race. So, a group of people on a spaceship receive two cryogenically frozen bodies. After unthawing the frozen beings, one of them turns out to be the legendary killer Jason Voorhees. And of course, unfreezing him has brought old Jason back to life. After killing off a whole investigation crew, Jason begins a rampage among the giant spacecraft, killing off anyone and everyone who even comes close to crossing his deadly path.While this movie is fairly enjoyable, the entire idea of "Jason in space" doesn't sit well with me. Why bring one of cinema's most legendary murderers into outer space, the idea is a bit ridiculous if you ask me. Despite this major flaw, "Jason X" is a pretty fun little horror movie. The story - while it is just a little unbelievable - works on most levels. The whole space-age atmosphere to the film was interesting, so any sci-fi fans can relate a little (unfortuantely I'm not one of them). The cast was mostly a bunch of no-name actors, but they all give fairly good performances, keeping in mind this is a Friday the 13th sequel (and the tenth one, might I add). There was one really well-thought up killing in the film that I thought was extremely unique and clever. I won't say anything to give it away, but I'm sure that you'll know what it is when you see it, I thought it was pretty cool.Overall, "Jason X" is a campy horror movie. While the special effects and acting are decent, the whole premise of the movie is pretty silly. If you don't take the film too seriously, you may find it to be enjoyable. This is perfect for any "Friday the 13th" fan who may also be fond of the sci-fi genre, but for all others it may be kind of dumb. Nonethless, it's brainless fun. 5/10.

The crucial line in this needless futuristic updating of the Crystal Lake critter is the one uttered near the end by the most likable character in the film just as she is about to be dispatched to the next world by our Jason: "This sucks on so many levels!" The word "obnoxious" has been wildly overused by the undersigned of late but, nevertheless, it once again perfectly encapsulates the characters populating this slasher movie/space saga foremost among them the kinky Professor who has his own greedy designs on Jason's future and the female robot assistant who indulges in an ultimately futile, would-be balletic duel with Jason (or rather his 25th Century upgrade, Uber-Jason)) which sticks out like a sore thumb! I can't write this review without mentioning the most unintentionally funny death scene in the entire series (even if it was all happening in Jason's head) i.e. his beating to death a girl in a sleeping bag with her own companion enclosed in a similar bag!! Incredibly enough, New Line took the Cronenbergian admiration shown in their previous entry to the next level here by managing to convince the maverick Canadian film-maker himself to make a very early appearance in the film as an authority figure of some sort intent on studying the remains of Jason which have been conveniently preserved in a freezing compartment of a hi-tech lab (or something); mercifully, we are spared the vision of his unsurprising comeuppance at the hands of the revived Jason which happens soon after...

Wow, this is the most ironic part in the Friday The 13th series I ever saw (I haven't been so lucky to see parts IV, VIII and IX, yet). When I heard this movie takes place in the future.... in space... I had already written it off. But, hey! The special effects are surprisingly fine, the actors are okay and there are indeed some (intentionally) funny moments (like: "This oughta do"). Of course, "Jason X" is far away from being a good movie but for horror-fans like me there's nothing to complain about. There's little logic and lots of gore and at least one really inventive way of killing a girl (the frozen face sequence). So, everybody who loves these never-ending horror-series à la Nightmare on Elm Street/Halloween: watch this. It's a good sequel for a change!

reviews.review_title: Better camera, acting, sfx but oh my goooooooood!!!
reviews.content: Oh my, what the hell!!! Hahahah!!! Jason goes to Space, Ernest goes to the beach and I laughted sooo hard. The actors are much better than in the prequels, camera and effects are very good, but who on earth wrote that script? This Cyberjason was just ridiculous. You can't blame it on the budget, this was ruined by the story. SciFiSlasher sucks!!! I hope the same cast and team gest the chance to do a movie with a good script. Anyhow, it's made solid, watchable and entertaining, but stupid.

reviews.review_title: First Jason I saw in the theaters
reviews.content: Ok, I've been a fan of past Jason films and always wondered how they could show cooler death scenes of stupid people. This movie does that. Only thing I wish is that when Jason is rebuilt they should of had a rocking fight scene and death scenes to the music from the trailer, Let the bodies hit the floor. That would of made it better.

reviews.review_title: In space....Jason will make you scream!
reviews.content: Anyone who's anyone will know exactly who Jason is. A horror icon as famous as the dream demon Freddy Krueger. This movie is about Jason on the rampage in space which might sound like the bosses at New Line Cinema are running out of ideas but this is a great film. Because this is set in the future, technology has become more advanced making for some creative and gruesome death scenes which is more than satisfying. There is also a lot of (intentional) humour here with the characters saying the most idiotic things, for example the characters are in a room with Jason outside Rowan: "i think he's still out there!" Ganessa: "Why don't you stick your head out and have a peek?" This is easily the best film in the Jason franchise (with the exception of Freddy Vs Jason) and everyone should see it...already seen it? see it again!!

The last of the original "Friday the 13th" series, and the least. Jason is put into deep freeze sometime in the 21st Century, but gets thawed out as a scientific curiosity during a student field trip aboard a spacecraft in the far off future. Kane Hodder returns for his fourth and final go-round as Jason and is his usual dependable self. The idea of featuring "Jase In Space" sounds absurd at first, but it works within the movie because despite his surroundings, Jason himself still remains rooted in his mindless and indiscriminating killing persona; this time he just happens to be a victim trapped in a world beyond his understanding or control. However, what really weakens this one substantially for me is that there are too many dumb jokes, and these teenagers who are supposed to be from the year 2455 still look, act, and spout dopey colloquialisms exactly like today's dopey teenagers. The writing and dialogue in particular could have been much better. A few highlights include the "liquid nitrogen face death" (one of the top kills in Jason history) and the humorous "virtual reality sequences". At least the ending devised an interesting way to eliminate Jason once and for all. ** out of ****

This movie knows it's bad. It doesn't pretend to be anything more than it being about Jason slicing and dicing in outer space. So does the movie get a pass? Is it a so bad it's good movie?There are definitely moments that are too silly even when you suspend your disbelief. As the plot moves forward the movie becomes more over-the-top and unbelievable.However I liked the attempt to create something new. The mix of a horror icon with Sci-Fi. There were a lot of funny and scary scenes. I liked how the movie doesn't take itself seriously and the characters have corny jokes and one liners. Some of the scenes with Jason were scary and I also liked the futuristic environment used for survival. It was an interesting dimension to a slasher movie.So even though it isn't the most memorable horror movie it was still entertaining.

Jason X is one of the best of the series. It has comedy mixed with horror and you have to admit the special effects (for a F13 film) are pretty good. Don't listen to these idiots who go on and on about how "BAD" the acting is, Friday the 13th isn't trying to win an oscar, or be the summer blockbuster. Anyway Friday the 13th is to good for the Oscars, everyone knows only crap is nominated. Well take my advise just sit back have fun, this movie is great, you'll laugh, you'll jump, you'll have fun. I will keep my fingers crossed that this is the start for a come back for the franchise.

Okay I went to see Jason X twice this weekend, I was shocked! This movie was so good. I was not expecting anything like this. It was funny, but yet kept you on the edge of your seat. It never slowed down, and that's what I like. This proves that Jason will be around for at least a few more sequels. (At least we can hope) Jason Lives!! This movie is awesome, a must see!!

Alrighty now.. the long awaited 10th film in the legendary "Friday the 13th" movie series hits theatres and what is the result? If you liked the previous nine you will like this one, if the hockey masked machete wielding Jason Voorhees isnt your cup of tea then you should probably avoid the latest installment in the franchise. In this film, Jason (once more played by stuntman Kane Hodder) is placed in suspended animation and winds up getting thawed out on a spaceship some 400 or so years later to wreck havoc on a hapless group of hollywood newbies who decided to audition for this film. Actualy the cast is pretty good as this sort of thing goes and the producers decided to have some fun with the concept, throwing in everything from an obvious "Alien" inspired storyline to a "Terminatrix" babe (played by Lisa Ryder, who like co-star Lexa Doig hails from the "Andromida" TV Series). Some funny bits with Jason and a pointed parody of the original film due to a virtual reality simulation (!) make this one a step above most of the efforts in this series. So, until Jason rises again, this one is a keeper for fans of slasher movies worldwide. GRADE: B+

reviews.review_title: He's back and out of this world.
reviews.content: Jason Voorhees part ten? The hockey-masked maniac thaws from a cryogenic freeze and goes on a killing spree aboard a spaceship in the year 2455. Enough said? Thought so. Kane Hodder is the machete slicing and dicing Jason. Also in the cast are:Lisa Ryder, Melyssa Ade, Chuck Campbell and Lexa Doig.

The creators of this movie don't seem to quite know what they want to accomplish here. There's a strong sense of parody and a sense of humor in the advertising campaigns, but this doesn't really kick in until about the last third of the movie. Before then it's pretty much bog-standard "generic horror flick" with some minimal nods to the updated science-fiction setting. Once the creators start having a little fun with the s.f. elements, and the KM unit gets upgraded into your typical "leather clad dominatrix/fighter" persona from most video games,  things start to kick in a bit. Not surprisingly, Lisa Ryder as KM is about the only person who seems to be having any fun with her part.  The virtual Crystal Lake is also a good idea, although tossed away way too quickly. The ending is also kinda cute in a circular/self-parody kinda way.
