Unfortunately, it's pretty boring for the first two-thirds, and the audience I was with didn't laugh once at any of the funny stuff in the early stuff. Overall, not too good and probably should have gone with direct-to-video.

I don't understand how you guys can find this movie predictable and boring. The deaths were such creative, the scenario was very innovator and the acting was good. How can it be the worst thriller ever? The only bad thing for me is that they took too long to finish the movie. They could have avoided some comes and goes about the spacecraft's security which was unnecessary, but the non-clichéd ending made up for this. Am I the only one who didn't find plot holes in here? I mean, it's extremely hard to find a horror movie without lots of them, and this movie surprisingly avoided it.I could notice a criticism to the capitalism system, accusing it of putting money above people. It also reminded me of "The Cube(1996)", even though their criticism was about job's alienation. A good watch for horror fans, and I hope watching good movies like that in future.

reviews.review_title: A Damn Good Outer Space Time With That Ticked Off Goalie
reviews.content: I saw this movie alone in the movie theater, and I'll tell you, I enjoyed the hell out of it. It is an honest to goodness horrible movie.  I am so glad that movies like this are still made.  This baby is a corker.  The actors are horrible, the teenagers are stupid, and Jason is in rare form, even though he has been frozen for like 2,000 years. They have really taken this franchise as far as it can go, but I hope that they take it further.  They should go every other, like one crazy sci fi Jason film followed by one set in the present day.  I wish it was the 80s, where you could count on Jason every year like taxes.  This is one of my favorites out of the series, simply because it is so damn hilarious and bad.

reviews.review_title: Some people think this movie ruins the quality of the Jason franchise? Seriously?
reviews.content: This was an interesting idea and a lot of fun. What bugs me is when I read reviews by people that think that this movie somehow ruins the quality of the Friday the 13th franchise and that this movie is too "hokey" and unrealistic. Are you serious? This from the franchise where in the very first movie we are supposed to believe that a middle aged, average sized woman can overpower numerous men and athletic teenage boys? And where Jason has been drowned, mutilated, burned, exploded, and buried, and yet still is alive in the next film? Has this series ever been known for its realism? The point is that from the very first "Friday the 13th", there are numerous aspects that force the viewer to check his or her sense of the realistic at the door. This is a decent "Jason" movie and is well worth a viewing. I actually liked the fun jabs at itself and the franchise this movie has, and overall is pretty decent. 6 machetes out of 10......

Honestly, this is a bad film. Some of the most annoying characters in a film, most jokes never land at all, no horror, no suspense, some weird score...well, at least Jason was ok, the first scene was good and we had some good deaths.

The one in space.Admittedly, I may have jumped the shark calling Part 8 the worst of the franchise. If only I knew what I know now. Times were simpler back then. I should've savored that guy getting his head punched off into a dumpster, because Jason X may actually be the worst big budget movie of all time.Sure 14 million isn't close to the big budgets of today, but it has the biggest budget of the entire series! (Not counting Freddy vs Jason which has a 25 million dollar budget.) Part 6 is still a legitimately fun movie that was made for less then 6 million. This had nearly 3 times the budget of that and it looks like a student film. Did they hire people that were fresh out of high school to save money??It's set nearly 500 years after...who knows when because Jason went to hell in the last one, so how did he get out? When did he get out? Or are they ignoring that one and making this as a sequel to Jason Takes Manhattan? If that is the case that would be quite fitting. Having two of the worst horror movies ever made directly linked would be a happy coincidence. Anyway, this takes place in 2455 or something because why not?You'd think doing this would be very creatively freeing. You could have Jason wandering around fantastical sets, using futuristic weapons, and maybe you could have the humans of the future be pacifists so Jason could go on an absolute killing spree. But no, instead it's just Friday the 13th in a metal death trap they prentend is a space ship. Which you never buy, even for a second. The film has a blatant lack of imagination to the point of lunacy.Even Jason is completely uninspired in this. He wanders around slashing people with a regular machete. But it's futuristic because it's slightly curved and has holes for some reason. That's really the biggest issue here, a lack of creativity. It's the future because everything is metal and people wear slightly more tattered clothes, but there's still midterms. The sets look absurdly cheap, the cinematography is ugly and constantly underexposed, and the performances are series worst across the board.It's baffling how bad this is actually, and quite difficult to verbalize. This series has been quite the disappointment on the whole but this brings it to unwatchable levels. Even the worst entries have a certain camp or goofiness that keeps them afloat. There is no such thing here. It takes itself deadly serious, which is odd considering it features a robot trying to put fake nipples on to please her programmer. The dialogue is terrible, the premise sucks, the characters are annoying, the kills are bland, the sets are hideous, and it's inexcusably cheap looking for being the most expensive in the franchise (minus the next two).

reviews.review_title: An enjoyable entry to the series
reviews.content: Well it took 9 years for a new 'Friday the 13th' movie, & I was weary when I heard that the movie was going to take place in space...but I'm sure glad I was wrong! Unlike other movie franchises that tried to make the jump into space, the F-13 series really didn't change much; which is a good thing. Many people were glad that Jason eventually left the woods, but like part 8 showed, that wasn't such a good thing. The movie starts off in present time where Jason is going to be frozen, since he cannot be killed. But an accident freezes both Jason & a scientist at the Camp Crystal Lake Research Facility. The movie cuts to the year 2455 next. A scientist & his students are visiting Earth for a scientific expedition (Earth has become a wasteland planet). They stumble onto the facility, & bring back Jason & the scientist's bodies back to their ship. When the scientist is brought back to life, she warns them about Jason, but it is too late. He wakes up & starts on his killing rampage...again. Like in so many movies, Jason is yet 'killed' again, but due to the ship's medical lab, he is 'upgraded' & becomes stronger than ever. Even though the movie takes place in space, it is still a F-13 film at heart. The space environment doesn't change that. The movie is fresh, with some great death scenes & nice one-liners. And the ending leads up to a new sequel. Since this movie has been getting some decent reviews & has made some money, hopefully we will get a new F-13 film or the long delayed 'Freddy Vs. Jason' film very soon. This movie is a lot of fun...go check it out!

I understand it was made it 2001 but damn the cgi was terrible. some things made no sense to meif she said nothing can kill him why would they think men with guns can
they were pretty calm when they found out everyone else was dead
shes over 455 year old but know how to use a gun from the current year

reviews.review_title: The final frontier, and another shark jumped
reviews.content: In the future, Jason(who poses like a runway model in this... often just long enough for everyone else in sight to drop a terrible one-liner) is experimented on. Just as he's about to be frozen, David Cronenberg shows up to take him away, and he and his people are killed by you-know-who(he uses a magically appearing machete). Rowan, a scientist, traps him in a cryogenic chamber that evidently allows both of them(she's put to sleep too) to move after they shouldn't be able to. Years pass, somehow with no one stopping to check on this area, and Earth dies... yet the power remains on. We're about ten minutes in, people. I've already lost count of the plot holes. Anyway, he's brought onto a ship centuries later, and goes on the largest murder spree(there is no stalking in this, though a portion or two has him viciously attack without us knowing exactly where he is at first) of any of these, with an excessive amount of characters(most of whom are easily forgotten, and a few of whom are obnoxious) so that you will not be able to remember everyone(even not-Tony Todd and female Data), to ensure that many can be wasted. This has great FX and is filmed and edited quite nicely. It's too bad that nothing has an impact. We don't care about anyone and the futuristic sci-fi action setting takes a lot of the power of the untimely demise of anyone(can't everyone just use that nano-thing to heal?). With that said, they do get cool, unique death scenes out of where and when we are... in fact, the majority of them are creative and memorable. This is a bit like a low-rent remake of Alien(with a bit of Cameron's sequel thrown in for good measure) with Mr. X in place of H.R. Giger's infamous creature. The designs are nice. Dialog is poor, as is acting. This is never funny, in spite of countless attempts. There are points in this where you have no idea where people are in relation to one another. This is 84 minutes long sans credits. The DVD comes with an interesting and occasionally amusing commentary track by the director, writer and producer, two featurettes that I will review on their individual pages here on the site, Jump to a Death and a theatrical trailer. There is a lot of violence, blood and gore, and a little sex and nudity in this. I recommend this to fast-food type fans(if you want a fix, nothing that lasts) of slasher flicks and this franchise. 5/10

Why the haters? This is non stop entertainment with decent deaths. It's sooooo stupid which just makes it more fun to watch. Yes it's loaded with flaws but which Jason film isn't. Just enjoy it for what it blatantly is.
Though I wish they had gone farther with the scares, it's still a very fun/enjoyable entry to the series.

reviews.review_title: Jason in all his glory. Dedicated only to fans.
reviews.content:
Let the bodies hit the floor!Jason is back and there's no possible way that he's returning to hell. "JASON X" is a great sequel. I'm a die hard fan of the Friday the 13th movies, and other fans have to agree that this movie rocks because it's all about Jason. And now way he's a sell out unlike other villians... Jason Voorhees returns and now the devil has something to fear.
For example, pretend it's your birthday and you are 8 years old. It's your day, and everything it's only for you : the clown, presents, the cake, everything. Your parents pay for a birthday party with the purpose that you will have more fun that the others. JASON X is the same case. The fans pay to see JASON doing his favorite thing : slashing dumb teens and anyone that gets on his way. Fans complained in JASON GOES TO HELL because there wasn't enough Jason, and in JASON X we get Jason all the time! Besides we get PLENTY of gore, creative death scenes, a very very PI**ED off Jason, hot chicks, a cool setting, even a good score.THE OLD DAYS... In some moments, the feeling inside the previous Friday the 13th movies was present. The creepy atmosphere, the "ki ki ki" and Jason looking mean brought some old memories. *MINOR SPOILERS* All of the death scenes show that Jason hates any living thing, and this time around he has no compassion for anyone unlike in previous films. Oh no, Jason shows no mercy. His machete had a lot of work in this one. The VR Camp Crystal lake setting is pure gold! It shows Jason in all of his glory. Those were the days where Jason would slash anyone around his territory. The death scenes, the score, the direction (which I must say is pretty good) and of course Jason brought the Friday the 13th style back. -END OF SPOILERS-THE NEW FRIDAY THE 13th Ok, maybe the plot is kind of (!) cheesy but the series needed a new story. The film has lots of black humor and this is why some people think that it's a cheesy film in general. Sometimes the humor is necessary to break tension.Overall, this is a good slasher and it's because there's Jason Voorhees. This is a movie to add proudly to the Friday series, and that's it. It won't change future plots, and it won't change Jason's fate. This is a reward for all the die hard fans that waited to see Jason lifting his machette again.Yes, we waited 9 years for this movie to happen, and I'm proud to say that the wait was worth. JASON X will be followed by  FREDDY V.S. JASON next summer. Movie in which Jason Voorhees will kick some seriously Freddy's ass! Come on, we all know that our loved hockey masked killer is the best out there. Just wait to see. Long live to the Friday the 13th movies!

reviews.review_title: This Movie Is Great! Underrated Film
reviews.content: Jason X Is A Very Underrated Film. I Unironically Love This Film It Is Awesome! Jason Is Amazing And When He Turns Into Uber-Jason Is AWESOME! The Main Characters Are Cool. The Kills Are Amazing. And This One Has The Best Kill In The Series. The Film Is Funny. I Actually Thought It Was Cool How They Were In Space. The Jokes Are Really. I Love Jason X!

reviews.review_title: I'd say this is better than Jason Goes to Hell, but still nothing special overall
reviews.content: Jason X (2001) is the next Friday the 13th film I watched from my personal collection. The storyline is very "alien" like where a ship in space comes across an old spacecraft with Jason cryogenically frozen inside. Of course Jason receives an electric current that sparks him back to life and the killing spree begins. This movie is directed by James Issac (Pig Hunt) and stars David Cronenberg (yes, the director), Peter Mensah (300 and Spartacus), Lexa Doig (Andromeda) and Markus Parilo (Fargo). The storyline for this isn't that great and reminded me of a made for television film in terms of the special effects, especially the outer space scenes. I did like the virtual reality game components, and the old hockey mask in space scenes and references, but there isn't much memorable here outside space being the primary setting. Well, Jason did have the scene where he dry iced her face and smashed her head on the sink...that was cool. Overall, I'd say this is better than Jason Goes to Hell, but still nothing special overall. I'd score this a 4.5/10.

reviews.review_title: Is this the best they could come up with?
reviews.content:
Warning: may be some spoilersYou know, back in the day, Jason was actually scary.  He was a true killing machine that could strike fear in those that watched his films and worshipped him in some way.  But as the films and years went on, something strange and unfortunate happened; Jason got incredibly bland and worse than that he became a cheap caricature of himself.  Jason was once the epitome of fear, now he is just an after-thought.  This is a tangential film that only bears the villains name to remind us what once was.  And my advice to Sean Cunningham is to either stop making the Friday films all together or get back to the old formula or what was once remembered as a proud franchise that pioneered the horror craze in the 80's is going to sink under it's own ineptitude.  And this is coming from one of it's biggest fans.  Please, make it better.Can you remember back to the early Friday's?  Can you remember what made watching the films so much fun?  It was the fact that first of all, Jason was scary but moreso he was also very phlegmatic, like Michael Myers was. He didn't take things personally, he just killed without passion.  He was the ultimate killer.  In the first four films, Jason was nothing more than a boy who had grown up to kill with an insatiable need for blood and corpses. Now the franchise has gone off on it's own little tangent and subjected Jason to a ridiculous folklore that just doesn't fit with who he was.  Part 9 dropped the ball by inundating us with that stupid "special knife" story and a sister angle when all of us know damn well that he was an only child. Face it, unless you are George Lucas, you cannot introduce family members late into a story and get away with it.  So Jason goes to Hell with Freddy bringing him there but now he in space and he decides that he has to kill again and again and again but with no real passion.  There is no stalking in this one, there is no desperation.  All we have is Jason rounding a few corners and killing the next person that no one cares about.  At least in the earlier ones we knew a little bit about who he was killing.  Think Tommy Jarvis, think Shelly, think of Chris, think of Ginny and Paul and Rick and so on.  There was at least a bit of character development to the people that Jason was slaughtering.  There was also a legend and most of all there was atmosphere.  And correct me if I am way off base here, but didn't James Cameron already take this premise and do it much better in 1986 with guys like Bill Paxton, Lance Henrikson and Michael Biehn?There was one very well done scene in Jason X and that was when he is in VR Crystal Lake.  Someone else commented that all of a sudden the film became interesting again when he was there.  You could hear the music, you could see the cabins and the lake and suddenly that comforting feeling of Jason at Crystal Lake was omnipresent again.  Jason X doesn't have the slightest idea of what it was that made the franchise so successful in the first place. 
This is one of the lousiest films I have seen and I was sure that nothing could top part nine and eight as the worst Friday's but this one does.0 out of 10

reviews.review_title: slashing by CGI and not by Jason...
reviews.content: And again he rises from his grave. It's hard to understand how he resurrected because he's being killed in part 9. But again, money makes the world go around. Kane Hodder was asked to play Jason again and he did, because fans loved him, he gave Jason his own type of looking. His head always moves before his body does. Betsy Palmer was in the neighborhood when they were shooting Jason X but she just say NO to appear in this, for me, the worst in the series. I had difficulties watching it, and I even almost fall asleep. Jason goes to space and immediately I remembered the other failure were pinhead goes to space. For me it's just not done. Even as the amount of killings is the most here in part 10. It's the killings that made me yawn. We've entered the era of CGI and that's what we are getting. Some are good and couldn't be done without CGI, just look at the scene with the girls frozen face. Although Halloween did it before without CGI with the burned face of a nurse in boiling water. Anyhow, it's a bit of Alien with Jason being the creature. This part of the series wasn't for me...

In the year 2455, a group of students on an trip to visit "old earth" and find two cryogenic ally frozen bodies. One is a young woman ( Lexia Doig) and the other is none other than Jason Voorhees(Hodder). They bring both bodies on board their spacecraft, where both subjects eventually thaw out and the one wearing the goalie mask goes on a murder spree.When I first heard that the 10th entry in the franchise is gonna be Jason in outer space, I thought that it sounded stupid and was gonna be rubbish but when I saw the film I was pleasantly surprised, sure it was corny and the story line is ridiculous but I loved it Jason is back and he's on form unlike the disappointing previous entry "Jason Goes To Hell".This 10th chapter in the "Friday the 13th" franchise retains the same energy as the previous entries but delivers it in a spaceship setting. You want to see Jason put "Rambo" to shame as he hunts down some ex-grunts? Right here, a-holes! Or how about Jason going mano-a-mano against a leather-clad, gun-toting female Android? You got it! Jason X has its fair share of slash and crash, but at the same time, it emanates an "Aliens" (an obvious inspiration) type of vibe. Some purists might say that's a negative thing, but I believe that after nine films, Jason needed a change of scenery like I needed a new "bootie call". They slapped old hockey-puss in space and managed to pull it off. Props to all! Okay the film is low budget but I found the special effects were pretty good, the spacecraft simple yet effective costumes are colourful. I particularly enjoyed the S&M-like outfit that Kay-Em (Ryder) sported after getting her robotic cherry popped. Nice! Our boy Jason hasn't changed much. He felt more human this time around though (he has hair!) and doesn't look like the zombie he was in part 6-7-8-9. I found Jason less menacing than he was in "Friday The 13th Part 7", but he still got the grisly job done. I also loved it when Jason gets the big terminator style makeover where he's all metal and robotic and such and such like. The fight sequence between Jason and the robot woman is definitely the highlight of the film and the kills are wicked and fresh.The good thing is that "Jason X" is just a good cheesy slasher and it doesn't pretend to be anything else but that. Yes, the good guys are weak and the film doesn't always capitalise on its groovy situations but we still get lots of explosions, kills, fights sequences, some occasional funny dialogue, some humorous situations (loved the Virtual Reality sequence) and Jason even gets to re-visit "Crystal Lake" to entertain two female campers in his own charming way.Kane Hodder (Jason) gives Jason more of a human personality this time around, but I didn't find him as threatening as he was in the previous entries. Lexa Doig (Rowan) handles her part well, but I would've liked to see her kick more ass. Lisa Ryder (Kay-Em) steals the show as the sexually curious, Kung Fu android. She has fun with the role. Jonathan Potts (Professor Rowe) does the pathetic creep thing well, but yes, he irritated me. Melyssa Ade (Janessa) is cute and her delivery is on, but her character didn't do it for me. She's kind of despicable. Peter Mensah (Sergeant Brodski) was charming as the resilient Marine. I loved every second that he was on screen. Chuck Campbell (Tsunaron) bored me as the geek and he had his moments of "weak" acting.All in all being a hardcore Jason fan I absolutely loved this entry in the Friday The 13th series, I loved the female robot, the action sequences, the kills and the over the top special effects.

It's Jason part ten. By the time this movie was released twenty years ago, it had also been twenty years since the original with Betsey Palmer was released back in 1980. Time flies.Anyway, I thought this movie was okay for what it is. By now, especially after Jason Goes to Hell, the shark had been jumped by a mile. So why not go to outer space and kill people in the future? Why not freeze Jason Voorhees and resurrect him hundreds of years later? Because at this point, do you really care?That said, the kills are actually quite well planned out and creative. The nudity is there. The characters are as silly as the previous camp counselors. It really doesn't take itself that seriously, which really works in the movies favor. It's complete camp, and that's the best thing they could have done.

Jason's in space killing people. Why on earth not? Jason X had the good fortune of following 1993's Jason Goes to Hell, where the formula had already been flushed down the toilet. Jason Goes to Hell was so bad and by comparison Jason X fares extremely well. So, why not send Jason to space; I mean, it's something he hadn't done before. If you put yourself in the right frame of mind and realize that you have to have zero expectations; Jason X goes down rather well, surprisingly enough.In an amusing prologue, featuring David Cronenberg no less, Jason gets frozen along with a female scientist slated to be his next victim. A crew aboard a spaceship in the year 2455 picks them up and head back to Earth 2 (since our beloved planet earth is no longer habitable). Soon, Jason comes to life again and starts killing off the crew members in his usually grisly fashion. So, what does the year 2455 hold in store for us that's similar today? Well, the most striking thing is that teenagers and adults alike don't seem to get any smarter as time goes by.While this is a silly film, and I mean SILLY (writing, idiotic characters, sci-fi ripoffs from countless films etc. ) Jason X is an enjoyable time waster for fans of the series. His kills are quite inventive and well done, in fact the whole production values of the film were impressive, compared to it's low budget. The whole notion of Jason being in space is of course ludicrous but I must admit it turned out to be a lot more enjoyable than I thought.

You either love this movie, or you hate it. There's not a lot of middle ground to be found here. I don't know if the filmmakers were shooting for it, but they achieved a level of shlockiness that just.... works. Is it a stupid premise? Yes. Is it ridiculously predictable? You bet your a**. But be honest, none of us watched this for high drama or Hollywood gold, because we knew it wasn't going to be here. This franchise became a cliche over a decade ago, and this film is pure, distilled cliche. Knowing that going in let's you just enjoy a film that doesn't take itself, or the genre, too seriously. I'd bet real money that 95% of the people who watched this at least giggled at, "It'll take more than that to put this old dog down; yup, that oughta do it." You don't have to love this movie, but don't look down on it because it isn't on a par with 'Casablanca'. Accept it for what it is: 90 minutes of just plain goofy, sometimes terrible, occasionally effective, jokes and one liners.

I have come to the conclusion that a good portion of the people who submit reviews for films like Jason X do so simply for the "thrill" of seeing their names or e-mail addresses on screen.  Seems a lot of you would be better off attending an autopsy in your area than watching a movie that is supposed to simply be entertaining.  Given that the previous Friday films had run out of steam, it made all the sense in the world to try to steer the franchise in a whole new direction.  Where the original Fridays were nothing more than T&A/slashfests, it is a formula that loses it's appeal after so many sequels.  If Jason X accomplishes anything here, it is injecting some life into an otherwise stagnating series.We know Jason cannot die...he has proven that, time and again.  Thus, we no longer watch to see if he will finally be killed.  Instead, we wait for him to die, just to see how he'll manage to come back anyway!  The method of this in Jason X is obvious from early on, but it still works.  The "new and improved" Jason is worth the wait for, even though he is not on screen all that long.As has been the staple of all the previous installments, the characters in Jason X were, for the most part, just killings waiting to happen.  I think it's a safe bet that, if there is a Jason XI, it won't involve anyone from MENSA!  Face it, the characters in any Jason film are there for the sole purpose of running, screaming and dying.  Any personality or acting ability that shines through, above and beyond those three things, is always a plus. In this case, I found most of the acting very credible, considering the circumstances.  I was especially taken by Melyssa Ade (Janessa) who, in my humble opinion, stood out in every scene she was in.  All I can say, to those of you who are reading these reviews before renting Jason X, is to go ahead and rent it, and watch it with an open mind.  If you're looking to be entertained, it does deliver the goods.  If you're looking for a 90 minute bloodbath, maybe Faces of Death would be a better selection for you....

Scream came and gone, It made it's mark in movie history that's true. Of course all those 90's horror movies that made a big splash will all be forgotten, but Jason will still be slaughtering teens and given us thrills. Friday the 13th has been around for over 20 years and isn't going anywhere.
I have been a huge fan of this series, I've been watching them since I was 8 years old and I've seen them come and go from theaters, seen critics dismiss them, and have had to defend them from people that just don't get it. You just can't take them seriously, just have fun with them.
Jason X was actually the best of the series, Jason jumped right in there and one by one by one took over the ship. People also keep trying to reject the special effects in this movie, which is crazy, they were awesome, I think what bothers people is that some movies like Lord Of The Rings, and Star wars use these unbelievable budgets for special effects, then Jason X comes along and with a mere 14 mil creates awesome effects. Friday The 13th has made it's mark in movie history, with 10 chapters and another one on the way, and I'm sure there is more to come.

Jason X is the best Friday the 13th yet. Can't wait for Freddy Vs. Jason and all you people that hate this movie and hate Friday the 13th, keep your stupid lame opinions to yourself! Jason's back! And they'll never stop making these movies cause people like me will always be first in line and see them time and time again.

I am so tired of people bashing this movie, I mean come on it's the 10th installment of Friday The 13th. This movie was excellent when you really think about it. This time they got it right, all we really want to see is Jason take out as many people as he can in 90 minutes. Friday the 13th whether you like it or not is a part of American cinema history, just like Star Wars and James Bond. I really think what makes people mad is the fact the Jason X proved that special effects are not hard to come by these days, I mean get real if Jason X with a 14 million dollar budget had the effects it had then why the hell does Stars Wars need 100 million. Can't wait for Jason VS Freddy next year maybe then this franchise will get the recognition that it SO deserves. Here's some advice for all you critics out there, Friday The 13th is just fun, just sit back with friends have a few beers and enjoy. Don't take it seriously.

In 2455, serial killer Jason Voorhies(the film confirms he murdered over 200 victims)is accidentally set free from cryogenic stasis to dismantle and destroy a crew on board a transport ship heading home. Along with Jason was Rowan(Lexa Doig)who tried to stop Jason back home on earth where they were both found..it was indeed her who trapped Jason in the cryogenic chamber, was stabbed by Jason using his trademark machete from the inside through her on the outside which opens the coolant to freeze her as well. She understands what kind of zombie monster he is as explained with how they tried many other aspects and methods of death which wouldn't end him. One by one members on board try and fail to stop Jason. Those still alive for the time being contemplate how to escape the ship before he catches up with them.This New Line release, much like the ninth film(JASON GOES TO HELL), takes the Jason model and tries to spin a new, different type of story set in the future allowing the monster fresh new ways to kill humans. Supporters of Jason enacting bloodshed in his normal environs might balk, but a chance to see him out of his normal routine is refreshing. And, the flick plays it's wacky premise to the hilt. The computer effects are decent, if less stellar than normal bigger-budgeted films, but the gore is on display aplenty. One poor soul is cut in half, another is thrown on a drill(the scene shows the man's body sliding down the screw piece), and in the film's best sequence a female medic's head is submerged in cryogenic fluid and smashed over a counter as it shatters into pieces. There's an amusing holograph sequence where they buy time to survive by creating an illusion of Crystal Lake with two nudie cuties distracting Jason. There's even a female android who does battle with Jason(it isn't much of a contest as she has superior firepower that subsequently blows him to bits)..when it appears that he is finally conquered, he is reconstructed by a mechanical device that can repair torn tissue and muscles, into a half-cybernetic being! This is clearly a flick designed for the Friday audience allowing us to see Jason doing what he does best, killing innocents who try their damnedest to escape the terror that awaits them.

reviews.review_title: Jason vs a bunch of dreamy gals
reviews.content: The female cast members of "Jason X" are all ridiculously dreamy. They're all great to watch. They're the only reason I like to come back to "Jason X" once in a while. Otherwise, this movie is not that hot. It's kind of silly after a while. The "Friday the 13th" movies have been pretty consistent over the years. They are usually pretty good. Some of them are really good. "Jason X" misses the mark but, wow, those gals are through the roof.

reviews.review_title: Leave your brain on the doorstep and enjoy.
reviews.content: "Jason X" is silly, campy, ludicrous... and loads of fun. I think the problem here with most negative reviews is that they're taking it too damn seriously. Do yourself a favor and take it with a grain of salt; that's obviously what the filmmakers did. It's a slasher film set in space; what did you expect, "Citizen Kane"? Granted, the whole slasher-in-space thing has been done before with "Hellraiser: Bloodlines" and "Leprechaun 4: In Space," but neither of them were this much fun.First off, we're shown Jason (Kane Hodder) inside a government research lab, never explaining how he escaped from Hell after the ninth film. This is actually explained in "Freddy vs. Jason," which was still stuck in development hell at the time, but if you need any explanation, here's one as good as any other: yes, Jason was pulled into Hell, but they were afraid he'd take over, so they threw him back.Anyway, in an attempt to move the world's most infamous undead mass murderer to another facility, oops... he escapes, killing David Cronenberg and about seven other people in the process. Project head Rowan (Lexa Doig from TV's "Andromeda") manages to freeze him cryogenically, but at the cost of her own non-cryogenic status as well. Fast-forward about four hundred years, and the Earth has become uninhabitable. Human colonists from another planet light-years away descend upon the ruined Earth on a "field trip," and guess who they find? Though Rowan is fortunate enough to finally be resuscitated by them, unfortunately, so is Jason, and he goes back to doing what he does best on board the ship after awakening to the sound of - you guessed it - horny young people doing the dirty. Their only hope is Rowan, android Kay-Em 14 (Lisa Ryder, also of "Andromeda"), and a very bad-ass Sergeant Brodski (Peter Mensah of "Avatar," "300," and "Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles").Is "Jason X" a great movie? Of course not. But that doesn't mean that it's never entertaining. Horror film fans don't go to movies like this to see Oscar-winning performances; they go to see a huge masked guy with a machete who knows how to wield it. Furthermore, in spite of the movie's flaws (of which there are admittedly many), at least this entry in the "Friday the 13th" series takes us out of the whole Camp Crystal Lake setting for once. If this isn't your kind of movie, don't watch it. If it is, grab a few friends and drinks and riff away.

"Jason X" is eight years removed from "The Final Friday" in which Jason supposedly went to hell. I guess he was just visiting. The "Friday the 13th" series jumped the shark ages ago, so nothing in this movie surprised me. They'd long since dispensed with the notion of Jason being human, so why shouldn't he be alive in the year 2455?The movie actually starts in the year 2010 in a facility of some sort where Jason is slated to be cryogenically frozen until a time in which mankind can figure out a way to kill him. He was frozen, but not before adding a few more bodies to his kill count.Over 400 years later he gets discovered and unfrozen whereby he picks up killing again.The premise is quite ridiculous, but at this point I'm used to ridiculousness with Jason. It can't be any more ridiculous than him being brought back to life with a lightning bolt after being dug up from his grave as was done in part 6."Jason X" had some throwback moments in it such as the "Crystal Lake Research Facility," a couple of notes of the ominous music, and some horny young adults. The bulk of the movie takes place on a spaceship, so there were no lakes to go skinny dipping in. Killing Jason was just as impossible as it had always been. It seems that even in the future there are no hand-held weapons that can stop him. He was shot countless times and impaled with a giant hook before an android used a high enough caliber weapon to take his limbs and his head off. That was just a temporary setback because he landed on a regeneration machine that turned itself on and began repairing him with nanobots. He killed a few more people and was killed by being hurled towards Earth 2 (Earth was uninhabitable) where he presumably burned up entering its atmosphere."Jason X" was wholly unnecessary except to make an even number of ten movies or just to say that Jason was active in the 80's, 90's, and 2000's. Final kill count was 21, not including the girl who killed herself trying to get away, or the unknown amount of people at Solaris docking station that the ship plowed through because Jason killed the pilot.

I've always felt a very deep sympathy for Kane Hodder. Kane Hodder, if you didn't know, has played Jason Vorhees in every Friday the 13th movie since Friday the 13th Part VII. I mean, this guy's whole career consists of stalking people with a giant machete and hacking them to bits. And after watching Jason X, I felt an even deeper sympathy for him.Jason X begins in 2010. The government has Jason Vorhees imprisoned and are keeping him alive to study. They figure that anyone who stays alive, despite being killed several times, is worth studying. Rowan (Lexa Doig) feels otherwise. She thinks that he should be put away where no one can find him. Something goes awry and Jason is loose. He disposes of everyone, with just Rowan left. She attacks him and throws him into a Cryogenic unit where he begins to freeze. But, before he freezes completely he stabs his way through the door, and Rowan gets frozen as well. It's now the year 2455. Earth is no longer inhabitable. Professor Lowe (Jonathon Potts) leads a group of students to the remains of Camp Crystal Lake. They find the two frozen bodies and are able to bring Rowan back to life. They assume that Jason is dead and send him to be examined. While being examined, he suddenly wakes up and goes on a wild rampage once again.	 The whole story feels like a bad episode of Andromeda. Nothing really ever makes sense and random things occur that have no relevance to anything. In the first few Friday the 13th movies, Jason actually had a motive, albeit a bad motive, but at least he had one. In Jason X he just knocks people off one by one for no apparent reason. He doesn't know these people, and they aren't remotely related to anything that happened at Camp Crystal Lake, so why murder them?The script, by Todd Farmer, is full of ridiculous dialogue, thickheaded characters, and absurd situations. You'd think by the year 2455 that these people would have seen enough horror movies to know not to split up when there's a maniacal killer on the loose. And they should definitely not assume that the killer is dead when, in fact, he never is. The characters speak the most blasphemous dialogue. These characters seem to think it's necessary to crack a joke right before they die, as if Jason might find the joke funny and spare them. All ten of the Friday the 13th movies all pretty much stick with the same story and setting. Why they needed to upgrade Jason and set it in a spaceship, I don't know. Jason X couldn't stray father from the original even if it tried. The only thing that this and the nine other movies have in common is Jason. Even Jason is starting to look a little worn out. And then just when you thought that the movie couldn't get any more pathetic, Jason gets an upgrade. Jason falls into an upgrade machine that makes him bigger, faster, and meaner. He even gets a new mask!When a movie has a body count higher than the number of people that are going to see it, it's not a good sign.---------0/10

I enjoyed this movie enough to purchase it, and I've watched it at least 3 times. I'm a fan of both Lexa Doig and Lisa Ryder, who've swapped roles here with Lexa being the strong female lead and Lisa playing the android. The pace is great, the actors are professionals, a number of whom have hopped around quite a bit in both film and television, and regularly find work. Plot? Seriously? It's a Friday the 13th film staring Jason Voorhees. If you have the nerve to call yourself a film aficionado, why are you watching a slasher film series that began in the 1970s? And yes, I was there at the beginning. These films are made for entertainment and to make money. It's called show business for a reason. Frankly, I think this is the best film of the series since the first one, which broke new ground for horror at the time. This is a 90 minute B movie that's meant to be an entertaining story. It's not Star Wars, nor is it the film that will change lives and how we view the world. It's just some escapism. A mental vacation to get away for a little bit. Keep the film in perspective and enjoy!

What a movie this is! Now right of the bat this isn't a good movie in the traditional sense. It's got mediocre acting all around and the writing is as schlocky as you can get, filled with puns, meta, and references. But it's not as obnoxious as it sounds.I actually really enjoyed this movie, more so than a few of the previous ones in the franchise. It's really silly, but in a good way in that it just doesn't care about trying to be serious anymore. This is the kind of refresh I needed after so many failed attempts to try and make the film serious again.So here the plot is basically moved to the future and instead of a camp its a spaceship jason is confined to. The teens/students on there are still the same characters and still as stupid as any other F13 film. The lead is not very memorable not smart either, as she's supposed to be an expert on Jason but never comes with any ideas.The way jason looked in this film was alright, he's definitely looked scaries, but his final form is great, not scary but definitely designed well. Now about Jason, the kills in this movie are pretty good with one of them added to ''most memorable kills'' in my opinion, which is the frozen face kill. It's also the best kill of this movie but overall the kills are good. Noticeably a lot of the actual 'killing'' gets censored but there's always some kind of aftermath that is used or shown in a interesting/fun way.Overall I felt this movie was paced pretty well, I didn't hang around too much and felt much easier to watch. The music is a bit iffy, the main theme comes back here and there but it's definitely not used as well here. The directing was alright, just about interesting enough but they really didn't care about building much suspense or making it seem like jason sneaked around, he kinda just appears everywhere full frame.There are some ridiculous scenes though like jason flying from the explosion in space and the Android doing some insane action moves. Like I said before this film definitely leans heavily into the comedy/crazy than the serious.For me its a 5/10, not terrible like Jason going to Manhattan, but also not even close to F13 part II because Jason just never became scary anymore, nor an attempt was ever made.

reviews.review_title: A bit of a sell-out, but nice anyway.
reviews.content: Watching "Jason X" gave me the feeling that it was the most expensive Friday the 13th-production ever. It sure was the most glossy, at least.Plot, short: In the beginning of the 21st century, the authorities decides to do away with Jason for good. As many have tried to kill Jason permanently in any way that are possible (as well as a few that aren't) without success, he's now to be contained instead of killed. A young woman manages to freeze Jason in a cryo-chamber. In the process, she also manages to freeze herself as well. A few centuries later, Jason and the young woman is discovered and picked up by a spaceship, and she is revived by the medical staff onboard. Jason, of course, awakens again, and goes for another killing spree.My opinion is that "Jason X" is well worth watching, at least if you're a Jason junkie, like yours truly. It has all the necessary stuff for a true Friday the 13th-flick, like hot young chicks, big guy with a hockey mask and a bad attitude, and lots of blood and gore. But I also miss the camp-setting, the dark woods, the cabins, and all that you'll get in the older movies in the series. I really loathe any attempt to scientifically explain what Jason is and why he never stays dead - It shouldn't be explained. Jason's a blood-thirsty freak in a hockey mask, who mysteriously comes back to life every now and then. Period. And I don't like the attempts of portraying him as even slightly human - Blood-thirsty freaks in hockey masks aren't supposed to be human or even likable (in preferred order), just scary. But anyway, the sci-fi-setting was quite nice and different, and I suppose that true low-budget-horror-art like this can stand a few experiments with the setting. But anyway, the way I like it, a good Jason-flick should be about a psycho wearing a hockey mask and killing youngsters in the most gruesome and gory ways imaginable, and "Jason X" is. But it doesn't need any expensive CGI or SFX. Ketchup, melee-weapons and gardening tools are more than enough, I'd say.Bottom line: Watchable, but not nearly revolting enough for my taste, and I give it 5 blood-smeared buzz-saws out of 10. Could be worse, could be better.

I'm not a hardcore horror/slasher enthusiast, so I enjoyed this movie, thought it should belong in the comedy/horror section (if there was one). A movie I could enjoy watching again. This is sort of a 'Jason meets Star Trek' blend, certainly not a typical horror film, no doubt hardcore horror/slasher fans are the ones giving it a rating of 1. I thought 'Uber Jason' was great, Lexa Doig is hot hot hot, the scene where Jason beats one topless camping chick with the other topless camping chick in their own sleeping bags in the VR room was hilarious! Some funny tongue in cheek one liners as well. More nude babes would have been nice, though :)

Jason X Directed by Jim Isaac and starring Kane HodderEVIL GETS AN UPGRADEFriday the 13th meets Star Trek, when Jason Voorhees takes a step too far and jumps into space. Gone are the scares which are required for a horror film. Effects at times can be laughable and the acting is a horror all by itself. With a Shatner lookalike Captain, the badly cast actor fail to make any character decent or memorable. Best acting goes to Kane Hodder, who you don't ever see or hear. Definitely the weakest of the franchise.His unique ability to regenerate lost and damaged tissue, it's just it cries out for more research. – Dr. Wimmer (David Cronenberg)

This was a good movie. I really liked it. I'm not much of a Jason fan but like this was a lot better then the other ones by far. The music really sucked in this movie. They could of had better music. But other than that I personally think this was the second best Friday the 13th movie. Other than the first. I recommend this movie to anyone who loves the whole Friday the 13th series. This a whole lot better than the other Jason movies by far.

I thought Jason X was really good.  I've seen all the Friday the 13th movies and I hated them. I thought Jason X was good but wasn't scary it had more of a coedic point to it cause the tried to lighten it up a bit too much.  I still rather enjoyed it though.

After seeing all of the other 9 Friday the 13th movies by now people would think they were boring but i am a fan of blood guts and gore and simply Jason was getting tired out protecting his beloved camp Crystal Lake but the 10th in the series takes a new turn with Jason being in space and committing many a few good deaths like freezing a woman's head and shattering it but stays faithful to the Friday the 13th tradition of the return of the much beloved machete for fans of horror or Friday the 13th this is a must see Roll on Jason XI

Man, people are so stupid. Giving this movie a bad review? If you do, you obviously didn't get.. uhm, anything. This movie is extremely entertaining! Cheesy? Yes. Of course, it's Jason in space for Petes sake!Lets break it down. Let me list everything that is good: *Jason is awesome. He just looks real good. *The kills are excellent. This one has some of the best kills in the whole series. *The pacing is super. Never boring. *The budget is quite high, movie looks really good. Effects are good. *Acting is satisfactory, and satisfactory is all we need in this case.So, what more do you want? Oh, more character development? Give it a rest. We don't want that. We want an awesome Jason killing lots of pretty young people. That we get.The only thing I don't like a 100% is the cyborg-chick. She brings it down a tad. Other than that, this is just very good fun. And since it's set in the future, they can make how ever many sequels (happening before this one in the Friday the 13th-timeline) as they want! Smart thinking!Shame on the douche bags giving this a low rating. I feel kind of sorry for them.

I enjoyed Jason X very much and I rate in one of the best in the series. You ask why, there is one simple answer: its different!!!! Jason is absolutely menacing, and to travel to 2455 or whatever ridiculous year it was, and destination: "earth 2" it was very well thought out and a heck of a lot different to all the others in the series. I found a lot of scenes hilarious as well, not going into great detail but the "unkillable" lines at the start were hilarious. And also the "upgraded" cracked me up as well.Jason at his best in this one people. don't miss it 10 blood-soaked knives

This movie was excellent!! It has got each and every cliché that a sci-fi horror movie should have. I was about die of laughter when i saw this movie. All you who liked, and rolled on the floor laughing when you saw the early Jason movies will absolutely LOVE this one. haha. wow. i can only say that it's one of the greatest movies i've ever seen.

All Jason movies are fun to go watch with friends and have a good time. Anybody who walks into this film or any Jason (or Freddy or Michael movie) and starts to criticize it may just want to choose NOT to even bother with any of these types of fun movies that are not supposed to be taken seriously.  I think that JASON X was pretty much the same as all the other Jason films... Horny immoral teenagers get punished by a guy that was neglected when he was a child.  His neglection has feuld his rage towards the camp (teeny bopper) counselors SO MUCH, that it has kept him alive to punish all teeny boppers more concerned with their hormones than the safety of kids (notice that he took sympathy on the kids in Jason 6).  Except in Jason X, he just got an awesome look at the end.  And anybody who just can't stand these movies, would really like the end part of this movie, because the producers/director also make fun of their own movie in a way that critics may find amusing.  If they stop at Jason X, it's been an entertaining ride, and if they continue to make these movies, I'll continue paying for popcorn at these shows. Let me to go off on a tangent... think of this .. a movie that parents WILL NOT take their kids to, or would not see themselves.. ONLY gets the numbers of the people who would see the movie or are allowed to see the movie.... BUT.. movies that parents WOULD NOT want to see (like some kids movie or Disney flick) are going to get the numbers of the kids tickets (which are many) plus the parents or the Adults who have to buy a ticket also who normally wouldn't buy a ticket.  Think of that next time box office numbers fly up on certain movies.Adam Campetti

reviews.review_title: Imaginative, clever, stylish--is this a FRIDAY THE 13TH movie?
reviews.content: **POSSIBLE SPOILERS**  Well, JASON X is here.  It should be a real treat for F13 fans, but even non-fans out there might get into it.  Except for the SCREAM-like one-liners (which seem to be a staple of horror movies these days), this is a pretty intense, fast-paced and clever outing.  Well made, stylishly shot, with some clever use of computer effects (hey, now there's a surprise!).Jason is now the subject of a lab. Turns out the reason he never dies is because he's a mutant that regenerates his flesh, limbs, bones, organs, etc; sort of a homicidal X-man.  He is scheduled to be cryogenically frozen until an evil corporate scientist shows up (played with smug relish by David Cronenberg) and demands that Jason be studied further before being frozen indefinitely.Of course, Jason escapes his bounds, but is tricked into the cryo chamber by a clever young female scientist who inadvertantly gets frozen with him. Four hundred years later, the two are unfrozen by a salvage operation run by a professor and a bunch of horny interns (you see where this is going  now, right?), who realize who Jason is (his legacy has survived centuries) and how much he might be worth.Needless to say, Jason wakes up, grabs his machete, and all hell breaks loose.  There's more than just your standard F13 plot here; we've got elements of THE THING, ALIEN, THE MATRIX and even THE DEMON SEED sprinkled throughout. But it plays far more as a tribute to these classics than a rip off. Jason's methods of murder are exceptionally clever as well, such as a woman's face plunged into liquid nitrogen, a man becoming impaled on a giant drill, then twisting all the way down, a girl being sucked out into space through a softball sized hole, and one of the screen's ickiest neck-crackings.  Maybe not the best of the series, but a definite improvement over the disappointing JASON GOES TO HELL, and Kane Hodder is great in his fourth turn as Jason.  Believe it or not, however, the door is still left open for a sequel (FREDDY VS. JASON?!)...

This is definitely one of the better Friday the 13th sequels. It's funny and has some great kills. If you are a fan of the series this is one to check out. I enjoyed its campiness and how it was a parody of a lot of horror movies.

Ah Jason, the best serial killer of all time. The man takes a beating, and stabbing, and bullets, and baseball bats, and weed-whackers, and flipped over car accidents and keeps on ticking...somehow. Yet he always finds his trusty machete to talk when his mouth cannot.Set up in space after being cryonically frozen with a certain victim, he is awaken to find himself on a space station and fresh new meat! Some of the scenes, like when he knifes the guy when he opens the door, are priceless. The scene with the two "premarital sex" girls was funny when he beat one with the other.It does get strange with the new armor and face and he seems different. Instead of taking bullets like normal, they deflect off him like in Terminator 2. Plus the set seemed too much like Star Trek.Instead of infusing him with new tech, I would have had him kill a bunch of Trekkies in space. Would have made this into a good film instead of the mediocre one that it was. The ending was odd, but no stranger than some others. "C+"

Well, to mean having Jason Voorhees battling a couple of teenagers in space, in the 25th century already sounds like a very lame concept in the first place. The actual end result is also far from satisfying and the movie is a pretty bad one, in many different ways.The concept was already quite bad but so is the actual story. They make no secret out of it that the story got very much based on the Alien-legacy movies. Not just with the story but also with the characters really. Of course they also tried to spice up things and update the Friday the 13th series by adding new hip teen stuff. This however works more out lame then good for the movie really because everything in the movie seems so far fetched and the events and characters in it all feel very distant.There of course had been some bad Friday the 13th movies before in the series but what they all had in common was that they got better as they progressed. This movie however only gets worse as it progresses. The story becomes more and more ridicules, which really causes you to laugh more often than to be scared or grabbed by any of it.The movie is all about blood and gore and with this it also relies obviously on some special effects. As an horror movie the movie really falls flat, also due to the fact that it's more busy trying to be a science-fiction flick. Attempts that are in vein though, fore "Jason X" as a science-fiction movie also really falls short, not just due to the fact that it is hardly being original but also due to its looks. The futuristic clothes, the technologies, it's just all being too lame. Also the actual special effects are being slightly below par for normal 2001 standards.The movie also really makes the mistake that it allows the Jason character to be the true star of the movie. This means that he gets featured a lot, which makes everything less scary and takes away a lot of the tension of the movie. They even throw in lots of close-ups of him and especially his eyes. Jason is not as much a threatening character when you see his eyes really. The fact that Kane Hodder is again playing Jason can't even seem to safe the character this time and I'm not even talking yet about the Uber-Jason character that pops up in the movie.The movie really feels like a pointless sequel, also because it has so little to do with the rest of the Friday the 13th-series. They should had just skipped this movie and have started working on "Freddy vs. Jason" right away, since that was the movie everybody was anticipating for after "Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday". This movie seems to completely ignore the fact that "Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday" ever happened and it also really isn't staying very loyal to earlier movies within the series, as it's trying to really be a movie on its own that is made to appeal a new, younger audience. A failed attempt though.Really the worst that the Friday the 13th-series has to offer.4/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

Well, I Just Finished Watching This Flick Not Too Long Ago and Agree With The Tag Line...Evil Gets An Upgrade. It's Great To See The Infamous Jason Voorhees Go On His Usual Killing Spree and Madness. Starts Off With Jason About To Get Frozen, But Escapes and Kills Off The Government Officials Who Are About To Freeze Him. From There, He Eventually Gets Frozen, But Takes A Victim With Him and Spend The Next 400 Years Frozen and Earth Becomes A Vast Wasteland. From There, The Victim and Jason Get Thawed Out and The Mayhem and Killing Begin. At One Point, Jason Is Vanquished But Gets Upgraded With A New Mask and Tricked Out Machete and Keeps Bring On The Pain. The Ending Is A Lame One and I'll Just Leave It At That.The Actors Were Not All Into The Story, Except Kane Hodder Who Plays Jason For The Fourth Time In This Movie; The Story Was Far-fetched to Send One Of Horror's Great Icons Into Space; But For What This Movie Is Worth, It's Not A Bad Film. This Isn't The Weakest Of The Franchise, But It Had It's Great Moments and Nice To See Jason Back In Action.7/10 Stars

reviews.review_title: A Balls to the Wall Jason movie written for Jason fans
reviews.content: The Friday series has had a lot of ups and downs.  What started as a fairly suspenseful murder mystery with an Italian horror twist was quickly turned into a Halloween clone by its first sequel.  From then on, scaring was just a thin pretense for films that were only made to wow you with creative deaths.  After making a whole armload of these killfests of varying quality, how do you top it all?  By removing the pretense, revealing all your conventions and then doing a little dance in them.Jason X is a streamlined gore machine, designed to keep raising the bar by having the masked menace kill tougher targets in new ways.  The body count rises to a height you probably can't even imagine and the deaths will have you falling out of your seat.  The human characters aren't just fodder though, they have entertaining personalities and fun dialog which'll keep your interest even when jason isn't there to turn them into red smears.Jason X is particularly a movie for those at least marginally familiar with the Friday line.  If you've never seen a jason flick, you won't be able to appreciate the parody and self-reference that are the major source of Jason X's fun.  You don't need to know anything about the F13 universe or any trivia at all, just being aware of the formula is enough.  (I recommend friday part 4).  So swing by the rental store, have a seat and let the blood fly!

reviews.review_title: Possibly the worst story line ever!
reviews.content: This was terrible, bad, aweful. The story was the dumbest I have ever seen. A frozen Jason comes to life on a space ship that just happens to have some teens on it and hacks everyone up. So stupid! And all the actors were awful. If you look at their bios, none of them have been in a movie since this one.Some examples of the dumb plot include 2 topless girls in sleeping bags, Jason getting his legs and arms blown off but comes back to life as a super-Jason, the black guy when he gets stabbed, Jason's first escape, Jason still coming after them in space, and the list goes on and on.BTW, did I mention this movie sucks.FINAL VERDICT:  Save some brain cells. Don't watch this.

reviews.review_title: A Big "X" Over the Entire Series With This Entry.
reviews.content: Jason X (2001): Dir: James Isaac / Cast: Lexa Doig, Lisa Ryder, Chuck Campbell, Jonathan Potts, Peter Mensah: Big budget disaster that should have a big x placed right over top of it. The ridiculous plot takes place in the future with the discovery of two frozen bodies. One is a female scientist and the other is Jason Voorhees who is responsible for murdering eight billion airheads. He will dismember many futuristic idiots aboard a spacecraft including a nasty bout with a female android that is beyond laughable. This is all very predictable right down to the total moron who attempts to reason with Jason only to have his insides double as wallpaper. Jason entraps two women in sleeping bags and beats one with the other. Director James Isaac hasn't improved since making another piece of sh*t called The Horror Show. Like that garbage, his films seem to celebrate the lowest common denominator of humanity. The production values are so pitiful that a third grade art student could not have done any worse. Dreadful acting from Lexa Doig, Lisa Ryder, Chuck Campbell, and Jonathan Potts. They join many others for nothing more than to become part of the celebrated body count. Gee, what a reason to make a movie. To show how many methods of death are available. This is a pointless piece of crap that should be placed in a sleeping bag and beat off a tree. Score: 0 / 10

"This sucks on so many levels!" In the horror genre, you have bad movies and then you have bad movies that know they are bad movies. "Jason X" is the latter. With nine films in the franchise, there is simply nowhere to go but upwards, and that's exactly where the tenth "Friday The 13th" (get it, Jason "X"?) takes us. Like Pinhead and Leprechaun before him, Jason is thrusted into the outer reaches of space and resumes his slaughter of bad characters aboard a cheap looking spacecraft. However, unlike previous slashers gone skyward, Jason's adventure in space is actually an enjoyable trip.First things first, this is not a scary, suspenseful or even remotely serious horror film. If you are hoping to squeeze any genuine thrills out of this movie, don't bother. However, if you are a lifelong "Friday The 13th" fan who has seen enough of Crystal Lake and doesn't take one's self too seriously, then saddle up and enjoy the best Jason movie in a long while. That's right, I said it. Most people are wound too tight and take their precious genre favorites too seriously, but not me. When I want to unwind on a Friday night, have a few beers and turn my brain off, I find there is nothing more suiting than "Jason X". With it's winning combination of nudity, bloodshed, nostalgia (sleeping bags, anyone?) and sense of humor, it doesn't matter that some parts of the film are a bit dodgy. Despite the ridiculous premise -- a group of students find a frozen, hockey-masked, machete clutching meat-bag and thaw him out on the way home -- and the lack of substantial special effects (those exteriors were a JOKE) there is still quite a bit of juice in this installment. Kane Hodder is back as Jason for what would unfortunately be his final round. Hodder goes all out, playing the uber-angry Jason that he created for "The New Blood" and even manages to make a ridiculous cyborg version of Jason seem menacing. Director James Isaac, a David Cronenberg (who cameos in this flick) protégé, delivers an unusually (for this franchise) stylish show, and despite the meager production values, gets the job done effectively. The movie looks good, even when it looks bad, if that makes any sense. It also helps that the movie was built off a script by a Joe-blow nobody fan in Todd Farmer. Farmer apparently loves Jason as much as he watches the SciFi channel, and it shows. You'll have a blast catching all the call-backs to previous movies and the little inside jokes that only a well-versed fan could possibly catch. Now, as you're reading this review, you're probably asking yourself "What's the downside of this film?" Well, I'm not sorry to say this; There is nothing wrong with this film. You go into a movie like "Jason X" -- the ninth sequel in an overly saturated franchise, which finds the title character in space -- and what do you honestly expect? If you can, God forbid, suspend disbelief, stop taking yourself and the films seriously for 90 minutes, you too will have a blast with "Jason X".

Jason X (2001) ** (out of 4) Tenth film in the series, second from New Line, has Jason frozen and then we flash forward four hundred years (455 to be exact). A new group of teenage scientist, on a spaceship, find him and decide to thaw him out. Guess what happens. I believe it was John Carpenter in an interview who was asked if he'd return for another Halloween movie and he asked what else could be done. Carpenter joked they could send Michael to space and I'm going to guess Sean Cunningham and gang heard this and went ahead with this movie. This is a rather strange film because on one hand it has a lot in it to like but on the other hand it's just too stupid to take seriously. What I did like about the movie is the effort of trying something new even if it didn't work out as great as they were hoping. I think more of a flat out spoof would have helped things but as they have it now, the half spoof stuff just doesn't work. The characters are just so downright stupid and annoying that you can't believe any of the set up. Just look at the scene where Jason is thawing out and two of the "scientists" are wanting to have sex. This scene, as well as many others, just stick out like a sore thumb. There are some very good moments including one rather long sequence where a SWAT team goes after Jason who must in return pick them off one by one. We also get one of the most memorable kills in the series when one scientist has her face frozen before Jason crushes it on a table. The science-fiction look also comes off rather poor but this here is due to the low budget. There wasn't a single time where I actually felt like we were in outer space. The film does have a fairly nice ending and a great joke involving two cyber girls. As far as the New Line canon is cancered, this is a major step up from Jason Goes to Hell but this isn't enough to enter the top films from the series.
Based on R1 DVDLeave your brain at the door or better yet drown it in alcohol with a few smart ass friends, it's the only way your going to enjoy this one.5/10 brain dead

These are the voyages of the Starship Voorhees. Yep, Friday the 13th Part 10 sees Jason in space, in the future. Seriously, folks, you may think I am making this up, but it's all true. Every damn word. See, Jason's body has been cryogenically frozen and, far into the future, it is discovered and thawed out. Big mistake. Jason awakens, reclaiming his machete and, after being vamped up into some sort of half mutant, half cyborg, once more sets about his slicing and dicing antics for our enjoyment. Now, here's the thing: anyone who complains about this movie is genuinely moronic. This is the 10th movie in the series. if you don't like them, don't watch them. Watching it and then complaining is like ordering a pizza then griping that you don't like cheese. Oh, and there's plenty of that here, too. The sci-fi twist is neat, and serves well as an excuse to reanimate Our Hero, and Jason's Borged up new look is pretty damn cool. The last twenty minutes descends into your usual running, screaming, chopping scenario, but it's to be expected. David Cronenberg puts in a cameo near the start, too, to lend the movie an air of respectability. An average slasher, then, but with at least a dash of originality.

I won't waste time pointing out the 1001 illogical plot holes.  Anyone who goes to see slasher trash expecting logic deserves to get burned.The movie starts out well, with jason held in a secret containment facility after numerous attempts to execute him have failed.  Atmospheric design and some good visuals.  The problems arise when he gets thawed out 450 years in the future on board a spaceship.  Cue 80 minutes of derivative horror sci-fi.  It all slavishly follows every cliché first established so brilliantly by Alien(s) and resurrected in a 1000 straight-to-video titles. We have the cryogenics, the dark, industrial corridors, the gung-ho marines getting wiped out, the corporate guy betraying everyone to make his fortune. All very predictable, but oddly entertaining.  The special effects are surprisingly competent, Isaac's direction better than a special-effects-technician-got-lucky should be.  Lisa Ryder 'going a bit Lara' in black leather is excellent.  But the script is terrible and betrays all the faults of a woefully inept first timer.  Manfredini's music is VERY bad, and incorporates nothing of the classic moody effects he provided for the original.  Even the killings are tame, and have nothing of the splatter shock of the early eighties - blame 90's irony and the need to bring in the lucrative teen market for that one.A bad movie, make no mistake.  It's trash, but it pretends to be nothing more, and is oddly entertaining as a result.  Certainly not worth the price of a cinema ticket, but definitely a good video to rent after a few pints.

reviews.review_title: Better then most of the Friday films!
reviews.content: OK... I have seen this movie twice and I think that it is better then most of the Friday films but still, it wasn't the best of them though.But, Jason in space was better then most ideas. I thought this movie was better than parts 5,7, and 9. The kills are pretty cool and it has a good body count. The only thing that I hate about this movie that the acting is TERRIBLE. People start to die like every 2 minutes and that most of the characters are annoying and make dumb jokes. This is probably the least scary of the series but it is very very entertaining, and I still recommend watching this if your a Jason fan. I give this film a 6 out of 10 (Good)

reviews.review_title: Über Jason should have arrived earlier in this so-so slasher
reviews.content: 'Jason X' manages to claw back a bit of dignity from the stench left by its turgid predecessor. Despite the outlandish premise of Jason being revived in space 400 years later, the idea holds promise. Unfortunately it can't capitalise on the claustrophobic possibilities of a serial killer stalking a spaceship's crew members one by one.Bland characters and a cheap, television movie look are prominent setbacks. This tenth entry, despite breaking free from its 1980s violence limitations, is also strangely tame in its kills, with the majority of them taking place offscreen, leaving the audience to view the grisly aftermath instead. No doubt a consequence of its low budget.But despite all the negative points in this science fiction horror, there's a late burst of creativity. Jason Voorhees is dispatched and everyone thinks the threat is over, but due to some futuristic nanotech reconstruction, he is reborn as Über Jason - an undead/cyborg hybrid that looks like something the Nazi's would have made via necromancy in some crazy alternate reality (think the video game Wolfenstein). Seeing this Terminator-styled monster become even more unstoppable adds some much needed energy in the final stretch, making this final film in the franchise a watchable, if lacklustre, instalment.5/10

reviews.review_title: Best film of the year! (whichever year it comes out)
reviews.content: I had the pleasure of watching jason x and i have to say it was a damn good flick. I didn't know how the flick was going to be (the whole space thing kind of scared me) but when i finally saw it I was truly impressed. The side chrecters of the films are well drwan out and are interesting unlike past friday flix and there is an end sequence in a virtual crystal lake that will make you burst out in laughter(the good kind). When this film comes out watch it! I'll be first in line with the popcorn!

reviews.review_title: Jason In Space...Now They Have Really Stuffed It Up!
reviews.content: I Hate This Film And I Don't Classify it as a Friday The 13th Film and i never will Jason in Space was the worst idea ever Anyway here is the plot The time is the near future. A team of government scientists working at the Crystal Lake Research Facility have finally captured the notorious and seemingly indestructible killer Jason Voorhees. In order to at least contain Jason, the plan is to freeze him in cryogenic suspension; but, as usual, things go horribly wrong and he breaks free to resume his murderous ways. The sole survivor of this latest rampage, Rowan, manages to lure Jason into the cryogenic chamber, but before she can complete the process and escape, she is mortally wounded and frozen in time along with Jason.Flash forward over four hundred years to 2455.The place is Old Earth, now a contaminated planet abandoned for centuries, a world of violent storms, toxic land masses and poisoned seas. Yet humans have returned to the deadly place they once fled; not to live, but to research the artifacts of the lost civilizations that caused this enormous environmental disaster. Little does the most recent landing party of interplanetary explorers realize the fate that awaits them when they stumble upon an unusual find from a primitive technological age.The student explorers, led by Archaeology Professor Lowe and their tech-droid KAY-EM 14, enter the ancient underground remains of the Crystal Lake Research Facility. There, they make a major archaeological discovery: two frozen ancestors; a beautiful young woman and a large man wearing a strange mask. There's only one problem: the auto-regeneration procedure has somehow been triggered. The frozen cry-jell is melting like a block of ice and soon the two bodies will thaw and deteriorate! With time running out, the young explorers return to their starship and blast-off for Earth II, where they are surprisingly able to revive Rowan, the young woman. But very soon, these students will come face-to-face with a shocking, totally new form of evil as Jason comes back to life as well and begins to silently stalk them through the corridors of the spacecraft.Forget what has gone before. Welcome to the future of horror.Only watch this is your a DIE HARD horror fan (I only ever watch this Jason movie if i watch the whole series in one whole go).

I apalled to see this get less than a five around the board.
I say it gets an 8 for FUN FACTOR.
Yes- it's stupid it's stupid as hell and cheesy... Did you watch any of the other movies?
Yes - it could've taken it self more seriously and has a few potholes.
Yes - it has the coolest death of any of the other movies (liquid nitrogen)
Yes - it's not scary... This one wasn't intended to be scary it was intended to be fun, it's pretty obvious ( corkscrew and sleeping bag)
Yes - people who love 'fun' horror movies but didn't like this one are idiots.
8/10- for the fun... and Kane Hodder was the best Jason.

The line from the movie that I used as the summary, pretty much sums up this film.  Jason X has a couple of cool looking kills (the ice face and the Supergirl with a shotgun) and has Kristi Angus who is amazingly hot, but other than those few positives, the rest of this movie was bad.  It was a bad movie when compared to other "non-slasher" movies and even by handicapping this film against it's predecessors, it still is not well made. The cheesy effects that pepper the screen throughout, which are suppose to make the film futuristic, just come across corny and cheap.  I will give the filmmakers a break on the make-up, because I realize that the film had to be cut for US release but splashes of blood instead of full-blown gore is not an adequate substitute.  Why could Part 9 be released un-cut on video, yet the DVD of X is cut?I liked the first ten minutes of the film, the reemergence of Jason while being examined, Ms. Angus and the kills outlined above.  I hated the CGI, bad make-up, stupid plot, bad acting, poor direction, "uber-Jason", and the ending.Note to New Line Cinema: veto any ideas for Jason going to Disneyland, Mars, Japan, Atlantis, or anywhere else besides Crystal Lake.  In my opinion if this was the best idea that came out of the Cunningham braintrust, it may be time to pull the plug and have Freddy kill Jason and have Freddy continue onwards and upwards.I think that this movie is better than Parts 5 and 8 and I think that Parts 7, 6, 9, and 4 are the best of the bunch because they bettered the ideas introduced by the first three.  They are action-packed and half-way smart, while 10, 5, and 8 are far worse than the original three and nearly unwatchable.This movie deserves 2 out of 10.  SPOILER: The best part of the DVD is that you can choose a death to jump to, so you should watch the first ten minutes (stop when they are frozen) and jump to the deaths of Andrienne and Jason 1 and then consider yourself lucky that I just saved you over an hour of bore.  END SPOILER.

JASON X is the tenth Jason Voorhees picture in his long-running Friday THE 13th franchise and it was released in April of 2001 and the film gets a lot of hatred.
