Paramount sold the franchise to New Line Cinema after JASON TAKES MANHATTAN and the film's concept is just really cool.Not only I'll review this, but like the remake of Jason, Halloween and Freddy Krueger, I will defend this movie. The story for this film is that Jason gets frozen and no one discovers him until 2455. By this time, Earth no longer exists and everyone lives on a planet called Earth II. Jason gets brought to life by a group of students / teachers that went to Earth to explore the land or something and he starts killing people on board the ship.A lot of critics and fans actually hated this one and says it is worse than "Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday", but actually, I don't mind this film at all because there are two Jason's, but they are played by the same guy.The acting is dreadful in a few areas, but I can easily overlook that. Kane Hodder plays Jason and he does good with his screen time, although this would be his final appearance as Jason and he is alright. This is all sci-fi with a mix of horror. Jason Goes to Hell was bad, but I find myself watching it once in a while. But, this one is not as stupid or pointless as the other films, like critics and fans did take those films the wrong way. I loved what New Line did to this franchise and to see Paramount getting the franchise back for the 2016 remake, yes, they are remaking it again and that is really cool. Or it might be a sequel to the 2009 reboot, I don't know.Parts 1-4 were really scary and intense, while 5-9 were also scary and much better than some of the pointless sequels in certain franchises and I can see why some of those get a lot of hatred.Overall, JASON X is kind of bad, but in a good kind of way and this film is a guilty pleasure for me. I love the direction, acting, music, visuals, action and horror scenes in this film and Kane Hodder could have not done a better job. I wish I could give this a a 10 out of 10, but considering the flaws that I have with this film, I can't. So I'm giving this a 6.3 / 10.

reviews.review_title: When the title is a film's cleverest attribute, you know it's in trouble
reviews.content: With Freddy Vs. Jason still stuck in development hell, Friday the 13th producer and creator Sean S. Cunningham wanted to ensure that audiences didn't forget about the monster in the hockey mask and gave us a tenth entry, coming 8 years after the previous film. With the last two instalments attempting to change the formula (getting him out of Camp Crystal Lake and then turning him into a body- jumping ghoul from Hell) and becoming two of the most hated entries into the franchise in the process, Jason X faced a battle to bring the well-worn slasher genre to a modern audience. Well, all gore- seeking teenagers love space, right?When the title is a film's cleverest attribute, you know it's in trouble. In the near-future, Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder) is imprisoned in Camp Crystal Lake's research facility, where a bunch of silly scientists (including David Cronenberg) look to transport him to another location in order to carry out further research. Naturally, Jason breaks free and kills everyone, just before being frozen along with the sexy doctor Rowan (Lexa Doig). They are discovered almost 500 years later by a group of explorers from Earth II, who take the two corpses aboard their ship, bringing Rowan back to life using advanced science. With Jason now established as a supernatural being who cannot be killed, he is soon alive and kicking and butchering the annoying crew one by one.With the post-modern horror boom still in full swing thanks to Scream (1997), Jason X plays mainly for laughs. Clearly made with the series' fans in mind, it features various winks at the audience and just may have worked had the script, actors and production values been anything other than abominable. Bad special effects can have its charms, but Jason X looks like a mid-shelf TV show most of the time, with the only inspired effect coming from a poor female doctor who has her face frozen with liquid nitrogen and then smashed to pieces on a work surface (one of the best Jason killings in the entire franchise). Rather than being funny, it feels symbolic of what a parody of itself the series has become. The fans will surely disagree, but the Friday the 13th films have never been good, and Jason X is the poorest of them all. It may not tell us how to kill Jason once and for all, but it demonstrates how to kill a franchise.

reviews.review_title: Weak Event Horizon meets Friday The 13th
reviews.content: This one was TOTALLY UNNECESSARY. Okay, it is a bit interesting and we get to see some iconic stuff like Adrienne's death or Kay-Em-14 character, but NO. It's a cringe story and the ambiance is nothing compared to other sci-fi movies.

Paramount sold the franchise to New Line Cinema after JASON TAKES MANHATTAN and the film's concept is just really cool. Not only I'll review this, but like the remake of Jason, Halloween and Freddy Krueger, I will defend this movie. The story for this film is that Jason gets frozen and no one discovers him until 2455. By this time, Earth no longer exists and everyone lives on a planet called Earth II. Jason gets brought to life by a group of students / teachers that went to Earth to explore the land or something and he starts killing people on board the ship.A lot of critics and fans actually hated this one and says it is worse than "Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday", but actually, I don't mind this film at all because there are two Jason's, but they are played by the same guy.The acting is dreadful in a few areas, but I can easily overlook that. Kane Hodder plays Jason and he does good with his screen time, although this would be his final appearance as Jason and he is alright. This is all sci-fi with a mix of horror. Jason Goes to Hell was bad, but I find myself watching it once in a while. But, this one is not as stupid or pointless as the other films, like critics and fans did take those films the wrong way. reviews.review_title: "Oh, this sucks on so many levels!"
reviews.content: I'll start this with my extremely short plot summary (not that it matters much): 400 years in the future, Jason finds himself aboard a spacecraft where he (surprise, surprise) starts butchering everyone in sight.Until last night, the only other time I'd seen Jason X was about 15 years ago. I hated it. For reasons I cannot explain, I decided to give it another go to see if my opinion had changed any at all. The short answer is: No - I still hate it. I'm a huge fan of the Friday the 13th series, but I cannot stomach Jason X. You might think that by taking Jason into space, you'd come up with some new, original ideas. Well, you'd be wrong. There's very little new in Jason X that we haven't seen before. The lack of imagination is staggering. And the few things that are new (like Uber Jason) are so ridiculous, it's insulting. Stupid characters played by bad actors, bottom-of-the-barrel special effects, a complete lack of tension or suspense - it's all so bad that my 2/10 rating feels generous. A few very random thoughts:Are there any lights on this spaceship? Why would you go looking for a hulking killer in the dark? Who could have imagined that female scientists in the future would dress like today's highschool girls? And who knew that scientists in 2455 would act just like over-sexed 1980s-era teenagers? The "space marines" are beyond useless. Here's an idea - why not split up while searching for Jason? It makes it easier for him to kill you one at a time.Like a lot of other people, I did enjoy the Holodeck scene. It's the only clever thing in the whole movie.Finally, and I'm just guessing, but I can only assume the Jason X screenwriters watched Aliens and Terminator one too many times.

If you don't like horror films and are not a fan of the "Friday the 13th" series then you were never going to enjoy this. If you are a fan of the series, however, then this is a great addition - the comedy elements really work and the special effects are great - adding extra impact to the shock-horror scenes. I watched this on DVD and the DTS soundtrack was fantastic... with the sirens going off around me and the rumble of the explosions I really appreciated the extra effort put into this film.
For those who took this film too seriously, have you ever heard the expression "tongue in cheek"?

reviews.review_title: One of the better sequels to a tired series.
reviews.content: I'll be honest to start. I'm not a big fan of the Friday series or Jason. I find the idea of the indestructible boogeyman a stupid one. By the time the 3rd sequel came around (the 3D one), I went to see these for two reasons: Nudity and Killings. When the censors started cutting the gore out - I stopped paying attention at all. Jason X is the best of the later sequels. It has an interesting idea, Jason waking up in the future, and a cast that can actually act and that the audience can actually root for. Jason is as menacing as ever (honestly, I could have used more gore, a lynchpin of the originals), and it's quick and fun. Just grab some popcorn and, as usual, turn off your brain.

reviews.review_title: This is one movie I can do without!
reviews.content: Out of all the movies of "Friday the 13th", "Jason X" is the lowest of the low. It has some good parts that I like, but from the rest of it. It just went downhill fast! An android Kay-Em 14(Lisa Ryder) was a perfect foe for Jason. As supernatural as he is, Jason(Kane Hodder) is the ultimate killer. Now that he's in the future, he's no longer a threat to Camp Crystal Lake, otherwise it was foolish to revive him in the future. Or is it? The silliest thing I saw in this movie was the CyberJason, OH PLEASE! That really takes the cake. Man I thought Part 8 was bad enough, I was wrong, this movie was twice as silly as part 8. However, the upgrade version of Jason seems rather cool in a maniacal way. At least it showed in his eyes. If they glowed, this movie would have been much better. This movie I'll have to pass on the collection list. The upgrade didn't do me any justice, Jason should just stayed dead. 1 out of 5 stars.

reviews.review_title: I loved it,but not quite the best
reviews.content:
This flick is a combination of gothic horror and future space-travel flicks.It is kind of Star Trek meets Amityville Horror.I loved the various lines or allusions to both Horror and Sci-Fi/fantasy.   It starts out a facility for cryogenic research-where the latest solution for washing hands of Jason is the freeze him and let the future take advantage of him.A scientist is accentally frozen with him.So we get into the heart of the movie-I'll let the viewers discover that.
   In all:I would give it an 8 for horror,6 for comedy and 5 for sci-fi

Jason X was a fine way to reintroduce the master of slaughter to the younger naive generation. But it backfired as the film ended up becoming a joke to most and a celebration to few. This could in part be because we were tantalized for years about the proposed Freddy vs Jason and by this point it was what we wanted. Another reason this failed at the box office is because it had been a decade since Jason last stalked his game, and the world had moved on, that's a sad thought. I myself love this movie and could watch it non-stop but then again I am biased as I love the character and the story, I could see if you were not a fan or if you were a fan and expecting more, that this would not be your cup of tea. But to those who only think of this film as joke, you are wrong. This film had lots of heart and took a heck of a long walk to get to screen, the battle that this film had to through to get shown should be made into a movie it was so wicked. Studio Execs leaving, people feeling Jason was not worthy to return, stupid people, and the internet were all causes for this film to be halted, but it prevailed and was shown and I think thirty million is not a bad number for a film that was not properly released or advertised. In the end this film came out swinging and was beautiful, it was the first Jason film I saw in the theater and I was elated. This is far better than Ronny Yu's soiled down Freddy vs Jason that would come a year later. or three years later if you count the fact that Jason X sit on a self at New Line for three years. I wonder how long it will take them to release the new Michael Bay produced remake once completed. My gut says it will go out quickly and be targeted at ignorant people and sell quick thus ruining the integrity that is and forever shall be Jason. See Jason X it well worth it and if you look at it, it is a fine conclusion to the chronicles of The Crystal Lake Slasher.

reviews.review_title: Now he's gone into space? What's next?
reviews.content: This movie is the tenth sequel to "Friday the 13th". The number is gigantic, considering that the franchise never had a single spark of quality. This time, imagination led the writers to take Jason into space in an attempt to give the public something they had not yet seen. But changing the clothes does not make the content better, and the franchise has never had good content, and that's hardly likely to happen.

Jason X is by far one of the most coolest, scariest, funniest, and most well-done movies I have ever seen!  The special effects are incredible and Jason has his best looks near the end!  The jokes in this movie are extremely funny and well thought out!  Jason X is a MUST SEE for every horror fan worldwide!  *****+ out of *****.  Real mad-ass movie!

reviews.review_title: In Space, No One Can Hear You Quip
reviews.content: Many of these Jason movies are notoriously bad, so I assumed this would qualitatively sit among them, but it's truly bonkers how terrible it is. It's not even really a movie; it's a bad Battlestar Galactica knock-off, with Jason mercifully killing the characters so that we don't have to endure their unbearable quips any longer. "What's his condition?" "He's screwed." Excuse me while I piss my pants from laughter.

reviews.review_title: At last a decent Jason Sequel!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
reviews.content: After the terrible part 8 and 9, Jason X is more than welcome, daft logic, no continuity, and instant unrealistic deaths. Friday the 13th movies are a true "movie" definition, made to entertain the audience with a capital 'E', take them away from boring reality of bills, work and relationships for 90 minutes and give them exactly what they want ENTERTAINMENT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!.Jason X looks cool, has decent enough acting, (none of the 40s movie acting that makes the acting in Casablanca look good, that some of the earlier films had).Jason looks as cool as he did in Part 7, Kane Hodder does the whole "breathing" thing, that shows just how p***ed off ol' Jason is.The FX are amazing (especially when the soldier gets sliced in two!)Despite some of the negative comments on this site (obviously not F13 fans), Jason movies are the "Raiders of the lost ark" of Horror film, ENTERTAINMENT not boring pathos and subtle political points that could bore anyone to sleep.Go see, I guarantee you will not be disappointed.

As a Friday the 13th Fan, this was the film I surprisingly watched the most of. It may not be good as everyone says it's not, but this is such a fun movie and I binge watch this one in particular to the rest for the creative kills and the fun scenes. Also, I love the idea the upgraded Jason Voorhees!

This is actually my first Friday the 13th movie, believe it or not. Mom wouldn't let me rent the 80's Zombie films. Pure silly comedy and monosyllabic closed-ended lines. This movie had some entertaining quality to it in a bizarre comedy-action style.. 80's movies were largely Bizzare experimentations, before the formulatic 90's regulated shows came out...Jason Voorhees is captured and taken to a top secret military facility near crystal lake to study his resilient physique, and preserved until a group of futuristic post secondary students and their professor uncover him and attempt to transport him to Earth 2. He escapes.

I am going to keep this brief - as labouring over a review for this would be a fruitless waste of time for me and you.Acting performances were typically laughable. As for the horror, we have all seen more frightening displays on the Disney channel. The suspense factor was butchered from several angles, not least by the seemingly randomised synthetic score and game-show type camera-work. The violence was bloody but not excessive, and may have been a little more thrilling if I was not completely unenthusiastic about the entire setup. Still nothing was gruesome enough to penetrate my scepticism. Worst of all, the pitiable concept was not played up as a "Funny, cos its rubbish" gag. Even for a Friday 13th movie, Its just plain rubbish.

reviews.review_title: Not the best, but not the worst
reviews.content: Well its the long awaited Friday the 13th part 10.  When I was a kid I figured the series would have 13 installments and now that doesnt seem to out of reach. The series takes an unexpected turn and pits Jason a few centuries ahead of time aboard a space ship, and when his body thaws out all hell breaks loose.  So like all Jason movies, theres slicing and dicing.  But you think with the change of plot the deaths would all differ much. But instead their mostly by merchedi or offscreen.  Anyways, ** out of **** stars.

reviews.review_title: Gloriously stupid and some dumb fun
reviews.content:
First, let us get this right out of the way. This is not King Lear. This is not Casablanca or Citizen Kane. There is no high drama or good acting expected in any Friday the 13th Movie. Anyone going in expecting anything in this list is going to be disappointed. Hard core.What we do expect: fine young females showing some titties, having sex and drinking beer. We expect to see some hard core murder performed in unique and interesting ways. We want buckets of blood as Jason fulfills his roll as an unstoppable killing machine. Little details like plot and character development get in the way of what we paid our money to see: Death and lots of it.Given that - how does Jason X stack up? It's an absolutely bad movie in just about every respect imaginable - and it's perfect.It's got all kind of interesting death in it - the first one on the spaceship with the liquid nitrogen springs to mind. The problem is that it hits you with probably the best death right off the bat - so there is some pacing issues with the way the murders play out, but it's hardly something to get worked up over.The movie has the highest body count of any previous Friday the 13th movie - at least 20, with the potential of several thousand if you count the space station that Jason blew up. Those looking for a visceral good time will have everything they want - in spades.The writing is even clever at times. Case in point, the bait used to distract Jason while the heroes get away (to say more would give away far too much).  Suffice it to say that this is a damn funny scene, probably the best moment in the movie. Me and my crew were on the floor laughing so hard I had trouble paying attention to the rest of the movie.
I was afraid that sly and pretentious films like Scream and Scary Movie had destroyed the horror genre forever with their "Nudge, nudge - look how clever WE are" approach to the old school 80's slasher flick. Fear not - this movie trumps those films live never before. I was worried that a series of movies that was over TWENTY years old - teenagers who saw these films on Showtime and HBO in the dark well after they were suppose to have gone to bed who now have teenagers of their own - had nowhere else to go, had no gas left in the franchise. I couldn't have been more wrong.In short, if you liked Friday the 13th 1-9, then part 10 will rock your world.

I expected from this film due to the budget, but obviously it was all just flushed. I'm a fan of Jason. I like Fridays 1-6 (parts 3-5 very much). Part 7 was "whatta hell is this TV-crap?" with a hilarious sleeping-bag execution, part 8 would have been OK if they wouldn't have been so shy with the gore and part 9 was just OK, with even some sight. I don't mind having a part 10 after "Jason goes to hell". I don't mind with the far-fetched plot here. I even don't mind tampering with Jason's outfit. What I DO mind here are these 2 things:-The actors seem to be reading their lines straight out of off-screen cards not even trying to act, which is uncomfortable and annoying. SHAME ON YOU!-The director DOESN'T EVEN TRY!!It all looks like bad cable stuff (even more worse than part 7!!) with NO kind of sense about lighting, cameras always at a distance from actor's faces (no close-ups), no creativity, no gimmicks... makes me wonder if there even WAS a director!? And the funny thing is, the "director" can't even blame the studio, 'cause he had a budget and obviously green light for gore and (even) nudity!Ain't nothing ever going to explain this mess. Talk about a CHEAT and WASTED POTENTIAL. Too bad for New Line, cause the studio had the courage...Avoid this turkey at all costs.

reviews.review_title: Jason X (2002, Jim Isaac) Uber Jason can't save a movie that looks like it was made by college kids in a garage
reviews.content: Just when you think the 'Friday the 13th' franchise has nowhere left to go along comes 'Jason X'. This is the tenth installment in the slasher horror franchise featuring iconic undead machete wielder Jason Voorhees. It had been 9 years since the last iteration of the series and a proposed 'Freddy vs. Jason' crossover film was stalling so this film was concocted to attempt to keep up interest in the character. The Crystal Lake setting had been done time and again and they even took Jason to NYC, so where did they have left to go? Space obviously.This film approaches Jason with a similar mentality as the previous one in that society is aware of his existence and they are trying at various points to capture, understand, study and/or destroy him. Instead of chalking up his undead nature to a supernatural phenomenon they give it a science fiction spin calling it an enhanced regenerative ability. They at first want to study him as a specimen but as Jason is apt to do he escapes and commences a bloodbath before getting frozen in a cryogenic chamber. One woman is inadvertently frozen along with him. They are both found and thawed 445 years later. Earth is uninhabitable and there is an Earth Two. Both Jason and Rowan (the science girl frozen with him) are brought to a spaceship which is a school ship with a professor, students, an android and a few military/security types. Of course Jason is awoken before they really know what they have on their hands and starts his rampage once more. Everyone but a select few, including original girl Rowan, are decimated before Jason is dispatched in space finally ending as a fiery meteor hurtling toward the surface of Earth Two. Of course his meteoric form crashes very near to a wooded lakeside camp.There is now way around the fact that this movie is a piece of junk. It is a hokey idea that looks like it was put together by college kids. This is the same timeframe when Peter Jackson was redefining what was capable with special effects with his 'Lord of the Rings' trilogy. This movie is at the other end of that spectrum, and it is hilarious as director Isaac was primarily employed as a visual effects supervisor for other films. The acting is horrible, visual effects are bargain basement level and the costume design is amateurish and bizarre with most of the girls in weirdly skimpy attire. While the budget of $14 million isn't that high it is more than the previous four 'Friday the 13th' films combined which I guess just goes to show if you want to aid science fiction effects, even bad ones, they are going to cost you. This film did have a few wonderful death scenes which is about all you can hope for as you are pretty much expecting the rest of the movie to be bad. Most notable was Jason forcing a girl's head into a cryogenic fluid sink instantly killing her and freezing her head which he then smashed on a counter to a gloriously gory effect. Then there is the Terminatrix android vs. Uber Jason after they both get upgraded by a computer system. I thought the Uber Jason was going to be more of a thing but he really only comes in at the tail end which is a bit of a disappointment. Like most Friday the 13th films there is some mild entertainment value. It is always fun to see Jason stalking around doing his thing, however, always disappointing to see a piss poor movie surrounding him while he does his stabby stab thing.Eric's Grade: F.

everyone knows that Friday the 13 after the first one the sequels really sucked ....but believe it or not this one is pretty good besides the point that every killer is in space but anyways this movie is pretty good,lot of action,some humor,and Jason famous machete ....i gave this movie a 8 out of 10 for being a fun movie to watch is better then what i expected so i really recommend it .....enjoy.

reviews.review_title: One small step for man, one small step for Jason Voorhies in Space
reviews.content: Believe it or not, this movie wasn't as dumb and terrible as people said it was. I mean this movie does have it's flaws. For one, for this being a horror movie, it has far too much action in it. I would put this particular movie in the "Action/Sci-Fi" genre. The premise was kinda overdone considering we'd already seen certain celebrated monsters make their voyage into space i.e. Pinhead in "Hellraiser:Bloodline" and Leprechaun in "Leprechaun in Space." This film and particular Jason movie looks like it was produced by the Sci-Fi channel. This is how mediocre it looks. I can't believe this movie was released in theaters. It looks more of a direct-to-video effort. I guess since the Friday the 13th series is one of the most successful horror franchises then they were obligated to release this theatrically. Anyway,you should rent this movie and see how the director and producers decided to take the Friday the 13th franchise after the supposedly "final" Friday film "Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday." Give this movie a chance. You might like it.
I loved It Freaking AMazing film for sure hope to find more films like this

reviews.review_title: "Jason X"- The one that was so bad, not even a David Cronenberg cameo or a sexy cyborg firing machine guns could make it interesting...
reviews.content: Look, I'm gonna be up-front about this....I don't know why "Jason X" gets a free-pass from so many people. And I especially don't understand how so many people actually really enjoy it or find it "entertaining." I really just don't get the appeal of it at all, nor can I really figure out what it hopes to accomplish.It's a film that aspires to be so much more than it is, but it never lives up to even a hint of what it promises. It's a contradictory film from scene to scene. On one hand, it fancies itself a subversive satire along the lines of "Jason Lives", yet it only delivers the occasional jest at its own expense. On the other hand, if often plays the material straight for attempts at honest thrills, yet these are contradictory to its lighter moments. It occasionally gets the idea that it's an effects spectacle on the rare occasion for more complex sequences, but it's hindered by a low budget. Yet it also frequently seems aware of its cheap cost in other scenes.It's like watching someone trying desperately to put together two different jigsaw puzzles after the pieces have become inadvertently mixed together. Nothing fits.We all know the plot... It's "Friday the 13th" in space. Jason gets cryogenically frozen (along with sexy scientist Rowan, portrayed by Lexa Doig) in modern times, only to be awakened on a spaceship 400 years later, so he can hack up stupid, nubile teens... in the future!Blah, blah, blah. He kills a few, gets blown apart by a sexy android chick (Lisa Ryder), gets brought back with magical future medical-technology as a half-robotic "Uber Jason", and chaos ensues. (That was all in the trailer, so there's no spoilers there.) It's a rinse and repeat of almost every previous film, except now Jason gets a hokey new metallic costume and there's a lot of bad CGI and green-screen effects because, you know... the future! And space!To be fair and give credit where it is due, there's a few positive aspects here. Lisa Ryder steals the show as robotic "KM-14" in a delightful little role. There's also some fun to be had with a few high-concept gags like a laugh-out-loud holographic simulation of Crystal Lake in the 80's. And I'd be lying if I said there weren't a few creative kills. (Cryo-freezing someone's face and then smashing it? Yes, please!) There's also a cameo from filmmaking god David Cronenberg, who chews the scenery in a fun-albeit-brief role! (How did they even get him for this movie?! Is he a big Jason fan?)But the film never comes together as I said. I can't help but feel screenwriter Todd Farmer was aiming at something a lot bigger and more bombastic, but kept having to be dialed back by studio-suits and producers over budgetary concerns. A lot of the scenes and plot lines come across as last-minute back-ups that were thrown in in case the studio couldn't afford the intended sequences.The tragedy is that it had a golden opportunity to do so much more. The "Killer in Space" trope is such a widely-known cliché, that putting more effort into subverting and parodying the concept would have given the film a fresher, more unique flavor. It needed to drop its more serious moments and take full advantage of delivering self-aware laughs based around its setting and location. The few times it tries, it works. But it doesn't take enough advantage of this... it's not commenting on the silly "killer in space" trope. It's just another example of it being done poorly, while giving us an occasional fleeting wink and nod.Even beyond the failed potential, there's just a whole lot of nothing going on. The effects budget eats up too much money, so everything else- sets, costume design, etc. look cheap and fake. Director James Isaac seems in over his head, and only delivers a minimum effort in his visuals. Series composer Harry Manfredini- usually a reliable musician in his own right- barely seems to try with a really bad and often artificial-sounding synth soundtrack. And supporting roles are among the series worst, with grating characters being portrayed by dime-a-dozen "pretty face" actors who would be more at home on Hollister billboards than on-screen. (Shelly from Part III and Megan from Part VI still remain the high point of supporting roles even to this day.)So sadly, "Jason X" emerges as one of the weakest films in the series in my opinion. It may think it's something grander than it is, but we as an audience can see that this just isn't the case.It's a 2 out of 10 just for it's few fun moments. But they aren't worth having to slog through 90 minutes to get to.

No, this isn't the scariest movie ever made. It isn't even the scariest in the never-ending series of "Jason Films". I think some of the critics of this film must belong to the category of viewers who still think of Alfred Hitchcock - for example - as the "Master of Suspense" and get no farther than their tags and self-imposed limitations.This is a glorious mish-mash of everything in sight: there's the obvious tie to the Jason films and to "Alien", to begin with. Then, of course, there are other links to "Aliens" with its female warrior, "The Thing From Another World" with the scientist trying to understand the monster,"It!The Terror from Beyond Space" with the room-by-room pursuit, a shack that seems to have escaped from "The Bride of Frankenstein" and, of course, the virtual young women at camp from numerous proto-movies. What's NOT to enjoy? This film is good, clean fun all the way through.The beginning is terrific, the editing is razor-sharp, the colors and sets are imaginative, the music is riveting (too many minor chords on the organ near the end, though) and the characters, thankfully, are not fleshed out to much. Uh-oh. Perhaps I used the wrong verb. What we need now is a spoof. How about "Jason Goes to College" or "Jason Versus Francis the Talking Mule"?Curtis Stotlar

JASON X (2002) * Kane Hodder, Lexa Doig, Lisa Ryder, Chuck Campbell, Jonathan Potts, Peter Mensah, Melyssa Ade, Todd Farmer, Melody Johnson, (Cameo: David Cronenberg)  For those keeping score at home this is the tenth stab in the `Friday the 13th' horror series with hockey-masked invincible hulk slashing psychotic brute Jason Voorhees propelled into deep space in the year 2455 after being cryogenically frozen only to be thawed unwittingly (and I'm using that as a potent pun here) by a group of young astronaut students with the atypical carnage ensuing.  Nothing fresh or exciting either  you'd think Jason would have some more inventive ways of offing the idiotic -  but the unimaginable script (hey it's an `Alien'  rip off!) sets new low standards in bad writing.  (Dir: James Isaac)

Man this one's really bad. Jason X is the tenth film in a series that (at the time) was going downhill. In fact, the series became a joke when Paramount sold the franchise to New Line Cinema. Anyways, the plot for this is that Jason gets frozen, and no one discovers him until 2455. By this time, Earth no longer exists and everyone lives on a planet called Earth II. Jason gets brought to life by a group of students/teachers that went to Earth to explore the land or something. He starts killing people on board the ship. That's basically it.There is so much bad about this film. The acting is horrendous, worse than any other Friday flick if you can believe it! I hate the turn this franchise took when New Line started making these films. It's all sci-fi. Jason Goes to Hell was a cheap version of Invasion of the Body Snatchers. And this movie is basically Aliens except substitute the ugly creature with Jason Voorhees. Friday the 13th films were originally scary and creepy horror/slasher films set in the woods. Parts 1-4 were amazing because they were simple. Even parts 5-8 were better then this Andromeda/Star Trek rip off.Jason X is kind of insulting to the series. It gets marks for Kane Hodder and one murder in particular. Jason freezes a woman's head and then smashes it in a thousand pieces. One of the more unique 'Friday' kills in the series. But overall, I just hate the direction of the series. Putting horror icons in space NEVER works. Pinhead in Hellraiser Bloodline, Leprechaun in Lep 4, hell even the Critters went to space in part 4. Those sequels were awful and this sequel is awful. EASILY the worst of the series.2/10

reviews.review_title: One hell of a wake up call......
reviews.content: In the future, Earth is no longer inhabitable.A field trip leads the class and a few marines to the remains of Camp Crystal Lake where they discover two frozen bodies, one of a young woman, and the other, a man in a hockey mask and carrying a machete in his right hand.The group decides to bring the bodies back for testing and re-animation.But what was the first mistake, bringing the two bodies back with them, or thawing them out so that Jason Voorhees can return again to wreak havoc and murder everyone in his sight? So whoever thought that this sequel needed to be made was wrong. So wrong on so many levels. I have a fondness for the Friday The 13th movies. They are dross, but they are fun to watch and pass the time.But this was just one step too far. If they really wanted to make this, why set it in space, was there really any other way than this? The acting is awful, and when Jason gets his upgrade, its time for the off button. But I waited to see if anything would be redeemed, but hey, I wasted another few minutes of my life.Cronenberg is in it for a few moments at the beginning, and this is why it's getting a two, he was really funny in this.But otherwise, this was a dud. My only explanation for this is that they probably made this to see if Jason was still popular enough for the company to make 'Freddy Vs. Jason'.Avoid.

Jason X is badly acted, badly written, the special effects look terrible and it takes place in space. Oh wait a minute, thats f#@ing awesome. Jason gets cryogenicly frozen for 450 years and wakes up on generic future space ship #262, from there he kills, kills again and kills some more and it is so funny. The killings are so over the top. Jason grabs a girls head, sticks it liquid nitrogen and bashes her head on a table where it just explodes. Now that is cool. Even Jasons supposed death at the hand of android (its the future, of course this film was going to have an android)Key-Em 14 is incredibly overdone as she basically dissects him with a shotgun (Lisa Ryder is super hot doing it as well). Oh, and there's a scene including two naked girls, Jason and sleeping bags, its got to be one of the funniest scenes to ever be included in a horror movie.Jasons upgrade near the end of the film is just the definition of Bad- Ass. The mask, the red eyes, its all uber awesome (in the credits they call Jasons upgrade Uber-Jason). Kane Hodder as Jason is incredible, the stare with those red eyes is actually terrifying.Jason X is fun, big, dumb, incredibly stupid fun. Its so over the top that you cant help but laugh and yes, as a horror film it downright sucks, but as pure popcorn entertainment, it rocks on so many levels.

reviews.review_title: Exceeds all expectations... roll on Jason XI
reviews.content: After the rather disappointing Jason Goes To Hell, I was almost fearing the worst as soon as I heard New Line were going to take Jason Voorhees quite literally into outer space.  A laughable idea surely, and a desperate one at that.  After much delay though, I finally got to see the movie on July 20th 2002 at a UK cinema no less, the first time a Friday The 13th movie has been released on the big screen here since the pretty awful Part V: A New Beginning back in 1985.  So, first of all, hats off to New Line and Entertainment Film for having the guts to give a tenth film in a slasher series a cinema run in the UK!To say director Jim Issac overcomes the shortcomings of the initial idea, is a bit of an understatement.  Thanks largely to Todd Farmer's competent and sometimes witty script, Issac is able to keep things moving at a good tempo, utilising the larger scope of "Jason in space" to come up with some superb set pieces, and a visual style that is far more impressive than anybody has really given it credit for.  A knowing, but mostly controlled sense of humour helps too, preventing the film from being swallowed up by its own outlandish storyline, meaning the final barrage of over the top action during the last 20 minutes work a treat.  Sure, it all becomes rather laughable, but then the film makers are in on the joke too.I can't really understand why so many have attacked the acting either.  I mean, what were we all expecting?  Laurence Olivier or Anthony Hopkins to pop up?  Or maybe, Al Pacino as Jason?  Come on people.  This is a low budget movie, with a young mostly unknown cast, and to be honest it's one of the best collected casts of the entire series (probably the best since Joseph Zito's "The Final Chapter").  Indeed, the cost of the film doesn't seem to hinder Issac's ambitions. Apart from the expected top class prothestics, the use of CGI for the space scenes is very impressive indeed ,particularly for a $15 million movie.Finally, a word for Kane Hodder.  Playing Jason for the fourth consectitive time, he's as imposing and serious as ever.  Whilst Farmer's script has fun with the trappings of the series (the jokes about premarital sex etc), never does he make fun of Jason, and Hodder's performance emphasisis this with some magnitude.  This must be the most screen time Jason has been allowed, and to Hodder's credit that despite his frequent on-screen time, he never looses his sense of menace - not once.  The film may not be that scary, but Hodder's Jason always had me glued to the screen.To be honest, Jason X is everything I hoped it would be, and more.  The only real damaging aspect of the film is Harry Manfredini's cheap sounding music score, which threatens to kill any menace Jason has.  If there is a Jason XI, I just hope another composer is hired, because as good as Manfredini's early Friday scores were, his last two, for Jason Goes To Hell, and now Jason X, have in all honesty been pretty dreadful.Placing it in with the rest of the series, it would probably be 3rd on the list, after the awesome "The Final Chapter", and the under-rated if flawed "Jason Takes Manhattan".  Great fun, just don't, as some people seem to be doing, expect Shakespeare.  Besides, Shakespeare was never this much fun.

reviews.review_title: Is it what I expected? NO! It's better!
reviews.content:
"Jason X," or "Friday the 13th Part 10," is the best outta the last 9 "Friday" movies.  It's kinda weird, but, this movie simply rocks.  I've been a big fan of Jason Voorhees for a while and I enjoyed all of the films (including "Jason Goes To Hell: The Final Friday"), and this one is no exception.  The movie is so violent.  Kane Hodder (who played Jason since "Part VII) is very good as Jason.  He should've been Jason starting from "Part 2."  If you're a big fan of the "Friday The 13th" movies, then check out "Jason X."  I guarantee it you'll love it.  Also, check out Jason in his new body suit a.k.a. Uber-Jason.
A+ ****** (out of ****** stars) 13/13

This movie is comedic and awesome. I never considered this movie cannon, but it should be enjoyed for what it is and not as a Friday The 13th movie. There are a lot of movies in the franchise that are better than this one, but there are also a lot of them which are worse than this one! A pleasant watch that i recommend!!

reviews.review_title: So let's basically ignore the fact the rest of the movies were called Friday the 13th and lets have Jason in space.
reviews.content: Yes, the previous movie released years before this titled "Friday the 13th: Jason Goes to Hell" has a bit in common with this movie. In that both movies have really nothing to do with the previous films. Granted part five and six have problems with the story as Jason is said to have been cremated in five, but that is nothing compared to the fact these movies do not even try to acknowledge previous installments of this film, though I am kind of glad they ditched the whole body snatching thing from "Jason Goes to Hell". This film has an introduction that is sort of old school, but then it is super futuristic and all and you are introduced to people you want dead. Well I wanted them dead, I never before pulled for Jason so much. The entire movie is like this, when the cyborg fights Jason the first time I was a bit bummed, but I laughed the second time when Jason became Super Jason. So basically, nearly all the characters are annoying and you are stuck pulling for the dude who says nothing, to me not the best ingredient for a horror movie. The film though was trying to be a bit more corny than usual and a bit funny, but for the most part I did not like it. I did like the part where they used the holographic girls to try and slow Jason down and what he did, but most of the comedy was a miss. In the end I almost think they made this movie less to make a serious movie, and more just to get Jason back in the public eye for his match with Freddy. Freddy needed it less because he has more personality than does Jason. There are worse ways to spend ones time, but this is most certainly not the best way, thankfully they never put Jason on a submarine or back in time with the dinosaurs.

reviews.review_title: The 'Jason' Film That Could Have Been... Instead, It's A Bad SciFy Channel Movie From The 2000's
How does he function with a brain that small?
reviews.content: Despite being released prior to 'Freddy Vs. Jason (2003)', 'Jason X (2001)' is actually the final entry in the original 'Friday The 13th' series. Set several years after the hockey-masked murderer fought the knife-fingered slasher, the film opens with our villain in chains in an underground research facility. It isn't long before he escapes, kills David Cronenberg and is tricked into being cryogenically frozen by a woman whom he manages to wound in the process. Over four hundred years later, a research team discovers both Jason and the woman who bested him frozen deep beneath the surface of a now-barren Earth. They take the pair on board their spaceship, thaw out our hero, fix her up with nanobots and perform tests on a frozen Jason who's unable to do them any harm... or so they think. As you can imagine, being frozen isn't a big deal for someone who has already been dead several times. When it comes down to it, the crux of the issue with this entry is that Jason going to space, much like Jason going to hell, should be far more interesting than this. Despite an entirely new setting, this is mostly more of the same and it's genuinely dull for the majority of its duration. It's just going through the motions, regardless of its efforts to do something different. The villain himself looks terrible here, with a dingy design that only vaguely alludes to his previously iconic aesthetic, and Uber Jason looks even worse, a supposedly 'cool' amalgamation of bulbous brushed steel and bland black leather. Plus, despite Hodder's as admirable as ever performance, there's something off about the big bad; he just acts like some dude. Though he's as proficient at killing and, well, not dying as ever before, he just isn't imposing and is only about as menacing as a wet tea towel. It feels as though he, too, is just going through the motions at this point, which is weird considering he's doing the exact same thing he's been doing for the previous eight films. The same can be said for the other characters, actually. They may be making their debut here, but we've seen them all before. None of them are anything more than cardboard cutouts, walking corpses given the illusion of life in the hope you'll care when they inevitably return to the vacant shells they so obviously already are. They scream, they scramble to come up with a plan, they scream some more; they're just canon fodder and it doesn't matter which one of them bites the dust next because they all serve the exact same purpose and have only the vaguest semblance of a distinguishing personality. There's this really weird moment where the professor randomly engages in some sort of sex game with his student (whose age is uncomfortably never made clear), having his nipple pinched with a pair of tongs while he wears a sheer negligee and demands he be punished harder, and this never comes back into the plot whatsoever. In fact, I'm not sure the two characters involved even speak outside of this single entirely unnecessary scene. There are a few baffling moments like that, but not so many that the piece can elicit the sort of bemused disbelief that results in an experience that can be laughed at. Instead, it toes the line between bad and fine, emerging as entirely uninteresting because of it. The flick has moments which seem to suggest it isn't taking itself as seriously as some of the other entries in its series, but most of the time it just doesn't seem in on the joke. It's too serious for its own good; a schlocky, tongue-on-cheek approach would have suited the material much better. It does attempt humour on occasion and, though this is appreciated, it's almost entirely unsuccessful. Its cheesy one-liners aren't funny and, because of the silent nature of its antagonist, they're often spoken by characters who are in the process of having their lives ripped away, which is strange to say the least. The cringe is at its strongest when the affair indulges in the sort of turn-of-the-millennium 'coolness' that plagued everything from feature films to television commercials around that time. Irony never comes into play, so the cringe isn't enjoyable, it's just cringe. Though the silliest moments are typically the most successful, the picture isn't funny enough to be classed as horror-comedy. At the same time, it almost isn't scary enough to be classed as straight-up horror. There's very little semblance of atmosphere and the direction is generally flat. Its aesthetic is also a bit inconsistent, and it looks like an incredibly cheap sci-fi TV show way more often than it should. It makes frequent use of the kind of early 2000s CGI that makes you wonder how anyone took digital effects seriously enough to develop them to the point they're at today. In the behind-the-scenes material on the DVD, there's this really funny moment where the filmmakers are talking about how they never used visual effects for the sake of it and only used them to tell their story, and then it hard cuts to the scene where the android's nipples fall off. Whoever edited that behind-the-scenes documentary understands the assignment far more than anyone who worked on the actual movie. The feature has a couple of moments of good gore, including a delightfully gooey scene in which Jason gets a bit of his own medicine, but it's generally quite tame. In all fairness, though, it does continue the franchise's tradition of having one of the best kills in one of the worst movies. If you've seen the flick, you probably know which death I'm talking about; it's genuinely brilliant, a gloriously gory demise worthy of a much better picture. Though this isn't entirely unsuccessful and its attempts at distinguishing itself from its predecessors are admirable, it's mostly dull overall. I appreciate the effort taken to tell a slightly different story this time around, but the differences really are slight and the outcome isn't as effective as most of the other entries in the series. The flick is often fine, but it's generally subpar and is honestly one of the weakest 'Friday The 13th' movies. In some ways, it's even worse than the ninth entry in the franchise. It's way more competent, sure, but it's far less interesting and you can't even laugh at it. For how genuinely terrible 'Jason Goes To Hell: The Final Friday (1993)' is, at least it isn't boring.

reviews.review_title: Hey, at least it's better than the last one
reviews.content: Easily the fifth or sixth time Friday the 13th has jumped the shark, this time pulling a double corkscrew backflip along the way. Following in the hallowed footsteps of Leprechaun 4, Hellraiser: Bloodline and Critters 4, this installment finds Jason cryogenically frozen for four hundred years and defrosted aboard a lightly-staffed spacecraft. No explanation is offered for his abrupt return from the depths of the nether, where he was unceremoniously dumped at the end of Jason Goes to Hell, though I'm not sure that really would've made a difference. This is a willfully stupid playground for half-baked science fiction ideas, terrible wardrobe choices and budget special effects; a cut-rate production that would feel right at home on the Sci-Fi Channel at 3am. Predictable to the end, it touches all the bases with gratuitous nudity, shallow characters, mysterious returns from certain doom and a truckload of dismemberments / decapitations / deaths. The only thing we're missing is the trademarked screeching cat fake-out, presumably because no self-respecting animal would be seen in such a production. Apart from one fleeting moment of self-deprecating parody near the end - which is totally out of place, but admittedly had me howling - there's no reason for this to exist. It's the kind of thing that would've thrived on the bootleg circuit, akin to Roger Corman's unreleased Fantastic Four, but by actually sending it to theaters, New Line took the wind out of those sails. The best thing I can say here is, hey, at least it's better than the last one.

reviews.review_title: Pinhead, Leprechaun and Jason walk into a space bar
reviews.content: Talk about a series killer  transporting Jason Voorhees to the year 2455 (and into space) in 'Jason X,' stating he "disappeared" after his final appearance in 2010. Where do you go from there? Oh, yeah, you reboot the franchise in 2009. And other than that inevitable reboot, 'X' absolutely was the original series finish (despite two of the sequels labeled as "final" and not counting the spin off 'Freddy Vs. Jason.') 'X' does start off with a good idea: after finally being captured, studied and executed  well, unsuccessfully hung, shot, etc, that is  Jason is set to be frozen. Though a good idea opening, four main questions arise: why leave the mask on? Where did he find a machete? How could he possibly get that machete through a thick metal door (even if Jason had great strength, the machete would still buckle)? And why wait two years after capture to finally attempt an escape  remember he can simply teleport himself at will anywhere, so why the wait? If you can look past those questions, then you're in store for many more lunacies in the film: horrible special effects, lame humor, plot that utterly rips off of both 'Aliens' and 'Alien: Resurrection,' laughable finale and 445 years later (one character mistakenly says 455, which would've been accurate due to the movie probably was made in 2000, but it's set originally in 2010) and even though the technology has improved, humans seem maybe 4 steps behind today's time. Overall, not the worst 'Friday,' it does have some good action, including an android battle and one of the best series scenes involving their version of a holodeck, which sums up the entire franchise. Favorite line: "You gotta be kidding me" in which I repeated the same thing. Watch the closing and you'll understand why.

reviews.review_title: Better than I thought, but still . . . Jason in space?
reviews.content: This was better than I thought it would be. It's far from perfect, but at least the gore's back and relatively creative. Unlike the pathetic previous New Line attempt, JASON GOES TO HELL, which tried to do something different (by not letting us see Jason as Jason for most of the movie--big mistake!), here we get Jason right from the start doing what Jason does best: KILLING!!!While I found Jason X exciting when released, the film has not aged well, particularly the digital FX. It's still one of the better "horror icons in space" sequels, easily beating similar films with Leprechaun, Hellraiser, etc., but that's not saying much. Launching an earthbound series into space is always a bad idea, and a potential franchise-killer.

reviews.review_title: Please! In the name of Michael Myers and all that is holy...
reviews.content: STOP MAKING THESE MOVIES! First this series copped the white mask from Halloween. Second it made countless dumb sequels in the name of gore and cheap money. But now, maybe earlier, it has started to repeat itself. When you can't even come up with inventive ways of killing people, especially when that is supposed to be the draw, it is time to call it a day. This series has delved into creative incest. The best part is stolen from one of the lame named predecessors, when JV bashes a CG girl infested sleeping bag into tree. It is funny, because JV is such a moron. When Friday the 13th Part VIII: Jason Takes Manhattan sleeps with Jason Goes To Hell: The Final Friday, you get this dirty blonde little piece of trailer trash.P.S. Lisa, Brent Spiner called, you got some explaining to do.

reviews.review_title: A horrendous campy sci-fi flick that happens to feature Jason...again
reviews.content: It seems like a lot of horror flicks take their character to space in one instalment or another. Hellraiser, Leprechaun, Jason Voorhees, Aliens...well that one might be a stretch. I don't know why anyone thinks that's a good idea but because this happens to feature one of the greatest slashers in film history, and because of one unique scene this is actually watchable. I think it does represent a definite downward spiral in the series. I think when New Line took over from Paramount for Jason Goes To Hell they lost sight of what this series is all about. I think fans and die hard Jason freaks would have came back twenty times to watch Jason slash his way through Crystal Lake but New Line insisted on changing that up. So here we are 450 + years in the future on the a ship named Grendal and Jason is loose and rampaging like he hasn't missed a beat. The concept isn't terrible, the cast is okay, Jason is still awesome, and I can even accept Uber-Jason and think it was kind of a cool spin however cheesy that is. But even with these things this is a really cheesy, campy, poorly made sci-fi flick. The special effects are simply awful, the beast thing that they shoot in the cargo hold before finding Jason is the worst piece of special effects I've ever seen (and I've watched some cheesy monster flicks.) Why not save the budget and take him back to Crystal Lake? Lexa Doig should be the lead scream queen of the film. There is great potential here for her character as the head of the research project in 2008 who inadvertently gets frozen with Jason for 450 years. Unfortunately Doig is completely underused and almost pointless to the story. Lisa Ryder is deliciously horrible (this is a good thing) as the cyborg/android Kay-Em. Her best scenes are taking on and taking down Jason but her role is hilariously B-Movie magic. She's awful as is the character. Peter Mensah is about the best performance in the film as the tough as nails Brodski. He is way underused because he could have easily been the best character. Unfortunately he gets all camped out in the end looking ridiculous in some CGI scenes of him floating in space. Melyssa Ade is the sarcastic and shrewd crew member. She's fun and has some great lines including one of the best lines in this film and any Friday the 13th film when someone asks what's going on and she says dead serious "Jason F%$&*ing Voorhees is what's going on." Classic. Jonathan Potts is sort of the typical scuzzy lawyer type character that everyone despises. He does well and has some good scenes and is actually pretty good overall. Chuck Campbell is the geeky scientist with a thing for the android. His character is a little underdeveloped given he is sort of a main character but for a campy B-character he is solid. And finally Kane Hodder, the legendary Jason actor returns for this instalment. He's still good in the role, he still IS Jason Voorhees but the unfortunate horrible campiness of this film makes his performance slightly less impressive and uber Jason is a crazy addition that I'm still not sure is good or just stupid.Fairly new director James Issac takes the reigns for Jason X. Since this film he's done a couple of horror films so he obviously likes the genre. I'm not sure what kind of budget or script he was given but I imagine he struggled to make this a half decent flick and you know when its all done and said it isn't the worst thing I've ever laid eyes on. It's watchable. Friday the 13th the entire series let alone the tenth instalment isn't exactly masterpiece film making and is all about the cult following it gains. Someone, somewhere probably loves Jason X. The one brilliant redeeming scene in this film is in the last fifteen minutes when they use a holographic scene of Crystal Lake to distract Jason complete with two young taut teenage campers stripping, smoking dope and tantalizing him. He proceeds to beat one girl with the other in a sleeping bag...again classic. Jason X is for the true fans but for most it'll be hard to sit through. You have to sit back, laugh, enjoy and just remember the whole series in its entirety is legendary. I know because I just watched them all in three days...just for you. 6/10

reviews.review_title: The opening credits were the best part
reviews.content: I remember how a sketch from an early episode of "MADtv" featured Jason Voorhees IN SPACE! I wonder how the creators of that sketch felt when this movie was released. Okay, it wasn't exactly the same, as this movie takes place in the future. I remember looking up Leonard Maltin's movie guide and being amazed at the sheer number of slasher films that his book seemed to be cluttered up with! I think "Friday The 13th" has the most numbered sequels of anything in his book. It was weird looking up plots and finding out the villains died in the last movie. Every single one of them is back! It was bad enough that they lied to us with "Friday The 13th Part IV: The Final Chapter". Then they lied AGAIN with "Jason Goes To Hell: The Final Friday". It looks like this is still the last canonical appearance of Jason in this timeline, although they simply made a remake years later. It's weird how they attempted to make the formula different in the last couple of movies. It's a pity they were just as dumb as the originals, if not worse. Anyway, this film features Jason being frozen for hundreds of years and then terrorizing the people on a spaceship. It's weird to see how these supposedly genius scientists are every bit as stupid as the kids on Crystal Lake.They just get killed off over and over like the dumb teenagers hundreds of years ago. I guess you could argue Jason simply became more powerful, but still they should know better. I was amazed at how awful the CGI was in the training simulation. I guess that might have been intentional, seeing as how it was a simulation, but it still looked hideous. We even got to see these guys die twice. I'm glad I watched this on Friday the 13th even if it wasn't in the title. I saw it on the Syfy Channel and honestly, it fit right there with their cheesy movies. *1/2

reviews.review_title: X Does Not Necessarily Mark the Spot.
reviews.content: In 2010 Jason (Kane Hodder) has finally been captured by military scientists. Unable to kill him, they figure they can freeze him cryogenically and do research on his invincibility. Naturally that plan goes by the wayside as chaos strikes and many are killed. A woman (Lexa Doig) is able to freeze the titled character anyway (and herself). Fast forward some 445 years (that is not a misprint) to 2455. A moronic space crew of college professors, students and military specialists discover the two frozen and take it upon themselves to unfreeze them. Naturally Jason is still wanting to kill everyone in sight and it becomes painfully ironic that the human race has not evolved one bit as teens continue to get naked, act stupid and pretend like nothing could ever happen to them. Welcome to life in the 25th Century. "Jason X" (the X being the Roman numeral for the 10th installment in the "Friday the 13th" series) is probably the dumbest and most full-blown dud of the entire group of films. It really has very little to do with the 10 other films of the series ("Freddy vs. Jason" is the 11th official movie) and it appears to be a silly ploy to get a new generation of movie-goers to watch this horrid cinematic idea. After an eight-year absence (those were eight good years) the American cinema had to put up with a revolution in this disaster of a series. No end in sight apparently as the series continues to sicken and torment us. Turkey (0 stars out of 5).

Subintelligent characters, idiotic conversations and behaviors, atrocious acting and CGI, boring soundtrack, a movie production seemingly made for TV in the 90s. I think I saw a 20th century rifle scope on their futuristic BFG in 25th century, just wow. Said to have a big budget, really? Truly pathetic, I just stopped watching cos this Jason sucks big freaking ass.

Saw for the 1st time in 2021 and i absolutley loved it. Took me back to simpler times when films were fun, in the modern age of political correctness and woke genz snowflakes ruining everything, this was a breath of fresh air.A fun popcorn film, thats just for fun, no political agendas or messaging, just some action, hot babes and some funny 1 liners.

I didn't think it could get much worse than Jason Goes to Hell but... yeah, this is bad. I'm starting to theorize why most Friday the 13th boxed sets only have 1-8. I feel like even the studio is probably ashamed of 9 & 10.And justifiably so. They're horrible.So the basic (spoiler-reduced) synopsis is:Jason gets cryogenically frozen to be thawed 400 years later so he can basically do the same thing he's done during every other movie, but in the future.The characters are unlikable, the story reeks of series fatigue and corporate greed. The movie simply has no purpose. It's missing everything that made most of the earlier entries entertaining. It's just... a hollow slasher where things keep happening, but nothing occurs that's of particular interest to the viewer.I personally disown Jason Goes to Hell and Jason X as Friday the 13th films, because they're horrendous. The eighth entry, Jason Takes Manhattan, should've been the last. Because that movie was actually fun and enjoyable.And, of course, even Freddy vs. Jason ignores this film's existence... good riddance! Never again on this one.

reviews.review_title: The immortal Jason Voorhees is back!!!!
reviews.content: Minor Spoilers for Big Jason Maniacs.Jason was at it again. More monstrous then ever before Mr. Voorhees causes more destruction in Jason X! I have seen most of the Friday the 13th movies with the monster Jason in them and most of them are very violent and gory and the second last installment Jason Goes To Hell was really plain silly. This Jason movie however is actually well written and has a bigger budget with some good effects. The battle between Jason and the android was neat. When Jason became Uber-Jason that was really good but near the end when the guy is trying to fool jason in the Crystal Lake area was believe it or not to ME was funny. I thought is was funny because the girls were stupid going in those sleeping bags and what happen? Jason picked them bags ups and banged them against the trees repeatedly untill they were dead. This to ME is the best Jason film to date because less sex, nudity, a more a variety of Jason kills and and lots of action. All Jason fans check this one out soon!

reviews.review_title: not as bad as people make it out to be
reviews.content: When I saw the reviews for this movie all hope I had for this movie had been crushed then I saw the movie and I have to say I am confused why so many people hate this movie. It does have plot holes and it is pointless to put Jason in space but it is entertaining as hell. The movie is more or less a parody of the other Friday the 13th movies and it is very funny when it wants to be. My main problem with the movie is the bland and uninteresting characters which are just their to die. The only interesting characters are Bronsky and the android. The end is brilliant and is reminiscent of the other Friday the 13th movies. The kills are very uncreative. The only kill that is very creative and brutal is the first one Jason makes is space. All in all it is not for everyone but it is very entertaining and fun.

reviews.review_title: Anything is better than Jason goes to hell
reviews.content: This film is still not good but it beats out Jason Goes to Hell. I have a lot of problems with this film but it at least has a few cool scenes. I won't be going over the synopsis since plenty of other reviewers have already done that, instead i will be going over what this movie succeeds at and fails at. The movie definitely succeeds in the death and gore department right from the opening. I also think the space setting is alright. I also think the tone and atmosphere is okay but not as good as previous installments. The movie fails at a lot of things though. First almost every character is unlikeable and the actors phone in their performances more than I would like. The CGI is also awful they should've gone as practical as possible and removed a lot of the bad effects in the film. The plot is also worse than a lot of the rest of the films in the series. I also am not a dan of super Jason literally why??? In my opinion avoid this one unless your a completionist

reviews.review_title: Dedicated only for Friday the 13th fans.
reviews.content:
Welcome Jason to the new century! The most controversial, loved or hated, and famous killer of movies makes his debut in the new century. Along his machete and trademark hockey mask, Jason also brings back the slasher genre in good shape.
With all the hype that FREDDY V.S. JASON caused at the time, JASON X delivered expectations and worked very well as an apperitive.I'm a die hard FRIDAY THE 13th fan, probably the #1 in my country (México) and I enjoyed this movie only because Jason was the main star.
The plot is cheesy 100% but who cares? Die hard fans waited 9 years to watch Jason on the screen again. I can still remember perfectly when in 1997 the internet spread a rumor about an upcoming Friday the 13th film. Many fan made scripts were available but no official word until year 2000 when it was finally announced that JASON X began production. Also, in 1997 the media made official a confrontation between Freddy and Jason. I taped the news report in several news programs from México, and USA. It wasn't until 2001 that the movie was officially announced.Anyways, JASON X is what WE the die hard Jason fans wanted: Jason doing the killings we love through all the movie, with the occasional sex scenes, gore!, and a brutal Jason. Kane Hodder is excellent as always. This may be his best performance as Jason. The effects are cheap but weren't needed at all, the gore played the important part this time. SPOILERS Some deaths are high class, like  when Jason smashes the frozen woman's head. Bloody brilliant!.But the best scene in the movie is the Camp Crystal Lake retro V.R. This scene is pure gold in the series! It's a historical moment in the series, Camp Crystal Lake featured in the year 2001. And even better, Jason doing one of his classic kills! As in part VII Jason smashes repeteadly to a tree a teen girl inside a sleepingbag. Brutal as ever. This may be not important to everyone, but the fans find it amazing.
Jason's demise in this movie  has to be the least liked in the series, although he's beaten by a strong man. At least this scene is better than the painfully to watch end in Part VIII. JASON X is dedicated only to FRIDAY THE 13th fans. If you don't like it, don't watch it. It's not meant for horror fans in general. In the Friday the 13th scale: 7/10.

reviews.review_title: Jason kicks better ass in space then at the lake...
reviews.content: Going where others have failed (in space), Jason Voorhees delivers. In Jason X, the movie starts off in the Crystal Lake Research Center where Lexa Doig's character Rowan is a doctor studying Jason and his ability to regenerate cells (which explains why he can't really die). After an escape and a slaughter of guards Jason ends up tricked into a cryogenic freezing chamber where he and Rowan get frozen.Now over 400 hundred years later when Earth is uninhabitable, a group of research students discover the pair and bring them aboard their ship to thaw them out and take them to Earth II. This is when trouble strikes as Jason awakes just a little more than pissed off. He destroys a team of soldiers and walks about the ship slaying anyone in his path. The remaining few must work together and stop him.Jason X is the first horror sequel to give proper justice to the space setting. After both Pinhead and the Leprechaun failed miserably, he comes through for us and entertains throughout the movie. Kane Hodder is just a beast as he tears through each of his victims with some of the coolest death scenes to date. Aside from the abnormally large but greatly appreciated body count, the entire cast as a whole entertained. Good acting by all, especially from Doig. Going into this movie a giant fan of the Friday the 13th series and not expecting too much, I must say it quickly became tied for my favorite (right up there with number 6 - Jason Lives). The humor was played well and the upgraded Uber Jason was just damn sweet!What are you waiting for... go see it!

reviews.review_title: jason's bad and he's back... and in space...
reviews.content: after the bomb that was dropped on the Friday the 13th series with "jason goes to hell", i am happy to say that Jason X will redeem the series. From the inventive killings, and the creation of Uber-Jason to the fact that he ended up in space in the year 2455. I must also compliment the addition of Sergeant Brodski, one of the toughest men i've ever seen in a Sci-Fi/Horror film. Of course if the future has as many hot chicks as seen in Jason X i can't wait...

reviews.review_title: SO stupid, but fun...turn off your brain and enjoy
reviews.content: This movie has the WORST plot ever. EVER. But, if you turn of your brain, get a bunch of friends, get together, have a party, put this on, root for Jason...that's a very entertaining 90 minutes. Don't watch it by yourself.The plot, or that's what you could call it, is that Jason Vorhees has been frozen and, 400 years later, unfrozen. He is taken up into a space ship, then recognized as the famous Jason Vorhees, they unfreeze him, duh, and Jason causes havoc.Plenty of violence!AND stupid horror characters.Not the best film in the world, certainly not the worst, but a good stupid film.

Okay, maybe Jason X wasn't the best movie ever, but if you're a fan of camp, you absolutely have to see this movie.  The scene with Jason at Camp Crystal Lake nearly had me p***ing my pants.  The whole film is so totally ridiculous you can't help but laugh.  There are a few generally suspensful/scary moments (Jason stalking the marines was probably the best), but mostly, the film was just silly.  There were some truly great one-liners, some inventive murders (liquid-nitrogen, the screw), though I nearly vomited when one marine had her throat slit (the sound was hideous). And the movie ends with one of the characters riding Jason 'into the sunset'.  Could a movie get any better?

reviews.review_title: I guess this movie must've taken place on a Thursday
reviews.content: The 9th film in the Friday The 13th series claimed to be "The Final Friday" so I guess this movie must take place on a Thursday. But it doesn't really matter what day it takes place on, nothing could save this mind-bogglingly bad movie. Jason. In space. You just can't help but wonder what the hell they were thinking. It reminds me of the show "Josie & the pussy cats in space." Some characters just shouldn't be set in space and Josie & the pussycats and Jason are prime examples of this.Man, what a bad movie.My rating: 1/10

reviews.review_title: You know they've jumped the shark when...
reviews.content: Jason X is the 10th entry in the Friday the 13th series, even though part 9 was entitled THE FINAL Friday. In this entry, Jason is locked up in a containment center in the year 2010. He ends up escaping and being cryogenically frozen. He awakes aboard a spaceship in 2455 and begins killing the people on board. While not as terrible as Part 7, this movie is really bad. The writers had to have run out of earthly ideas in order to come up with something as stupid as putting him in space in the future. I'm just glad they didn't put aliens aboard the ship.The acting in this movie is about as pathetic as it gets. One of the lead roles in the movie was played by the guy from the Expedia.com commericals. Awesome...You might think that people from the 25th century would be a little more advanced but uh...No, they're not. They're just as stupid as the people from the 80's slasher movies were.The special effects was a real cop out in this movie. This is the first Friday film that's used CGI for blood and gore. The plot of the film, as I've mentioned before, was retarded. A scene where they tried to reference earlier Friday the 13th films using holograms backfired by being utterly retarded looking. Everything Jason does in this movie just makes you laugh at how ridiculous the whole concept is. Thankfully, any Friday movies made after this will take place in modern times.1/10

reviews.review_title: Boldly going where every horror monster has gone before
reviews.content: Yes, there comes a time in a horror movie monsters life where they decide to send him into space. The first was "Critters IV: They're invading our space." That one almost made sense, since the critters came from space to start with. And you get to see Angela Basset naked. Or her body double, anyway. Then you had Hellraiser IV: Bloodline, which ended with trapping Pinhead in a dimension where he could only phone it in for direct to DVD sequels. That was followed by "Leprechaun in Space", a movie where I think halfway through, they decided, "Let's make this a farce, no one is taking this seriously, why should we?" The idea is you put the monster in space, and watch him reenact the alien movies.Well, sadly, this was the end they intended to put poor Jason to. They had him get cryogenically frozen and then resurrected on a spaceship, along with Lexa Doig of Andromeda fame. (In a role reversal,Andromeda co-star Lisa Ryder plays an android, and a better one than Doig played on the series. Probably didn't do the casting right.) Of course, Jason comes back from the dead, and starts picking off horny undergrads and space marines. He is apparently killed (right, like that hasn't happened before) but resurrected with the help of nanobots into "Super-Jason".And why would a science ship have giant drill bits sticking straight up to impale star marines on? It boggles the mind.

The plot Finally captured in the year 2008, Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder) is held inside a government research facility whose scientists try to answer the question that keeps eluding them - why one of the most infamous mass murderers in history cannot die. Once Rowan (Lexa Doig), leader of the research project, prepares the specimen for cryogenic suspension, a greedy scientist goes over her head and comes to remove Jason, only to have the mad slasher break free and slaughter him and his entire entourage. Tricking Jason into following her, Rowan eludes him into entering the cryogenic freezer and begins the process, but a breach in the system causes her to freeze with him. The government tries to deny any evidence of the project, and nearly four centuries pass, during which the Earth gradually becomes less and less habitable and humans have relocated to a planet in another star system that they've named Earth II. A team of young students descends onto the ruined Earth, where they find the frozen bodies of Jason and Rowan in the forgotten research facility and take back on board their ship with them. Rowan is thawed and revived, but the team mistakes Jason to be dead, having no idea of his abilities or motives. Before long, Jason awakens to the sound of young people having premarital sex once again, and the carnage erupts once again as the ship proceeds to Earth II.
