The remaining survivors fight for their lives as the centuries-old mad slasher proves that he is just as evil and just as indestructible during their time as he was centuries before.I have seem this movie a few times now, I really liked It the first time saw but every time I see it always find something new i don't like about this movie.The last time we saw Jason he was going to hell and then the next thing we see him being chained up somewhere, I need to ask this How the hell did he get out of Hell ?.I saw this again last night, for some reason I find it really boring and it was hard for me to try stay awake.Jason going to space was not a good idea at all and Jason getting upgrade was such a really bad idea. i hated that turned him into some robot. he was not the Jason we all knew or have been scared of before.The acting wasn't half that bad and there were only one or two good deaths scenes this movie.i going give this movie 4 out 10

reviews.review_title: The film feels like it was made by a horny teenage nerd...but that doesn't mean it isn't fun to watch
reviews.content: Silly, juvenile, but admittedly fun- Jason X never really decides whether it wants to be a parody or actually take it seriously, but there is some entertaining moments along the way. First thing first, I don't like this movie, and there are certainly quite a few reasons why. First off, the majority of the acting is pretty horrible, with Lisa Ryder being the only halfway decent actress throughout the whole film. The set looks cheaply made, like a bunch of rejected sets of an early 2000's sci-fi film that was never made. The CGI can be quite obvious at times, although it isn't horrible, despite it sticking out so much. Some of the dialogue is super ridiculous, and in general the film is poorly written with some things clearly showing this film was made in 2001 and not 4 centuries in the future. Despite all that though, this film is surprisingly fun to watch, and is quite possibly one of the most entertaining entries in the franchise as a whole. Its kills can be fun from time to time, its setting and technology somewhat interesting, and its goofy antics are obviously stupid, but quite enjoyable to see play out on screen. In the end, Jason X was not nearly as bad as I thought it may be, although it certainly isn't in any way a good film. Maybe its unneeded, maybe its dumb and childish, but it certainly isn't the worst film ever made, nor the worst in the franchise.My Rating: 4.8/10.

I left the theaters back in April in complete amazement in how good Jason X was. I know I know Jason X is not an oscar worthy film nor is it part of the top 250 but it was still entertaining as hell. Being a big fan of the "Friday" franchise I found Jason X to be a great entry into the long running series. The film is not really scary at all but it is action packed and very entertaining. I can't wait until it comes out on DVD!!! OVERALL: 8/10

If you were ever into the Friday the 13 movies you will love this one. It has throw backs to the other films (similar deaths, etc,) You will cheer for Jason to keep raising his death toll and snicker at the corny lines spoken by those about to feel Jasons' wrath. I'd say this is one of the best Friday the 13 movies ever made and would recommend it to anyone who enjoyed the 9 earlier films.

reviews.review_title: Jason X...Jason goes to spaaaaace!! Because isn't that just you think of when you think Jason Voorhies?
reviews.content: So this was probably more fun than part 9 but it feels even more weaker in tone and further removed from what Jason's supposed to be about to me, as godawful and bizarre as Jason Goes to Hell was, it still barely and just about felt like a Friday movie. This never really does, apart from that one funny scene with the old school Crystal Lake hologram. The overall experience and quality of this flick right from the get go is that of an especially poor episode of some crappy science fiction show. It has a very noticeably cheap direct to video feel and aesthetic to it, the bad kind of direct to video, and it's not much more fun to watch than your average sci-fi channel original, Jason or not. I suppose it must be a lot more fun if you take on board that it isn't meant to be taken seriously, but that can only go so far, and the movie being aware of how lousy it was really didn't add anything help, because it really isn't smart enough of a movie to really do anything with it! It may have been stupid on purpose, but of me it was still pretty dang stupid and lame anyway, it couldn't even get that right!! While the awesome classic that is part 6 did show that a little well-placed wry humour could go a long way, this goes overboard with it, and it's hackneyed attempts at self-deprecation come off as obnoxious. The 'music' was really bad as well, abysmally bad, cheap tacky-ass excuse for a music score, there's no finesse to it, it just loudly blurts out whenever something happens and there are no slower menacing themes to go along with the nonexistent atmosphere, I couldn't believe it was by the same composer as the original. One of the few things that makes it worth watching is of course Kane Hodder, although all but one of the kills are weak or worse lazy cutaways, he still brought his very distinctive air of intimidation and lethalness to his movements and he was always fun to watch as the character. I didn't really care for Jason's design however, it's not nearly one of his best, he's supposed to be a rotten zombie from hell at this point, so why does he have silly tufts of hair? And the head is too big, and the mecha-Jason is cool and all but he does virtually besides break down a few doors, he looks like an action figure! I love Lisa Ryder's character of the perky android, her super upbeat attitude and over the top delivery fit right into the world of the movie and I thought the best part was when she kicks Jason's ass and blows him to bits when she brought out the big guns! The movie just overall never really did it for me that much, because it's so far removed from the simple but solid magic that these films had in their eighties heydays. Thank goodness Freddy Vs Jason gave the undead slasher a little more dignity than this effort did. Space is truly where the long running horror movie franchises go to die! It is somewhat entertaining and enjoyable and it's absolutely nothing like the other movies in the series and to be fair isn't totally without a certain tacky charm, but as a Friday the 13th movie it's definitely one of the worst ever, there's too much silly annoying humour and the terrible production values bring it way down, and perhaps worst of all it's downright forgettable, can't say that about most of the other movies.. I believe I'll take creepy dark woods Jason over this any day! X.

Excellent film!!! the director/writer decided to go complete "Camp" with this one!!! hahaha, great way to go! this is Great campy fun! with the splatter you expect from a Friday film!!!Jason is back! only this time he's UBER jason!!! wah hahahahhahahaha

reviews.review_title: At least Jason X tried to do something different
reviews.content: I must confess that I am not really a fan of the Friday The 13th series. As a teenager, I saw most of the sequels on HBO and could tell little difference between them. So taking a cryogenically frozen Jason and putting him 400 years in the future in outer space is not the worst idea out there. I actually thought that could be a good premise to a tired franchise. Jason X has a lot of problems and is a mixed bag that ultimately is guilty pleasure viewing. I do enjoy this for a laugh, but it could have been legitimately good if it was taken more seriously. The writing, dialogue and acting is really bad, with a mostly clueless young cast that could have been on Dawson's Creek or something. It does what most science fiction does and rips off Star Trek. The tone is really silly and tongue in cheek. However, Kane Hodder is as great here as our hero Jason and he is as menacing as ever. The money from the film obviously went into special f/x and cinematography. Jason X really looks great, but with a flimsy plot and goofy acting the film falls flat on it's face. But if that was tightened up, Jason X could have gone the distance. That having been said, I enjoy Jason X and Freddy Vs Jason much better than the other films in the series.

I thought this would be crap. But it was great. Jason had great kills and a better story. When he becomes super powered was really cool but it still couldn't compare to the original. Jason is a really cool character but I think they should stop know. Let him die already. 15 thousand sequels is enough. Just stop trying.
When I got this movie as a present I thought the person wasted 6 bucks but it was a really good after seeing the other sequels (not including the third one that was good) but it was fine. The best futuristic horror (if it's not the first).

Jason X is as all of you know the latest installment of the friday the 13th series. Thankfully, this movie ignored the 9th version of the series and went straight to the story.  In the beginning, Jason is cryogenically frozen with a woman and they are not discovered until 400-500 years later.  The two are found by a space crew made up of a greedy captain and inexperienced hot science professors.  When they melt the bodies(including Jason those morons!) Jason is out on a killing spree on this ship.Like in all movies of the series, this movie has awful acting, tons of gore, and hot young teenagers.  This movie may seem like the best one of the series but it should not take any pride in it. The only noteworthy thing about watching this awful movie is that it is noted as the horror movie with the most amount of murders. It's true but they went over the limit; at least 1 person was attacked or killed every minute in the stupidest way. Also, may I note that this movie is supposed to be a horror, but when I am watching this I sometimes think they tried to make this film a comedy. Not a good combination. Anyway, for the die hard Jason fans, go see it. For the average movie-goer, you can skip it no big deal. 3 stars out of 10.

Wow! Talk about your piece of garbage. I haven't been this entertained in so long, I might have busted my sides. Obviously, this film was made to satirize itself. Or was it?Bad acting, funky lighting and ridiculous dialogue really create quite a quandary: Is it good because it's so bad or is it too good to be considered terrible?I've decided to label this film a piece of brilliant stupidity. Most idiotic films try to hard to make themselves legitimate, but Jason X simply throws all of those thoughts out the window. This may be the best sequel in the series, which isn't saying much, but then again, what does one expect from a film series with 10 remakes of itself. I will say this,it will be a hell of a lot better than Halloween Resurrection.If you've seen the trailer for it, this film takes itselfway too seriously. For crying out loud, how many times can Michael Myers come back in a serious and scary fashion? The producing team for Halloween should take notes from Jason X: you've made far too many sequels up to this point, so you might as well have a little fun with it.I will also say this: David Cronenberg's cameo performance was pretty cool, and Lexa Doig was ravishing.

reviews.review_title: yes and no about Jason X (and a few BEEPs)
reviews.content: so you want to see a BEEPy movie so you can BEEP your date? be sure not to watch Jason X, because it's such a BEEP your date will not want to BEEP you anymore. yes, it's stupid. yes, it's more scifi than horror. yes, sean cunningham is still member of the crew. no this is not exactly another Friday the 13th movie. at least not one like you suspect one to be. yes, Jason has got some new looks, so he doesn't look like Jason anymore. no, it is not a sequel, since Jason goes to Hell ended with Freddy and Jason. but don't be afraid, Freddy and Jason will battle each other in the next Friday the 13th chapter: Freddy vs Jason. just skip this BEEP and watch Freddy and Jason instead. by the way, during that movie, your date will definitely want to BEEP you.

I'd like to start this review off with a little question: What do you get when you combine STAR TREK with Friday the 13th?... Well, what do you get?... Wanna take a guess? JASON X of course! I'd love to see what the planning phase was like for this movie. Imagine a bunch of filmmakers sitting around: "Where can we set this latest Jason movie?" "Ooh, I know... how about in the Wild West?" "Na!" "What if Jason turns up in LA and starts killing gang..." "Meh!" "Ooh. Ooh, I know... Jason onboard a ship!" "Hello? JASON TAKES MANHATTAN?!" "No, no... a SPACE ship!" "WE LOVE IT... here's $10 Million!!!" So, in a half-cocked, hair-brained plot device, Jason winds up on a space ship several centuries in the future. And he pretty much does what he's always done. Stalking around and killing people. There are absolutely no interesting characters. The dialogue is eye-rolling atrocious. And it all feels so shoddy. Like an early episode of STAR TREK, but without the camp quality. There is one cool thing about this one however, Jason gets a solid metal mask! Other than that, this film is worthy of a photon torpedo carpet bombing!!!

If you're asking me if this movie is good, my answer is no; not by a long shot. If you're asking me if this movie is entertaining, then my answer is absolutely; it's one of the more entertaining movies I've seen this year. This movie doesn't succeed in being scary, nor does it do anything to advance Jason's overall storyline (I'm pretty sure most people wouldn't consider this cannon), but there are plenty of gory, sometimes hysterical, kills that fill this film's meager runtime.
F

This was a great ride from begining to end, I remember wanting to hear the Bodies song or The Original Jason theme, but none. Even so, the movie had some great effects, the Jason player (Kane Hodder) was so excellent. The actors were, well, good enough. David Cronenberg, (Scanners, Existenz and Nightbreed) makes a cameo as a Scientist. I expected the usual machete slashing, but got random killings and decapitiations. Out of 10, 6 or 7.

well after being a fan of the friday series since 1988 when i seen friday the 13th part 8: jason takes mannhaten at a local drivein i 've been hooked. since that summer when i was 1 1/2 i've rented, bought and seen everyone (exept for JGTH) at least 30 times! well now here comes JASON X. whatever happened to friday the 13th titles) anyway, i saw this movie on opening day and i was surprised that alotta people where buying tickets to JASON X. so i sat with my friends and i pretty much enjoyed every second of this movie. there were about 30 kills and intence action. the crystal lake scene was cool and funny. i loved the way Uber-Jason looked but for the sure tobe following sequels (11,12,13, and probably a freddy versus jason) his look should go back to normal Jason.   any way i give this a 10/10. this is the best sequel of the whole series.X,3,2,1,4,6,7,9,8,5 in order!
Most people think of Jason X as Friday the 13th in space. It is. Made to capitalize on the sci-fi craze of the late 1990s and early 2000s, this film, the tenth in the franchise, sucks.

reviews.review_title: Without doubt the best of all the sequels...
reviews.content: I left the cinema after watching Jason X in stitches. Having seen nearly all of the Friday the 13th series and been more and more disappointed with the efforts of each it was fantastic to see a film take itself so lightly. As usual there was a fair amount of gore and teenage lust but the script has some, without trying to sound clichéd, killer jokes. The acting left a lot to be desired but this has come to be expected with this particular slasher series. The story is based around the context that Jason has been frozen in cryogenic stasis while the world around him has fallen to pieces and mankind has deserted the earth. That of course doesn't stop some meddling students on an interstellar field trip finding and defrosting him. Great idea kids! The result is a fiendishly funny and not entirely unscary film. It has its moments of corny dialogue (man falls on top of giant screw and twists down it - "he's screwed" is the line) but this is offset by some laugh out loud jokes. One especially good one is near the end so hang around even if your not enjoying it. I can only recommend this film to anyone looking for good solid entertainment and a film that takes itself lightly.

reviews.review_title: It's a good film to sit down in front of and switch off your brain for a bit.
reviews.content: There have been a lot of negative comments about this film, but honestly, what do people expect of a tenth installment? The Jason Vorhees movies continue not because they're good, but because they are a tried and tested formula - blood, mayhem and gore. There's no deep meaning here. It's just more of the same.If you go into this movie expecting anything other than silliness and blood-splattering, you'll hate it. On the other hand if, like me, you expected it to be diabolically bad, then you'll be pleasantly surprised.Of course it's throw-away rubbish, but it knows it's crap, and pokes fun at itself. And for that reason it's a good film to sit down in front of and switch off your brain for a bit and have a laugh.Apart from the original movie I can only recall seeing part of one of the intervening series of films - some nonsense with Jason on a boat. So I can't comment on whether it's better or worse than the others. Even my memory of the original is hazy now. But this episode is not too bad.The best bit is the android girl who gets "reprogrammed" by her creator/would-be-lover into a killing machine. Up to that point she was mildly uninteresting, as all the characters are. After that, I was rooting for her the rest of the film. The others are fairly bland and die in an assortment of ways, some more amusing than others.There's some hokum about how Jason keeps going and why he regenerates etc. but it's just added fluff to the carnage. There's also the obligatory sexual scene, but it's tame and light.Not very good, but for a tenth movie of a franchise, it holds up quite well.

Jason X (2001) is bad, but you can watch it because it is entertainingly bad. You can also watch this movie for Jason going around killing people in a space station in brutal and impossible ways that makes it funny but cool to watch.The acting is bad, and the characters make a lot of dumb decisions that gets themselves killed, while also acting stupid in general. How Jason gets on a space station in the future is interesting and the way it looks by the 3rd act of the movie is interesting.Jason is cool and kills people in impossibly brutal ways that can make you laugh from time to time, while also doing things that make no sense. How the characters act, how Jason kills people, and how shots are put together is funny to watch.Jason X (2001) will be entertaining to watch for people who like this franchise, even if this movie is not good. You can have fun with this movie, even if it is not one of the best on Friday the 13th franchise.

The plot of the movie was very interesting, but silly. The location was very nice, way different than the other locations. The kills were so good, gladly they were onscreen. The storyline was kinda stupid, but I don't care at all. It was a very intense movie. The graphics weren't very nice, but nice try. In my opinion, they should stop making Friday the 13th movies, because it kinda gets very boring and annoying the whole Jason thing. I mean, just die. It's not realistic at all.

reviews.review_title: Oh my god! This movie rocked!
reviews.content: I just went to see Jason X at the Movieplex and it was awesome! After months of waiting, It lived up to my every expection, and then some!!! Okay now to the story:After unsucessfuly trying to kill Jason, they deciede to freeze him. But something goes wrong and a woman freezes to. 400 hundred years later, space people find them and bring them to their ship and let them thaw out.Very creative killings, the upgrade scene made sence, overall great movie   10/10

reviews.review_title: I would support and cheer for Jason if he took on the Addams Family!
reviews.content: The saddest comment on this tenth installment of a cinematic INSTITUTION is that in ran in Sydney for just 6 working days - that is simply pathetic!!!! As one reviewer so aptly commented, Jason X is to the FRIDAY 13TH franchise what BRIDE OF CHUCKY was to the CHUCKY series! OK...granted - this was no masterpiece but hey, for any serious devotee of the Jason culture - this offers so much! terrific one-liners, a marvellous virtual Camp Crystal Lake sequence and with Kane Hodder behind the mask - the definitive Jason! (His fourth outing I believe!) Jason in space is no dumber than his last re-invention....as an alien parasite in JASON GOES TO HELL: THE FINAL FRIDAY - and ludicrous and misplaced as THAT was...I was entertained!JASON X was originally conceived as a JASON vs FREDDIE slasher epic, but somewhere in the legal logistics they couldn't get their act together and thus Jason found himself alone in a cryogenic chamber and ultimately helming his own little blood-letting space odyssey! If you have any awareness at all, you will get a lot out of this film - don't look at it on the surface...that was never the makers' intent!I was bitterly disappointed to have to watch this tenth outing..more than one year late in its Australian release, in the company of less than 5 people recently! The film had NO advance publicity, no critical coverage and basically no media advertising of any description! Its "failure" was carefully orchestrated. Got news for you people, they've been trying to "kill off Jason" for almost a generation...its gonna take more than your contribution, believe me.  Jason will ALWAYS live!

Jason X is one of the more entertaining Friday the 13th sequels, but that doesn't make it any less terrible or stupid. I do like how they just kind of gave up and made the characters say stupidly hilarious things, but it loses all those points from the abhorrent CGI, awful acting, idiotic characters, and an overall ridiculous plot. (Seriously though, they gave up big time. Like they didn't try at all). I'd complain about how the never explain how they didn't explain how they got Jason back from hell, but I don't really care at this point. If you need something in the background, then this is the perfect movie for you.

What more can I say, this was a great Jason movie. He is the ultimate horror movie slasher. This is the best Jason incarnation since part 7 (New Blood). Kane Hodder is great what he does. I suggest if you are even a remote fan of the series to rent this one when it comes out. There are some interesting kills and a very good change with our main title killer.

reviews.review_title: Is the 'Jason' franchise beyond a joke?! Apparently not!
reviews.content: Thanks to "Scream", we live in an age where post-modern horror is now the 'de-rigeur' thing; and your franchise is nowhere unless you have at least ONE entry that follows such a pattern. (Think "Freddy" & Chucky"... ) So comes 'Jason X'; and it's clear from the start that there's nothing at all here that was meant to be taken seriously. This is an episode definitely NOT above chucking in liberal doses of humour to go along with the required entrails and thus hopefully swell the studio coffers. You know what? I prefer it this way, too! Staunch devotees may find themselves disagreeing with me, but this is a welcome new direction for Mr. Voorhees; and the knowing chuckles combined with lots and lots of blood turn what could have been yet another painful slog into a fun send-up of horror clichés past - and indeed, tired plot-elements in general...I'd rather they go for the funny-bone where the Fridays are concerned; since I can't honestly say I had all that much affection for them in the first place; unlike in the cases of Child's Play and A Nightmare on Elm Street. It's been proved that the former AND the latter are perfectly suited to 'seriousness'; whereas I've ALWAYS struggled to take Jason seriously as anything more than a cheap Michael Myers knockoff, right from the start - so this could be his 'niche'... !!! The movie finds time to use its future setting cleverly; exploiting the possibilities both for elaborate deaths, and indeed, the 'post-modern wit' earlier described... A clever use of virtual-reality in particular to ensnare Jason provides a fun projection of how people might look back on the saga as a whole, in our OWN distant future! The props may have gone a little more 'space-age' (if perhaps, no less 'cheap-looking'... !) but it's nice to see that underneath the new exterior there is still retained a certain element of people lurking behind props in the haunted house, waiting to go "Boo"... ! 'Terror' is quite a simple reflex-mechanism to engender, if you think about it; and most of the old values are happily not lost, even though the surroundings were deemed in need of an 'upgrade'...Judging on "Resurrection", the 'Halloween' series ought to think seriously about the option of gravitating toward INTENTIONAL laughs, too... Yes, this film features pretty amateur surgeons in sheer cutoff tops; but what the heck is wrong with that, when the dominant tone is one of tongue-in-cheek spoofery???! Traversing the comedic route has effectively resuscitated this series more effectively than a bolt of lightning EVER did... If people can't hear you 'scream' in space, they might be able to hear you chortle, at least... ! (Yes, there are SEVERAL references to the 'Alien' franchise in the actual movie, as well!)
This is total garbage and should have never been made. Looks like film makers are tapping a dry well. STOP THE STUPID JASON CRAP AND LET IT DIE.

reviews.review_title: Lots of fluff and NOT scary.
reviews.content: I saw this movie because my friend kept saying how awesome it should be. Well, this movie combines elements from Star Trek (Next Generation), American Pie and all the other Jason movies.  The fact that Jason's "upgrade" was aggravating.  You see, Jason was only enhanced for about 10 percent of the movie.  For the entire other 90 percent he was like the old Jason.  Also, there were these ANTS that could regenerate wounds and heal. What made me mad was that these ants enhanced Jason but they didn't repair any of Jason's victims.  What's up with THAT?  That infuriated me!  So many plot holes.  Why are their nothing but American Pie hot chicks on this "space ship"?  That was lame.  Even the band girl from American Pie was in this movie.  Her death was the grossest.  She was sucked through a vent due to a hole in the spaceship that made all the air go out into space.  There were other gross killings.  One guy was impaled on a screw (giant).  When one of crew asks what this guys condition is, the reply is "he's screwed". How NOT funny.  There was even an ANDROID that somehow manages to do the MOST damage to Jason.  This ANDROID was kind of like DATA!!  She yearned to "become human."  Can you say, RIP OFF OF STAR TREK!?  Of course, there is the tough black sergeant who resembles the Candyman.  He's all tough and says some really stupid lines.  I hated this movie.  What made it worse was that everybody in the theater was hysterically laughing.  That's BAD MOVIE EDIKIT!  I would suggest seeing this if you want to see a bad movie, other than that, stick to the BEST one.  Friday the 13th part 2!

reviews.review_title: Jason, why don´t you just be a good boy and die! PLEASE!!!!
reviews.content: Sometime ago I was actually thinking about watching all the Friday the 13th movies in order they were released, but after seeing Jason X I changed my mind. Never again am I going to pay to see crap like this.I rented Jason X fully aware of the fact that it´s a stupid "horror" movie. I just thought I might take it as a comedy and that way it could be entertaining. I was so wrong. Jason X is a horrible movie and it´s not even scary. You know those Teletubbies? Now those guys are really scary! In one of my nightmares I run into them on a dark street and then I wake up screaming. But this Jason Voorhees does nothing to me. A 5-year old kid would be scared of him, but come on, the whole Jason myth is just plain stupid. How many times has he been killed? Some weirdos seem to get their kicks watching Jason slaughtering young people, but any normal human being should find it sick. The whole Friday the 13th series just shows that all that the film makers want is just money from the freak fans who obviously exist. I believe this was the 10th movie in the series and I´ve read that all the parts are all the same: Jason somehow comes back to life and starts killing. This just goes out to prove the stupidity of people and film makers.Jason X should be buried as deep as possible and left there. On the other hand the movie is such waste that it  might not even decay. Still, it´s our job to take care of the garbage so that the next generations don´t have to suffer the way we did.As a final note I´d like to say that someone please kill that goddamn Jason or put all the film makers responsible behind the bars.

What can I say, Friday the 13th just does whatever and the fans suck it up. Where most franchises die once the go to "space" Jason got an upload. I don't care who you are this movie is totally fun. Friday the 13th has never tried to be anything more than fun, something to show to your friends while partying. It always comes through with kills and...well kills, Jason is the master of that. Love the first 10 minutes, by that point you know Jason was back and time to sit back and watch the blood flow, the movie delivers. It delivers on the fact that Jason kills, that's what you pay for that's what you get. For all these negative comments, I would think by part 10 if you didn't like Jason please just don't watch.

reviews.review_title: Pretty great for the 10th film in this series
reviews.content: Jason falls into the "Futurama" trap of falling into a cryogenic chamber, but he gets the last laugh when he jabs his machete through the wall, stabbing the woman who trapped him and freezing her in the process. They are discovered 455 years in the future by a science-teaching-kind-of-spaceship, and jetted off into space. (The Earth is a desolate wasteland, so clearly we didn't recycle enough.) They revive the woman, but assume Jason is dead and just poke him with sharp things and cut off his mask. Big mistake.Jason revives and starts killing scantily-clad space students. The marines are sent in to get him, and this briefly becomes an Alien-with-Jason flick. He dispatches them all and the remaining students, their teacher, the woman from the past, a surviving marine and a Ninja-S&M robot have to take him on.I thought this was going to be awful, and the first act kind of confirmed that. Although David Cronenberg pops up and gets killed by Jason (truly a horror hall of fame moment), most of what happens is a bit stilted and the effects are awful. But once Jason dispatches the marines and the real plot kicks in, this really one of the best films in this series. It manages to fulfill the formulaic expectations you have for the series while injecting some fresh elements and being genuinely funny at times. It also has some of the more inventively gory kills in the series (a special call out to the guy impaled on a giant screw that lazily keeps spinning and drifts all the way down).This film has a souped-up nanobot powered cyber Jason in the last act.Jason is distracted by a hologram projection of two topless camper chicks in sleeping bags.Yes.

reviews.review_title: I Loved It...Roll on Jason XI
reviews.content: I thought Jason X was great for so many reasons. A new premise, great actors and actresses and some truly bizarre killings. Jason X was top-notch.For starters, I liked the premise-Jason in space. Space really is the best place for a horror because there is absolutely no escape when you're right out there in space aboard a ship with a maniac on your tail. A lot of people I spoke to criticized the film being set in space but did we really want to see another film set in Crystal Lake?I liked the performances throughout and it was great to see Lisa Ryder and Lexa Doig (from Andromeda)together again. Ryder played Kay-Em 14 who was an android and she came out with some good lines. The film itself was quite comedic at times but that's not a bad thing.Mustn't forget the star of the show-Jason. Kane Hodder plays Jason again and once again does a brilliant job of making Jason Voorhees menacing.The killings are quite bizarre at times. I won't go into detail but they are quite strange especially Jason's first victim when he wakes up on the spaceship.All in all, Jason X was a great film in which the unstoppable killer hacked his way through victim after victim. I don't believe I'll ever tire of Jason particularly if Kane Hodder continues to play the part. I can't wait for Jason XI to be made!

reviews.review_title: For serious Friday fans only(minor spoilers)
reviews.content: The fan in me loved Jason X, but the critic in me hated. First let's start with the fna part. The film has nudity, great one liners and good death scenes that one would expect from a Friday film. Now the critic in me knows that h can pull a better film out of his a*s. The movie is horribly edited, the dialouge is horrible and the acting is very tepid. There's also no back story what so ever. See this one only if you're a serious Friday fan.

reviews.review_title: Someone should make a Jason vs Jar Jar Binks movie set against Alien Resurrection.
reviews.content:
Just saw Jason X . . . It is bad. No big surprise there. However, it is dull, dull, dull. Now, that is a shocker. I really didn't see much point in setting the movie 500 years in the future. Really, even with the decent sci-fi special effects, Jason X is a re-hash of every other Friday the 13th film. It doesn't capitalize upon its backdrop. In the end, the time period is little more than a gimmick.
The audience is promised something new and special. However, the flick doesn't deliver the goods. Instead of a fresh spin upon the series (think Wes Craven's New Nightmare or Bride of Chucky) Jason X is Friday the 13th parts 3,4,5,6 and Jason Goes to New York rolled into one movie.
The picture name drops and hints at other genre pictures (the likes of Alien and Solaris are referenced). Still, is that really all that clever?
Furthermore, the cast is loaded with aspiring young mannequins who fail to breath the smallest amount of life into the underwritten roles. Truthfully, halfway through Jason X, I could not even remember the names of the victims-in-waiting. Okay, I know that people go to these movies for the high body count. To be sure, Jason X delivers in this area. Well over 20 people meet their timely deaths in this film. Still, so many characters are sliced and diced, the proceedings become tedious after about 12 minutes. One scene places Jason inside a virtual reality simulation of Camp Crytal Lake, circa 1980. Finally (three quarters of the way through!!!) Jason X shows a genuine sense of humor. If the rest of the movie displayed the same spirit, it would be a winner. Instead, it rates a three out of ten.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as people say it is...
reviews.content: When a film series hits ten sequels, you know that the writing staff are just trying to hold onto any kind of meal ticket they possibly can, sure that nothing else they put together will bring home the bacon. After all, who can honestly look me in the eye and say that the tenth James Bond film (or any episode featuring Roger Moore) was anything other than an expensive stream of fire-lighters?It seems there are two schools of thought about Jason X as a result. There are the hardcore fans who seem to think that using the same basic plot over and over and over is a good thing despite the fact that this episode outgrossed its three most immediate predecessors put together. Then there are the people who have watched more than two dozen films in their lifetime, and are ready to recognise that sometimes a little variety is a good thing.Jason X distinguishes itself from the previous eight rehashes by adding a very basic, superficial sci-fi setting. This is the first good move, as one critic I normally violently disagree with has described the other eight films as "the ultimate in recycling - so much so that you forget which episode you are watching after a while". At least there is little chance of mistaking Jason X for episodes one through nine. There is also the element of digital photography. I would have loved to have seen this film theatrically, especially after the grainy, out of focus crap that George Lucas proclaimed as the future with his digital Star Wars. It would have been nice to see if digital photography truly is capable of delivering what its proponents claim. If the DVD-Video of Jason X is anything to go by, then George Lucas should be informed that he is doing more to hurt the digital revolution than help it.Anyway, I am not going to comment on the plot, since it has been done to death, and it appears that the American Butcher's Association has once again failed to recognise that adults watch films, too. The DVD-Video sold in Australia runs almost as long as the IMDB-quoted theatrical running time, which means that at least three and a half minutes of footage that was deleted from the USA theatrical exhibition is present on Australian home videos. About the only complaint that I have here is the Kay-Em droid, who really does more to annoy the audience and ruin the experience than add to anyone's enjoyment. Kane Hodder is in great form as the hockey-masked killer, however. Unlike the majority of people who have played Jason in the past, Hodder really looks the part of a demented woodsman who has grown up totally cut off from civilisation. Anyone who has any doubts about that should take a good look at some of the frontal shots of Uber-Jason. That guy really must have eaten his Wheaties as a boy. Such a pity that the MPAA butchered his first two appearances as Jason beyond recognition (a fact that is hilariously referenced in the illusion-campsite scene).In all, if you are into films, and not circular rehashes of the same old tired plot ad nauseum, then Jason X is for you. It's not the most creative thing you'll ever see, and it's not the best horror film on Earth, but the mere fact that they were brave enough to do something different and have a little bit of fun with it elevates the tenth Friday The 13th far above eight of its nine predecessors. I can see why they dumped the FT13 moniker, quite frankly.

*SOME SPOILERS AHEAD*I'm glad James Isaac, the director, decided to return to the B-movie formula after the disappointing "Jason Goes to Hell," which was simply a failed A-movie effort.  Now, the acting, storyline and dialogue are definitely in perfect B-movie tradition, but the directing and production design were quite impressive.  I loved the color schemes and use of the digital camera, which was then transferred onto film.  I loved the digital look of the film, it's almost flawless.  And though the special f/x were obviously generated by computers, they also looked pretty cool.  OK, so we got ourselves another screwy idea of how to bring Jason back to life, but heck...we love Jason so much that we can't stand to see him go. What makes "Jason X" so much fun to watch is that there's no pretentions. This is pure camp and doesn't try to be any more than pure camp, and it simply takes the genre of camp slasher flick and runs with it as far as it can.  This tenth (I'm not quite sure if I can call it the final) chapter contains a lot more humor than the previous sequels.  Most of the sequels did contain a certain degree of humor, but this one takes the cake.  There are many funny scenes and lines of dialogue, including one where one of the female victims is about to die and her last words are "This sucks on so many levels."  Another funny line occurs when the big black guy got stabbed in the ribs by Jason.  He says, "It'll take more than a poke in the ribs to kill me."  After Jason stabs him again, he says, "That'll do."  You can call this movie weird, you can call it insane, but you gotta give it points for originality.  Of course, in great B-movie tradition, all the female characters look like they leaped straight out of the pages of "Playboy" or "Penthouse."  Even the scientist, who gets frozen along with Jason, is hot as hell.  Though most of these chicks don't get naked, at least they run around in tight, skimpy clothing.  As I've said in past reviews, most of the people watching these flicks are guys, so you may as well appeal to the general demographic.  I just wish that gloriously hot blonde chick in the beginning didn't get killed off so early and died of such ugly death--her face frozen and smashed into pieces.  As far as the nudity factor goes, at least I got my wish at the near end of the film, when those two hot babes stripped off their tops. It kinda sucks that there was only brief nudity, but it's definitely a scene worth fast-forwarding to and rewinding over and over again. 
The most entertaining scene in the movie is when the victims are all cornered by Jason and don't know what the hell to do, until the robotic woman pops up like a warrior, in a scant leather outfit, holding a machine gun.  You can't help but cheer on the top of your lungs when that scene comes up.  If you're a movie critic, you can pick apart this movie in many ways, but its flaws are what charmed me about the film.  The acting is bad, but it was bad to the extent where it made me smile (rather than cringe).  The dialogue is also bad, but it made me laugh, and it sort of parodies the cheesy lines we hear in many trashy horror flicks.  Cool death scenes, hot chicks, great moments of humor, one great nude scene. What more can I ask for?  I'm not quite sure, but I felt the movie was missing something, which prevented it from making it any more than a slightly above-average film--at least in my opinion.  There was a certain aura of dullness to it, though I still had a good deal of fun. Nevertheless, it's definitely worth watching and worth renting on DVD (there's a great commentary and a great documentary about the Jason flicks). You pretty much have nothing to lose.  But I really wish they could've played "Let the Bodies Hit the Floor" somewhere in the film, because it sounded awesome in the trailer.  Once again, I must say:  Stop playing music in trailers if it's not gonna be in the film!  My score:  6 (out of 10)

reviews.review_title: Not the Worst Movie - Pretty Good
reviews.content: Okay Okay, so its not the best movie either, but its a good idea to add to the Friday The 13th Series. Jason is cryogenic-ally frozen from 2010 - 2455. And is eventually found and taken on board a spaceship along with a Female Research Assistant who was accidentally frozen with him. He wakes up and starts going on a killing spree. The movie does have some weak spots along with some horrible clichéd sentences,and not the best acting,the characters are seriously stupid and goofy-like who think that the best time to crack a joke is when they're dying. But i did like the idea of Jason becoming half Metal- man towards the end, But the writers could have made that more special by putting a bit more effort into the acting if they cared at all about Jason. The movie has lots of blood and gore and Jason hacking up lots of people, So isn't that what everyone wants?However the Movie could have been made a lot better..
Man, the best horror movie right here!Jason Vorhees thank you bruhhh.

It's interesting reading up on the film rights disputes, that have been going on between Paramount Pictures and New Line Cinema these days. That's why you haven't seen a Jason Vorhees movie since 2009. They are still fighting over, who actually has the right to make another Friday the 13th movie. So, Jason continues to sit in creative limbo here in the 21st century, until that all gets figured out. So, getting back to this film, New Line Cinema brought Jason back, completely ignoring their plotline from the previous film, Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday (1993) and try to pull off a reboot, of sorts.It has been eight years since we last saw Jason Vorhees in the theaters. A lot may have happened to him, off camera, since the last film. The events in this film happen after the year 2008, then we jump 450 years into the future. We start up in the beginning of this film, where Jason is shackled away in a Crystal Lake Research Facility (boy Crystal Lake has grown a lot since 1979). Scientist realize he can't be killed. His recuperative abilities are a mystery. He is slated for cryogenic suspension, in order to get rid of him forever. He doesn't seem to be the worse for wear. He's not even his old disfigured self anymore either. He has his hockey mask back too.A horrible group of characters inhabit the futuristic research vessel, that Jason ends up on. What is really hilarious about the whole set-up, are half of the crew look like teenage camp counselors. That is the producers of the film, sticking to a Jason Vorhees staple. All the characters deliver bad dialogue and silly one-liners. There is nothing but tired plot scenarios and scenes that are not needed. There is one funny scene, in which Jason meets two women in a camp site hologram. The science fiction part of the plot, totally gives off a Star Trek vibe. This is definitely Jason's biggest death toll in one of his films.On the good side, Jason X (2001), does however, have that feeling of being like an old Roger Corman, science fiction movie from the 1970s. That doesn't save it from being a joke however. The plot gets a little tiring and the end seems to never come. Jason just keeps coming back for more, as a grade D, Star Trek episode, unfolds in front of us. Jason's essence even takes over the ship's computer in a ridiculous plot-twist. Eventually, the story goes from Star Trek to Space Balls. It just feels a little bit too comic-bookish. I wanted to put this film on my Unwatchable List, but you have to see this film to believe it. The film is still a failure, but I still think it was a brave attempt to take a tired IP and try to do something different with it. You also are treated to a David Cronenberg sighting. The legendary science fiction/horror director, plays the role of Dr. Wimmer. That's worth it I think.3.3 (F- MyGrade) = 4 IMDB.

reviews.review_title: This sucks in so many levels
reviews.content: Now all we need is bride of Jason and the stupid will be completeSeriously: slashers are stupid. This slasher series was always stupid (the first one was servicable) and never took any chances and I'm so sick of villains that don't die. At least the final chapter and a new beginning changed things up. This movie is worse than those. Yes I said it.

The bad sequels keep on rolling. Friday the 13th needed to stop beating a dead horse at seven and let it rest in peace. Yet some genius at New Line thought it would be a great idea to send him into the future of all places on a space station. Who would watch the first couple in the series and think it would ever come to this or would want it to? Jason has been captured by the government to be frozen since he wont die nor will this series and before this can happen the military wants custody to study his regeneration ability. If this is the case then how did he stay dead or look so rotted and needed to possess bodies? They just weren't trying anymore.Jason gets lose, everyone dies, except one woman who is able to trap him and they both are frozen in cryogenics until visited by students on a field trip to see what earth is like. I kid you not. They took the thin plot of episode 8, set it in the future and had them take a cruise with Jason in space. Recycled plot disguised as a new refreshing idea. Who are they kidding? I thought some of the future technology was fascinating and cool. Star trek fans will enjoy it. But it becomes a cartoon by robot girl who transforms into a dominatrix terminator who tries to save her creator from Jason. Danger Will Robertson anyone? Uber Jason seemed like a cool idea on paper, but he doesn't seem different or stronger then his normal attire and thus a wasted opportunity. He does survive the heat from earth's two's atmosphere and lands in his new home in the lake. I know these aren't suppose to be works of art or high class entertainment. But this doesn't excuse the poor story telling. 0 out of ten.

Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder's 4th and so far final appearance sadly) is finally captured and about to be frozen as a means of dealing with him, but then David Cronenberg (famed horror director and master of the 1986 remake of "The Fly") shows up and tries to get Jason off the freezing so he can profit off Jason, only to get killed. This leaves the beautiful brunette scientist gal to try to freeze Jason and gets herself frozen along with him. Centuries later, long after Earth is in ruins and the human race located to another planet (Earth 2!), the science girl and Jason are thawed out by a college expedition and before long (right after two of the students have sex) Jason wakes up and goes on the rampage!And then, just when they thought they had killed Jason, he becomes... Uber-Jason!Okay it's not brilliant (sort of cheap looking actually) but it must be hard to keep an old franchise interesting by the tenth entry. Well, watch it for the intentional and unintentional hilarity.

I don't get the bad reviews. For me this was beautifully over the top, non-stop entertainment. People need to watch it with their tongue firmly in their cheek. I think they should have included 'comedy' in their tags, as it obviously, intentionally is. For me this movie worked on every level, there really isn't a slow scene in the entire movie. Definitely worth a watch.

reviews.review_title: Once again a horror villian in space
reviews.content: Another day, another well known horror character thrown into a unfunny, lazy, poorly edited, and laughable cast in space for a quick cash grab. Of course, Kane Hodder gives a truly outstanding final live action performance as Crystal Lake's favorite serial killer. However, the most appaling part of the film is the lazy climax that sees Jason get over 9000'd into Earth 2, with an open possibilty for a sequel that never happened.

reviews.review_title: Fun and refreshing Demolition Man spin
reviews.content: Fun and refreshing Demolition Man spin. The world and universe change, but Jason stays the same. I think it was a worthwhile addition, a part of me thinks the future time line gives the series a more epic canvas!

I honestly expected to enjoy this movie. People either say that this film is a campy blast or that it is one of, if not the worst of the franchise. Knowing that I enjoy campy horror movies done right, I assumed that this would be fun. Oh boy, was I wrong.Jason X has a few laughs, such as the "we love premarital sex!" line, but that is hardly enough to save it. At the end of the day, it is a dumb movie with bad acting, forgettable characters, and nowhere near enough fun kills to save it. However, the frozen head kill might be my favorite of the franchise. Fortunately for Jason, this was an improvement over the previous two movies in the Friday the 13th franchise.Rating: F, bad.

Jason should have died in Part 9. "Jason Goes to Hell" was the best and most thrilling of the entire series. The idea that Jason is brought back by freezing, is either WAY over-done, or has at least drained every idea possible. The end of Jason is here. End of story. If there are any others made, it might be wise to chop up the creators with a machete.This is the most ridiculous installment ever. I don't even know if it's any better than part 7 or not. Both ideas- psychic powers and reanimation two-three hundred years later are both stupid and desperate ideas. I can't believe that this one even made it to DVD....What a sickening ending to the series. It's just a shame...Part Nine was so, SOOOO much better, and SUCH a better ending... What a disappointment and a disgrace...Well, at least it lasted for ten films. Woot. Congratulations, I guess.

reviews.review_title: Daft gore story where Jason goes into Space
reviews.content: SPOILERSOnce upon a time there was a group of classic horror films which brought the genre back to the masses. With films like "A Nightmare On Elm Street", "Halloween" and "Friday The 13th" we were given some dark, slightly scary films which were based on the art of disturbing the audience and giving them nightmares. Eventually however, these series degraded into films where the established main characters would not be scary, but they'd kill larger numbers of people in much more extreme ways. This new take on the idea might not have been as intelligent an idea, but with films like "Jason X", they were incredibly entertaining and definitely worth a look.Set in the 25th century, Jason Voorhees has been cryogenically frozen and resurrected in the future. Faced with a fresh group of teenagers and money grabbing adults, Voorhees will once again grab his machete and create carnage.Basically this film is a simple opportunity to grab Mr Voorhees and place him in space. Any sort of surrounding plot is irrelevant and rather pointless. Despite being 500 years in the future, the teenagers continue to be sex obsessed, playful and one remains stoned. The only real difference between future teenagers and ones from previous modern films is that they are now living in space and don't understand certain phrases. In effect, there is nothing new to this film, but there's no reason why we shouldn't enjoy it."Jason X" is your typical violent, gore filled story and is ridiculously daft as well. With absolutely no plot, the idea of this film is that it's so that Voorhees can travel around and cut people up in extreme ways. It's not a decent story and it's not clever, but "Jason X" is still ridiculously entertaining. With some extreme deaths and some cracking lines, this film is just good fun. Watching Jason killing people should never be entertaining, but it just really works. It's not brilliant, but ultimately who cares, it's just a good laugh.

Jason X (Friday the 13th Part 10) was a rather okay movie, but was just....... well just to "out there" if you know what I mean. I can't believe they have made ten Friday the 13th movies already. I now discovered they are coming with Part 11: Jason Vs. Freddy Krueger. Oh my gosh! What is New Line Cinema thinking??? I hope they stop on the 13th sequel at least. That should be the finale. Jason X's plot was okay, but some of this acting was bluuuuuuuuugh. This movie was okay. I give Jason X a 7 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Body count was way too big!
reviews.content:
The best thing about the DVD of JASON X is that it gives one of the best documentaries on horror films ever. "The Many Lives of Jason" is quite good. In it, Kane Hodder (the man who plays Jason) tells us that he kills 28 people in JASON X. Seven of them are killed in the first two and a half minutes. Now, after learning this, I was beginning to wonder if I should really watch the film. Because, films with that high of a body count, are usually pretty bad. Like the horrid, HALLOWEEN: THE CURSE OF MICHAEL MYERS where the killer just goes around killing people for no apparant reason. Now, I understand that that is what Jason is made to do. It's like his job. So, I understood this and took it into consideration while I was watching.
JASON X is a continuous murder fest. Which is good if you like people getting butchered every two seconds. I don't think there is a scene in this film where someone is not either getting killed or getting attacked. Most members of the cast are unknown, and a campy horror film of this sort usually has a heavy metal soundtrack, but I was disappointed to find out otherwise. But the film will still satisfy those of us who like a murdering rampage film will an extremely high body count. JASON X gets 3/5.

reviews.review_title: Good movie, was expecting a better script
reviews.content: I was glad to see a modern version of Jason. Although the special effects were great, it lacked a few elements like suspense and a solid script.I hope the next movie will be more serious. Until then I will have to settle for the DVD.

reviews.review_title: Kane Hodder makes this ridiculous set up work
reviews.content:
You have to be able to have fun with long time running horror franchises
Friday the 13 th is one of those and arguably the most chronologically messed up of the great sequel spewers
Halloween
NOES
PHANTASM
CHILDS PLAY
TEXAS CHAINSAW.....Jason in space,,, in the future??? Why the hell not?Friday the 13th, part 10........ awesome!!Part six is still the best, but X is underloved.

reviews.review_title: Jason spreads the terror on board of a spaceship...
reviews.content: As well as "Jason Goes To Hell: The Final Friday" this movie has no direct connection to the series. It's not as bad as that film but it's not far better though. This time the "improvement" in JASON saga was to send him to the year 2455, creating a SCI-FI movie that related to Friday THE 13TH has the JASON figure and not much else. One of the few details I really appreciated in this film was this "future JASON" which appears in the last 20 minutes, with a futuristic mask and steel armor.As many people say the series is only genuine until part IV, since then it's just a bunch of "artificial reinterpretations". Now that I already watched all the ten titles I can say that from part IV we can only save Part V and VIII in my perspective, all the rest is pure trash.

Of the countless Jason movies I've only seen 2, the original Friday the 13th ( the one with Kevin Bacon in ) and this Jason in Space as I call it. This one I really like because it differs from the rest because of where it's set.The cast of characters are still as dopey, even though it's set over 400 years in the future. Jason is found frozen as is Rowan (Lexa Doig), they bring both back to life and before you know it Jason is killing dafties by the score. Rowan warns the staff on the ship about Jason, but she'd have been better speaking in Serbo-Croat because Professor Lowe is only interested in the money he'll receive for bringing Jason back to his employees, alas he'll not be seeing any money as he's soon bumped off along with most of the tough marine types. This leaves only Rowan, some students, Tsunaron and his modifies android Kay-Em 14 ( Lisa Ryder).Kay-Em is probably the best character in the movie, followed by the feisty Janessa (Melyssa Ade) and Tsunaron (Chuch Campbell). Some great thrills in the film especially with Uber Kay-Em and Uber Jason, and plenty of gory deaths. But this is more of a SciFI movie than a stand alone horror film, and is all the better for it. I enjoyed it.

reviews.review_title: In space only Jason can hear you scream!
reviews.content: The tenth movie in the long running Friday the 13th series, Jason X took the series in a very different direction by putting Jason Voorhees into space aswell as four hundred years into the future where humanity now lives on earth 2 where the teenagers are still just horny idiots just waiting for Jason to kill them.Jason X is exactly the movie you expect it to be an over the top slasher movie that doesn't take itself too seriously giving it's audience exactly what they asked for an entertaining slasher movie that's just an hour and a half of Jason Voorhees killing various people in bloody entertaining ways. The special effects while dated by today's standards were actually pretty decent for a low budget slasher movie made in the early 2000s.The idea of putting Jason Voorhees in space is as crazy and silly as it sounds. This is probably the least serious entry in the Friday the 13th series to date and that's in a movie series that has had some very odd entry's which have included a copycat Jason Voorhees killer, followed by the resurrection of Jason that essentially made him an unkillable zombie, then a movie where Jason fights a girl with telekinetic powers, then Jason went to Manhattan where toxic waste turned him back into a child which was ignored in the next movie where Jason dies but comes back once again as a body snatcher creature which ends with him being sent to hell with Freddy Kreuger, after all that it's no surprise Jason went to space it's the next logical step in a series as crazy as this one.Jason X was released in 2001 but was actually filmed in 1999 and was first released in Germany in the year 2000 before it was finally released in the US in 2001. The movie was made during the Matrix craze era of the early 2000s when every movie was trying to get in on the science fiction craze brought about by the success of The Matrix.I recommend Jason X if your a fan of old school slasher movies that focus more on the death scenes and special effects it's fun, bloody and entertaining like a Jason movie should be.

reviews.review_title: Not the worst of the series...really!
reviews.content:
I have to respectfuly disagree with robocoptng986127, who has obviously put a lot of effort into summarizing the whole movie, though there are several errors in the details of his summary.This entry in the series has to be given some credit in certain areas:First, this film escapes the normal confines of the series as far as locale and takes good advantage of the new setting(s). It demonstrates at least SOME imagination.Second, the film does not take itself as seriously as some of its predecessors. The script has some great repartee and you almost expect the actors to be winking at each other when they deliver their lines.Third, the characters may not be distinguishable from those in previous movies, but they are at least distinguishable from each other.Overall, I found this movie to be a lot more watchable than "Jason's III - IX" and would place it as the second or third best effort.
I mean, this is a "Jason" movie, for God's sake...not "Last Year at Marienbad".

I wasn't expecting much from Jason X.  I made that decision based on the last 2 Friday movies - Manhattan and Jason Goes To Hell but Jason X has to be one of my top 5 favorite Friday's.  It appeals to the old school as well as the new school fans and it also pokes some fun at the Friday series as a whole, which is totally cool.  There were some cheesy jokes but what would a Friday the 13th be without them!!  Definitely worth seeing!!

Jason X, known as Friday the 13th part 10, i thought that this was a good movie, this one was set in 2455, Jason is back after lots and lots of years with victims he killed and people who tried to kill him, but they all failed. Now with over 200 victims that lost their lifes, Jason i think has got to be known as the cerial killer who killed the most victims. Now he is ready to kill more. I give this movie 10 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Better than many of the previous Friday the 13th films!
reviews.content: No, I'm not going to sit here and try to defend the film.  Yeah, it was a terrible film, it really was.  But I've got to say it wasn't nearly as bad as most of the previous Friday the 13th films.  This one at least has some originality to it.  I agree is was a bit of a stretch to have Jason Vorhees in space, but at least it opened some doors for some interesting and futuristic deaths, weapons, characters and what not.  I can't believe people would say this one was worse than the previous 7 films, they're all just different ways of telling the same story and virtually nothing new to look at!  At least this one was an interesting change of scenery.The acting was nothing to get excited about, but c'mon, it's the 10th movie in a horror series, what can you expect?  Besides, the movie doesn't require good acting, I'm not watching this film for acting talent.On the upside, the women in the film were very good looking.  Virtually every female in the cast was very attractive and quite nice on the eyes.Also, a lot of people said that the special effects weren't very good.  Well no, they aren't very good compared to "The Matrix" or "Jurassic Park", but for a Jason film, they were pretty darn good.  I was personally very impressed with the special effects, I'm sure the budget was pretty small for this film and somehow they pulled off some pretty good special effects. Also, before I forget, I really liked the opening title sequence in the film.  Very well done (MUCH better than ANY of the previous Friday the 13th films).The dialogue in the film was really bad, with a number of moments that just make you want to cringe because you can't believe how stupid the lines are.The whole Uber-Jason thing was stupid as all hell!  Why did they do that? Ok, I can understand the machine that fixes humans actually putting Jason back together, but why would it make him better than before?  And why, oh why, would it create a new hockey mask for him and make his whole right side out of metal?  I cannot even begin to express how stupid that is!  That aside...the make up effects were actually pretty impressive and well done.No, I wouldn't recommend this film to just anyone, but if you are a Jason fan, go ahead and watch it.  ...And if you are just a mediocre Jason fan and a sci-fi fan, then go ahead and check this one out.  In all honesty, you don't need to watch any of the previous films to understand what's going on here (it might even be better if you don't).  Although, it might be nice to watch the first two films, and they may shed some light on subject.  If, you do choose to see this film, I hope you enjoy it.  Thanks for reading,-Chris

reviews.review_title: If you were a true horror fan.....
reviews.content: Okay, I am sick of those 90 slasher films (I know what you did...scream....you get the point).  If ANY of you people were actually true horror fans you would give this film credit.  I want more movies like this to exist.  I hate movies where the killers are human.  That kind of scenerio is a joke!  Please support this movie and go see it so they will make a Freddy VS. Jason before Robert Englund croaks.  They won't make a Freddy VS. Jason movie if this film bombs at the box office.  I'm sure everyone can spare 2 hours of their precious time and 10.00 bucks to go see this.  I hate the whole space thing also; however, I will atleast give it a try.  If you can, wait a week or two after opening weekend; thus, horror movies do well opening weekenend then drop.  Look how well Scream did at the box office and how they soaked that franchise for everything.  I'd much rather have Jason soak up the money instead.

Sometimes long pumped out horror franchises head to space, like Leprechaun and Hellraiser, and the distinguished Jason couldn't escape it either. Finally, this is the last Friday-the-13th related movie I haven't seen. Low hopes and some excitement for a decent body rack was what I went in with. So, 25th century has the people living on Earth 2, but a single greedy doctor's and his uncannily 20th-century-alike flock of students exploration ship has just picked up a valuable relic on Earth 1. Guess one time. The plot is essentialy "Alien", just replace the xenomorph with Jason. Most of "Jason X" is what you would expect, a loud, glorious, stoopid mess, full of shiny and uninspired sets, completed with digital violence taking over practical effects, and a costume design that raises eyebrows. Protagonist characters are very cliché, not the smartest bunch and are very expendable, which Jason continuously makes sure of. My biggest complaint, really, is not enough diversity in the kills and gore section, or the stuff that could compensate for the overall silliness. Other than that, "Jason X" is a reasonably self-aware flick that spends almost all of its time racking up body count, sometimes so monotonously that boredom is born. Here and there a joke is inserted. A spoof on the franchise itself, the entire slasher genre? Maybe, but what does it change. If nothing else, it's at least entertaining. 4/10.

First of all, anyone going to this movie intending for a good scare, you're not going to get it, but this movie is worth the trip to the theaters.Don't be fooled by movie critics that get paid to watch movies and think they know everything about movies, but they only give thumbs up to foreign films and films that have Oscar winners; Jason X is a good film to take your mate to, but the movie is really not to be taken seriously for any awards or breaking box office records.However, Jason X is a good film, regardless.  I have heard lots of critics that HAVEN'T EVEN WATCHED THE MOVIE bash the film, I will have to admit, I don't see why New Line would have Jason go to hell one installment and never explain how Jason comes back the next.Jason X is funny, exciting, and action-packed; however, it is NOT intended to be scary, but any fan of Jason knows this.  Friday the 13th and Jason films were never intended to be scary, but they were intended to be what it has been doing for 22 years, a good summer slasher film.I do have to question the Jason franchise, you have said that he died twice, but it seems that he just comes back.  I know in the sixth installment we find out how he does come back, but in Jason X, we never know how he comes back, he just comes back.  Funny how the devil doesn't want Jason around.If you're a fan of slasher films, you'll love it; if you're a Jason fan, you'll REALLY love it, if you're looking for a good film to spend some money on, you MAY like it, but one thing is for sure, you will walk out of the theater saying one word.  Sequel.

Roger Ebert in reviewing Master of Disguise described the film as `a party guest who thinks he's funny, but isn't and you just want him to go away.' That pretty much sums up my feelings on Jason X quite nicely.  It tries to be suspenseful in places, and isn't.  It tries to be funny, and fails. If they tried to make it scary, God did they ever fail.  They tried to make it cheesy, and God did they ever succeed.Like Friday the 13th VI: Jason lives, Jason X doesn't quite capture the blend of horror with comedy that other successful franchises have so classically attained.  Friday 13's humor always comes across as pointless extras that are severely out of place, or in other words, they don't know how to capture humor effectively while trying to maintain a horror atmosphere.  (Here's a Hint, guys: Talk to Sam Raimi and Bruce Campbell.)At least Jim Isaac and Tod Farmer (director & writer) tried to do something new with the dead formula (much like the makers of Jason Goes to Hell tried to do something new).  Like its predecessor, this entry attempts to combine multiple sci-fi genres, comic books heroes/villains, and change up the setting, and they take it a step further by giving Jason a new look. Guess what?  They fail on everything except the new look for Jason (too bad it's a new stupid look.)  I guess I'm not surprised since I didn't feel the original succeeded on anything other than making money, and if the so called 'original and best' in the series doesn't fair so well, then how can something derivative from it succeed?On a positive note, I'm happy to say after nine entries, veteran Friday the 13th composer Harry Manfridini created a score I actually enjoyed listening to while watching.  Granted, I'm not going to rush out and buy the thing any time soon, but it did not make me cringe and reach for the mute button like another entry . . .  Jason Lives.

Nostalgia pulled me back.  As it had with part nine.  I adored these films as a kid, where somehow, they always seemed to get it right sequel after sequel.  But since part 8, they have strayed from the format thinking it will work.  They are now 0 for 3.They stuck Jason on a boat.  Lousy.  They had his spirit body-hop.  Lousy. Now they stick him in the future up in space.  Lousy.  He and a crusader against him are frozen in time cryogenically and thawed out 400 some-odd years later.  The beginning time listed in the film is 2010.  Seeing how many times the release of the film was pushed back, maybe the filmmakers new how bad it was and anticipated a shelflife of several years.  Anyway, in 2455, a research-space crew discover the two human popsicles.  They thaw out the hot chick and think Jason is a lost cause.  But up he pops to start a standard mayhem.  Hey, ten films in and it gets hard to think up new ways to disect people.  They even brought back the writer of the original, Victor Miller, and not even he could come up with anything worthwhile 22 years later.  20 actually, according to the credits, this was completed in 2000 (remember how rushed these things were back in the 80s to make it to each summers slew of flicks?).  Here we get machete ad naseum, heads slammed about (something that really annoyed me in part 8) and, once again, the element that's bothered me about the last two films: tortuous deaths.  Big J used to pop out of the darkness and WAMMO you were dead.  A musical stinger, the audience jumps, and a quick flash of blood.  It was fun as hell.  Now, Jason drags his victims around or makes their deaths a lingering experience. The frozen face-smash was interesting, but mean-spirited.  Plus this thing goes on forever; lots of talk, and far too much money spent on the outer space effects.  Is this "Star Wars" or "F13"?  For a wonderfully fleeting moment things go back 20 years when Jason is "taken" back to Crystal Lake for a moment.  But it doesn't last, and they go for a stupid laugh as well. The ending is an endless barage of gunshot blasts, a lot coming from a cocky and very annoying android.  Then your usual set up for the next movie. Another disappointment is that they managed to get Manfredini back to do the music...and it's awful!  Only a few ch, ch, ch's and a lot of tv-movie type stuff (whistling flutes and dramatic build-ups).  Maybe by part 11 the music, the plot style, the murders, will finally revert back to the greatness of the earlier films.  And like a loyalist, I will be back as usual.

This movie is superb... I just don't know why people who give their review said that it's bad or because it's a sequel... I think that any movie, original or sequel, can be good! It's not just for money... it's for real fan who love it!... And if you're not a (real) fan, just don't see the movie... anyway, thanks to say what you think!

reviews.review_title: Kane Hodder still has what it takes as Jason.
reviews.content: Wow! A Friday film that is made for the fans! Jason is thawed out in the future and wrecks havoic on a spaceship! There are plenty of twists and turns and some truly horrific kills! Kane Hodder still has what it takes as Jason and this film must boast what i consider to be one of the most attractive Friday female casts ever! There is a great homage to Camp Crystal Lake and an upgrade to Jason that has to be seen to be believed! Anyways a great time at the movies! Hey Jason, glad to see you back!

reviews.review_title: It's been nine years since the last Jason movie hit theaters, and while Mr. Voorhees has been away we saw the rise and fall of the post-modern slasher movie.
reviews.content: Scream and I Know What You Did Last Summer showed there was new life in this sub-genre of horror, with their heroes and heroines a little smarter and wiser than the oversexed victims we saw in the first Friday the 13th and Halloween flicks. In fact, even the Halloween franchise got in on the post-modern act by having Jamie Lee Curtis return to face Michael Myers one last time in Halloween: H20 (well, until the forthcoming sequel, anyway.) So here we are in 2002 and now it's Jason's turn to get a reboot in Jason X, his tenth film and New Line Cinema's second with the character. I'll admit that I gave up watching Friday the 13th films after the third installment. I don't count myself as a big fan of this genre because I know Jason is gonna survive each film, no matter what happens. From speaking to friends and acquaintances who have seen all the Friday the 13th  movies out there, part of the appeal the Friday films offer to slasher fans is the fun in watching Jason off his prey in new and creative ways. For that reason alone fans of Jason will probably enjoy Jason X as it offers plenty of grisly kills that haven't been seen before. But does it offer anything else besides an impressive body count? After a cool opening credit sequence where the camera is inside Jason, we see the homicidal hockey mask wearing maniac has finally been captured and is being held in solitude. Rowan (Lexa Doig) doesn't want Dr. Wimmer to take Jason away from the secure facilities at the Crystal Lake Research Facility. Of course, Jason breaks free and offs everyone there except for our heroine who manages to freeze Jason (and herself) just before she has a date with the Grim Reaper. Time passes and 500 years later Earth is a forgotten wasteland. A group of visiting history students uncover the entombed Jason and Rowan, take them back into their spaceship and thaw them out. Now that the first act of the picture is out of the way, the carnage truly begins. As far as Friday the 13th films go, Jason X has some superior assets. The set design of the spaceship Grendel sure looks cool, and the visual FX by Toronto-based Toybox are pretty kick-ass all around (especially for one scene where soldiers play in a holodeck). The actors all do a good enough job given the material they're working with -- you know, have sex, scream, collect paycheck -- and the characters are likeable enough. Kane Hodder's Jason is, well, Jason and he does what one expects him to do when a big homicidal maniac wields a machete. Extra kudos are given to Lisa Ryder, who plays the android Kay-Em 14. Ryder's mechanical character comes across very different than her Andromeda starship captain role she's best known for, more subdued and likeable. I've read elsewhere that Jason X has by far the largest body count of any previous films, and that certainly gives an incentive for horror fans to go check it out. But... somewhere along the way I think Jason X veered left when it should have veered right. This should be a film that focused on capturing a wider audience, say people like me who fell away from the Friday the 13th series because, after awhile, every Friday movie seemed the same. While credit needs to be given to screenwriter Todd Farmer for going that extra step into the unknown and taking Jason off-planet and placing him into a sci-fi setting, I think Farmer needed to take the material that one extra and dangerous step further: into satire. Sam Raimi did this with Evil Dead II and the resulting fusion of horror and comedy paid off in a huge way. Evil Dead II is considered a classic by just about every horror fan, and I was hoping Jason X could utilize this approach to make Jason Voorhees' approach more appealing and less familiar. Farmer and director James Isaac try hamming it up in later scenes but by this time the tone of the movie has already been established, and the result are moments that should have been funny but instead you roll-your-eyes and groan out loud. Also following into the realm of missed opportunity was the chance to play with some sci-fi clichés we've all seen since the first Friday the 13th film came out more than 20 years ago.
