There are some in the picture, like Rowan asking about "beaming off" the ship or the Aliens-like vibe coming from the Marines who are sent to hunt down Jason, but you're left wishing there were more of these, or better executed for more laughs. One stand-out example is the recreation of a Camp Crystal Lake hologram circa 1980 and Jason's interaction with it. Again, it works because it's played for the right amount of laughs and drama. The audience is already in on the joke; after nine films, we know what Jason's reaction would be but it's still fun to see it happen.When we're finally introduced to the new, upgraded Jason 2.0, there's surprisingly little of him in action before the film needs to be wrapped up. Of course, room for a sequel is left at the end of the film and it would be interesting to see where New Line decided to go in a future chapter.> Ultimately your mileage on Jason X will vary depending upon what you want to get out of it. If you're looking for a scary movie that winks at the audience a la Scream, you'll probably be disappointed. At the same time, die-hard fans will likely get more enjoyment from seeing the return of Jason and the new kills he notches along the way. And if you're someone like me who was hoping for more re-thinking of the entire franchise and the horror icon Jason Voorhees has become in the genre, you're split down the middle.As much as I dig that poster design and the concept of re-inventing this franchise and finding a way to appease the traditional Friday the 13th fan, Jason X remained a mixed bag for me.

reviews.review_title: You'd think by now they'd start having some fun with it, no?
reviews.content: There IS something amusing about a spaceship, 300 years in thefuture, in which the crew of astronaut scientists are all teenagersin belly shirts who are just dying to get it on. A cryogenically frozen,then thawed, Jason Voorhees stalks the ship and hacks off headsone by one. No suspense, no real gags--except the one in whichthe stoic black sergeant gets run through from behind by Jason'smachete. "It'll take more than that to bring this old dog down!" hebarks. Another machete pierces through. "...That oughta do it!"(Body slumps to floor.) Since the movie will make back its moneysheerly through the date-night trade, couldn't the filmmakers havehad some fun with this? Even the trademark FRIDAY THE 13TH"Chik-chik-chik-chok-chok-chok" effect has been sampled andprocessed and killed. This is one pathetic, if unmissed, casualty ofHollywood's franchise-mania.

I am a long-time horror fan. I love slasher flicks, especially the original Halloween and the Michael Myers character. The first few Friday the 13th movies were classics. As I was looking for something to watch on Netflix, and this showed up. I hadn't seen this in forever. Since that previous viewing, I've seen many, many horror films... and many, many of them were terrible. "Jason X" stands alongside some of the worst I've seen. Not even 7 minutes in and I wondered why I was watching this again.Briefly... does this movie think it's being funny with the premise? Because it's not. The plot is nonsense, with many plot and logic holes. Outer space... okaaaaaaaay. The acting is weak. This "super Jason" is ridiculous.You'll see a lot of 7/10 and 8/10 reviews for this movie. Horror fans are an interesting lot. Why have to make do with more garbage films than probably any other genre. And we're more forgiving for franchises we enjoyed in the past. This explains some of the reviews... I'm guilty of enjoy crap films too. But this is beyond that for me.Long gone is the sense of fear and terror that you might have felt when Jason was stalking teenagers in the woods at Camp Crystal Lake. This is a parody, essentially, and it's bad at that, too. What you have here is a lame attempt at maintaining a pulse in this long-time franchise on life support... it would have been better for everyone if they had pulled the plug on this movie before they started.

reviews.review_title: Basically, it's Aliens, only much worse.
reviews.content: Alright, I've always been a fan of the Friday the thirteen series, since the first one, so don't take this as someone who is biased against the entire Jason attitude of Rush, Stab, Repeat. But Jason X just goes too far in what we fans can really tolerate. The premise is new to the Friday the 13th series, unfortunately the ENTIRE story hinges on the premise of the movie ALIEN. Basically greedy government officials want to keep the ultimate weapon alive at the cost of anyone in a hundred mile radius. Of course Jason breaks loose and begins to kill and cut his way around the spaceship which is all fine and dandy... and then BAM, three consecutive nude scenes *yay* so far, it's basically the Friday the 13th Formula, despite the entire teacher sex scene (Which I will not even MENTION.) So finally they know Jason is around and BAM we hit the same formula again (i.e. Nerdy dude is electrocuted, stupid bimbo kills herself by accident.) And I must at this time comment that the chicks are even stupider in this edition (Who shoots Jason and then leaves him ON A TABLE BUILT FOR FIXING PEOPLE?) OK so then they fly around, blah blah, Jason then kills an entire crack squad of marines (Another ALIEN REFERENCE?) The teens panic and run around like chickens with their heads chopped off. Then Jason regenerates into something that will shame fans for many a year, he transforms into Uber-Jason. Luckily for us, he usually is only seen in walking sequences, that, and the occasional bang against a tree. The kids end up blowing up their entire Home space station (Is it made of glass? You'd think a space station would at least have a shield.) Then it comes down to the five, Tough black guy who sacrifices himself... (again) Cyborg and her (ugh) Human boyfriend... Slut who sleeps with the now deceased teacher. and the main chick. To make a long story short, The slut ends up having one of the stupidest deaths in the movie, that death could have been so amazing yet they are content to put some slices of bologna on the railing and BAM! A death scene. I won't ruin the very end for you, sufficient to say it also is reminiscent of ALIEN. The entire movie feels like it's being fed down you're throat, it has awful one-liners (32% :o), Terrible deaths that just reek of the other movies, and stupid teenagers AS USUAL. Yep, this sure was a great movie... The only time I would ever recommend this movie, is if a mad scientist gave you the choice of watching it, or eating Rusty nails, and even then, it's a close race.

I remember a while ago thinking how terrible this is that Jason is going to space . . . Well, although I would loved for Jason to stay on earth and be HIM for the rest of the movie . . . this is a welcome change from one of the worst movie I have seen and not just from Friday the 13th it was horrible. Jason actually looks decent in the film until he becomes "Uber-Jason" and although he looks funny in pictures it's a little easier to stomach in the movie it self.  The score is great and it's very nice to have Harry back this time around even though there are some cheesy parts in the score. The story is good and easy to follow with some great characters and good dialogue and the acting is above average for this type of movie and it's so good not to see one of the people from Dawsons creek up there with Mr.Voorhess.  Although the story is a tad out there the beginning made it a little more believable as hard as that is to say and it doesn't get to farfetched with it being in the future. All in all I was surprised and welcome this into the series!

How did the written script of Jason going into space with time travel even get accepted by studio's in the first place? That really shows the odd time and lunacy of studio idea's about horror films back in the early 2000s. With that said it could have been a complete disaster, and having seen the film numerous times there is almost an enjoyable aspect about it even though it's a poor film, the definition of a guilty pleasure I suppose. The beginning is great, we have Jason tied up, with a good looking actress, Lexa Doig, playing a scientist as the main lead, and then the legendary David Cronenberg as a quick cameo. However, once the plot turns into the mindless space odyssey, the film goes downhill. The jokes are terrible, action sequences are fake looking, it has terrible acting performances and the idea for little nano-bugs to create Jason's metal amour, just awful. I understand those who'd like it just for the senselessness to it but overall the movie is one big mess and regret.

reviews.review_title: Jason goes space age....with sexy results
reviews.content: Simpsons tie in, couldn't resist. Apologies for the misleading summary, because there is nothing sexy about this movie, but it is still enjoyable.This time Jason is set loose on a space ship full of rather silly people, hot girls and action heroes. THis film certainly has its moments. The effects are decent, the kills are fun and Jason's science fiction upgrade at the film's conclusion is well done.This probably won't be liked by older Friday fans, but if you were born a little down the Friday chronology give this one a shot. It gives Jason a little bit of personality and some cool toys to play with.

You can not keep a good man down and Jason is back in top form.  After ripping off mostly the "Alien" series, Jason proves that the worst monsters are created right here on good old Earth.I don't think they should have "updated" him.  The original retro look made him even more menacing.Word of advice to the producers:  If you plan a number eleven, kill more good looking naked chicks or just have them cavort naked!Smashing good time for lovers of gore!

reviews.review_title: Know what you are getting into and you will love this film.
reviews.content: Let's be real, this is part 10 of what is one of the worst movie franchises in film history. It's not Chariots of Fire, it's Jason Ten. If you not only accept that, but embrace the shear ridiculousness of it, this is one incredibly entertaining movie. The filmmakers obviously didn't take themselves or their content too seriously and the film is tremendously tongue in cheek. Don't expect anything scary, but get ready to laugh. I totally enjoyed the movie, as did everyone else in the theater. If you go into with the right attitude, it's impossible not to like this movie.

Although entertaining at points Jason X works better as a comedy than a horror or a Sci Fi film. Everything is so generic, so cheap, and just lazy filmmaking. New Line should be ashamed that this came out the same year as the lord of the Rings.

Jason X (2002) Kane Hodder, Lexa Doig, Lisa Ryder, Chuck Campbell, Jonathan Potts, Peter Mensah, Melissa Ade, Melody Johnson, Derwin Jordan, Dov Tiefenbach, Kristi Angus, D: Jim Isaac. In the year 2455, scientist Doig and machete-killing Jason Voorhees are brought back to life from cryogenic suspension by a team of students. You know the rest: the actors have premarital sex and drop like flies.The writers behind this tenth cheap follow-up to the FRIDAY THE 13th sequels, which will hopefully end the tired splatter-franchise, didn't have to waste their time making another script. Ryder is game, as a robot programmed to kick booty. Apparently Adam Marcus was lying after he made JASON GOES TO HELL: THE FINAL FRIDAY, because Hell Jason never reached and Final Friday it wasn't. David Cronenberg appears in the beginning. Followed by FREDDY VS. JASON. Running Time: 98 minutes and rated R for strong horror violence, language and some sexuality. RATING: * ½ (out of ****)

This is, undoubtedly, the worst movie I have ever seen. Period. I've seen a lot of movies, a lot of bad movies, but this one is at the top of the list and nothing else is even close. Oh, of course there are movies that are much worse-made in all aspects, but when you consider the 'Friday the 13th' franchise being utilized and the results obtained, nothing compares.There is not one single redeeming quality in this movie. Not only am I surprised this did not go straight to video, it should never have even been given that honor. 'Jason X' reeks of bad-TV-movie from beginning to end. I don't even know that I would go so far as to say TV-movie. It reminds me something that would be categorized as the worst episode of the worst sci-fi series ever. From the terrible camera work, to the horrible special effects, to the embarrassing over-acting, to the ridiculously cheesy soundtrack, to the childish script, this movie has 'amateur' written all over it.When it goes for laughs, it fails miserably. The only laughing you will do during this movie will be unintentional on the part of the director, I guarantee that. On the other hand, there are absolutely no worthy scares. Of quite possibly the cheapest way to get scares - jump scenes - I counted one. And as I said, they are cheap. As for gore, there is nothing here that is worth anybody's time. I would guess that on half the kills, the camera cuts away just before the money shot. This is the business of a PG-rated movie, not an R-rated Jason film. Inexcusable. What gore they do show is laughable at best.In horror movies, you are supposed to like the characters and be rooting for them to survive. When characters then do die, it is that much harder to watch. In 'Jason X', you are rooting for everyone to die as painful a death as possible.and you don't even get that satisfaction.And on top of everything is the complete implausibility of the whole situation. But I won't even bother. By now, you will either take my advice and stay as far away from this movie as possible, or you are a glutton for pain.'Jason X' zero stars

SPOILERSJason X is about Jason getting frozen and getting thawed out in 2400 and goes on a killing spree. This one is just the others, except this one is in space. Towards the end, Jason becomes Uber-Jason. My favorite death in this when the girl's head is frozen and is smashed against the wall and shatters. That was sort of disgusting. They kill Jason but then he comes back as Uber-Jason and nothing can destroy him. But they blow the place that he's in up and he floats into space and lands in the lake while the 3 surviving people are safely in a escape pod. But when he falls in the lake a couple thought he was a shooting star. Then you see his mask in the lake. The end. Overall, this is just a high-tech slasher film.6/10

reviews.review_title: My comments recommend the film but doesnt give anything away
reviews.content: I can't say this is the best Friday The 13th film because I haen't seen the others yet. But I can say that this film made me laugh a lot and that it is definitely worth seeing, even if your not a fan of horror or sci-fi, but you musn't be afraid of some gore and violence. But there are more laughs from this film than anything else.

reviews.review_title: Classic story with a new twist
reviews.content: Jason X is a new twist on the now-classic story.  It seemed like everyone in the theater (including me) liked the movie.  Yea, some parts are kind of cheesy, but overall I left having had a good time.  In this installment in the series, Jason gets frozen, then thawed 500 years later on a space ship. After a minor losing of limbs and head, Jason gets upgraded to a new age, high-tech Jason.  As always, there are many deaths, including some new creative ones (Scientist gets her head frozen then shattered), and a few scares.  If you are a fan of horror movies, then this is a good one for you. If you don't like horror movies, then you still might like this.

reviews.review_title: Jason SUX would be a better title. 3/10
reviews.content: How hard would it have been to make this film fun?  Not very hard in my opinion.  All I ask for is so very little with this type of film. Sadly, Jason X is pretty damn awful.  Out of the entire movie, there are two scenes I liked.  The first scene is involves a neat death.  Jason shoves a chick's head into a liquid that makes her head freeze, then he smashes it.  The next scene, and my favorite, involves Jason trapped in virtual reality.  The scenario is at Crystal Lake, and it involves two women who want to "drink beer, smoke pot, and have premarital sex" with Jason.  The way he ends up killing them is hysterical.The rest of the movie blows.  If you like gore, you might like it.  If you like anything authentic, stay away.

reviews.review_title: O Sleeping Bag, Where Art Thou?
reviews.content: I'm gonna keep this as short and simple as I can. This movie is a crock but it's a funny crock. If you keep your expectations low, you will enjoy this film (besides, whaddya expect? the movie is set in space for God's sake. I don't think they were going for credibility here). People get it in pretty nasty ways. It's always a treat to see David Cronenberg, I'm hoping to cast him in my first feature. The sleeping bag scene is a celluloid classic. I was forced to watch this sucker and I enjoyed it, laughing nearly the whole time. I'm recommending it in case you like horror movies that kinda poke fun at themselves. Give it a shot. Rating: *** out of *****

reviews.review_title: Jason in Space: how is that not funny?
reviews.content: What most people don't seem to understand about Jason X is the fact that it is obviously a comedy. Really. Just watch it thinking that it is a spoof of Alien Resurrection and you can truly appreciate the movie. Don't try to take it seriously, because if you do, you will hate the movie, as well as miss the point. I mean, come on. It's a Jason movie in space. How can you possibly take that seriously? Honestly, no one should do that with Jason movies anyway, excluding the first one, which wasn't even truly a Jason movie. Do i need to remind you about the wheelchair death in Friday the 13th part 2? Or how about the death by weed-eater in part 7? Let's also not forget Jason takes Manhattan, which was hilarious. So, in essence, if you watch Jason X expecting to be scared or expecting a riveting plot line , you are watching the wrong movie. Go watch Halloween or the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre. On the other hand, if you want to laugh and still get to see gratuitous violence, then by all means, watch Jason X. It has all of the staples of the series and some fairly creative kills along with parts that are so ridiculous you can't help but laugh, such as the hologram sequences and uber-Jason. Overall, i think Jason X is highly underrated mostly because so many people don't have a sense of humor. The writers are obviously able to laugh at themselves, so you should be able to as well.

Set in the year 2455 A.D., space explorers and soldiers visit the uninhabitable Earth and pick up two cryogenically frozen bodies. One is a female scientist (Lexa Doig) and the other turns out to be Jason Voorhees (Kane Hodder, who else?). After being thawed out, the scientist warns everyone about Jason's murderous rampage, but like all the brainless teens in the previous sequels they ignore her and find themselves getting picked off one by one. The tenth installment in the "Friday the 13th" series not only borrows elements from "Alien," "Star Trek," and "The Terminator," but is gory and occasionally funny. Nothing original, but some of the murders boast some showmanship (woman's head dunked in frozen liquid and smashed into pieces) and the hologram scene at Crystal Lake is silly. By the way, what's up with the cyber-Jason? So dumb. Lisa Ryder steals the show as an android who even tries to take Jason down; filmmaker David Cronenberg has a small role as one of Jason's unlucky victims. My evaluation: ** out of ****

Apparently canon doesn't matter in the Friday the 13th series. It's not like it mattered before, but come ON. Jason, in SPACE? When he clearly got dragged to literal hell in the previous movie? What happened in those 450 years between the last 2 movies? Anyways, this movie just barely straddles the line between so-bad-its-good and just plain old bad. I mean, it's campy in some places, but the continuity mistakes, as well as nearly everything else about this movie, are unforgivable. Also, WHY IS JASON IN OUTER SPACE?

reviews.review_title: LET THE BODIES HIT THE FLOOR.
reviews.content: A new twist on the Friday the 13th movies. The masked killer Jason Voorees in the 25th century is interesting. A group of young scienctists find The masked killer frozen. But once they bring him on ship and thaw him out, He'll soon go back to his own ways, (If you are a Friday The 13th fan, you know what I mean). The special effects are good. The cast of characters are likeable at times. This movie has a few good suspencful moments. It's somewhat predicable. I hope this the end of Jason.

reviews.review_title: A smartly made, witty and inventive sequel
reviews.content: A Friday the 13th movie set 400 years into the future which takes place in outer space, ludicrous right? Well you'd think so but this scenario actually works in Jason X, the tenth instalment of the Friday the 13th franchise and the second to be released by New Line Cinema after the debacle that was Jason Goes to Hell (1993) which promised to be the Final Friday, but of course it wasn't.Thanks to a witty script by Todd Farmer and smart direction by James Isaac this is an enjoyable sci-fi horror action movie and a welcome change to see Jason in a different setting. It delivers some inventive kills, is funny where it's supposed to be and is not as bad as some reviewers would have you believe. In fact I avoided watching this for almost 20 years as I thought the filmmakers had gone too far in a desperate attempt to keep the franchise going, I was pleasantly surprised to see just how good it was, even 20 years on.Produced by original Friday the 13th creator Sean S Cunningham with his son Noel Cunningham the gamble to put Jason Voorhees into space paid off, probably because this is for all intents and purposes Alien (1979), but instead of HR Giger's creature jumping out and killing the crew it's the unstoppable Jason who terrorises the spaceship. Played once again to good effect by Kane Hodder the serial killer gets a cool makeover when he's regenerated by nano technology after being cryogenically frozen since 2008 in an attempt to contain the killer.Jason X has the highest budget of all the Friday the 13th movies costing $11 million due largely to it's digital effects, where the average Friday movie would cost around $3 million. Not faring well at the box office upon it's release it's certainly worth a revisit and a reappraisal.Look out for an appearance by legendary horror film director David Cronenberg who, as Dr. Wimmer, holds Jason captive in the Crystal Lake Research Facility before he inevitably escapes.

I had high expectations for this 10th Jason adventure. I mean, the last installment Jason Goes to Hell: The Final Friday is my favorite F13 and I thought it ended the series perfectly. Once New Line Cinema revealed that they wanted to continue the legacy, I wondered how they were gonna bring him back and make it worthwhile instead of pointless. Now that i've seen it, i've been answer the question: Did we need another Friday the 13th? Read on and you'll find out what I thought.!!!POSSIBLE SPOILER OR 2!!! A few years have passed since Jason Goes to Hell, and Jason is being contained by the government. He breaks free and kills off almost everyone there, except one woman. She lures him into a tank where they are both frozen. Over 400 years later, a group of scientists journey to what is an abandoned Earth and find the two frozen specimens. They take them with them on their space station to take to Earth 2. They thaw out the girl, Rowan, and tell her that they are safe. Unfortunately, Jason has also thawed out and does what he does best.Entertaining, good acting, great effects, and a pretty cool premise, but poor dialogue, the overall plot is nothing special, and there are some missed oppurtunities(Like with Uber-Jason for example). **1/2 out of *****. Could have been great, but is only o.k.

reviews.review_title: Great special effets, poor story line but awesome kills!
reviews.content: If you're a fan of Friday the 13th, it's a must to watch! Yeah, the plot is stupid but there's really great special effets for its time and plenty of gruesome murders yet to be seen!! I'm a big fan of the franchise and overall I'm glad I saw it.

reviews.review_title: 9 years is too long to wait...
reviews.content: Jason Goes to Hell was released in 1993.  Now it is 2002 and we have Jason X.  Well, when these movies were big in the eighties, they were cranking out a sequel almost every year...the number of the film, also coincided with the current year.  Then in 1988, they stopped with Jason Takes Manhattan...then 5 years later, Jason is back in what most feel was a disappointing sequel. Well, now it has been 9 years since fans had a chance to see Jason on the big screen (well, in April anyway).  In my personal opinion, the series really did not need any entry like Jason X.  I really liked the Camp Ground settings, and running through the woods of Crystal Lake.  But to put Jason in space, 455 year into the future and to just make it an Aliens rip-off. Very unsatisfying!  I don't know if anything will be different on the version they put on screen, as what I saw on my bootleg copy, but I was very disappointed in the low-gore level this film had.  I agree with most other reviews...this film has not place in 2002, only because really decent horror films have gone down hill since the presentation of films like Scream or anything that has followed behind it.  People don't want to see Jason, Freddy or Michael anymore...well, except die hard fans like myself.  People are so saturated with PC quality horror films, they have forgotten the greats of the 80's. Corny jokes, bad dialog, slow pacing, and almost no gore really hurt this film.  Now, part 9 had satisfactory gore and was very violent...that is what one wants from a Jason film.  Not what part X is giving us.  The sets were nice, and well done, but you just can't past all the silliness, and unbelievable set-ups..even for a Friday film.  If Freddy Vs. Jason is made...I really hope whomever makes it really get back to the 80's style of horror movies & just goes crazy!4 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Great movie about killing Gen X'ers; Ironically.
reviews.content: I loved this movie...I've perused a couple Jason movies...I never liked them but THIS, this is an awesome premise and Jason doesn't let me down...Watching all those smarmy under 30 douches get mangled by Jason was a wonder to behold! The dialog was mind crushing, so trite and stupid but...Jason does his part perfectly.

Jason Voorhees, the horror legend from the EIGHTIES, is back on a spaceship in the 25th century. After his last episode on the now dead Earth, he was chriogenicly frozen along with a girl who survived him. But in the 25th century, nobody seems to know about the legacy of Jason. The stupid teenagers didn't even bother to re search their frozen subject. Predictable, un-scary lousy entry in this worn out series. I love Jason. he was the only one out of them all to actually give me nightmares. but in the movies that he managed to scare me, they were made in the 80's. this film was made in 2001 where they have all their fancy camera angles and all their fancy special efects. They do not enhance the scare quality at all. they make the average horror movie a piece of crap. There's very little to say about this film. Not recommended.*1/2 out of ****

Well, if your going to watch this movie you probably are expecting the trash that it is. BUT this isn't TOO bad, their are many, many horror films, Friday the 13th films, and Jason knock-off films that are much worse. Don't get me wrong, Jason X is stupid. I really, really hate all of the characters with a passion, but I did appreciate the unnecessary nudity near the end.There are some good death scenes that continue the tradition that Friday the 13th helped create. This movie basically amounts to "Friday the 13th Part Ten: Jason in Space" and since EVERYTHING having to do with space is ALWAYS in the future, (its amazing how everything in outer space is in the future, isn't it? So does that mean the space shuttle time travels?)this is no exception and set in like the 69th century or whatever. Titantic sucks.

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as I expected and pretty good for a movie that is a 10th sequel
reviews.content: Jason X I have to admit is a rare, good sequel. Usually movies that are up to the third or higher sequels tend to usually stink (ex. Halloween) and others that don't stink (ex. Evil Dead). The movie did something that I wish all movies that are not in the drama categories did: the actors/actresses did not try to act. The ones that did, at least succeded. Their are only a few times when they try and don't succed but it was rare. And to be honest, I thought the special effects were good. And at least the movie didn't have rock music blasting throughout the whole movie.8/10

reviews.review_title: Welcome return of the 1980's most infamous horror icon.
reviews.content: "Jason X" is an excellent film. Simply put. The C.G.I. effects are superb and very believable. The actor's do try hard and it shows, they exchange witty comments while expressing actual fear at the same time. Kane Hodder does a great job reprising Jason Voorhees, he never says anything but he still can maintain that "Jason" feeling just by his body movements, and think that is partially the reason why this film works. I thought the idea of putting Jason in space was comical, but I wasn't so quick to disregard it because of a new setting, which many narrow-minded people have done. Jason is still himself, he just has new victims, new settings, and more advanced weapons they can fight him with. But not-surprisingly this film is absolutely flawless. There is a new element added to the series: Humor. The cast makes many one-liners and the scene in which (SPOILER) Uber Jason beats one promiscuous teen with another promiscuous teen is just flat out hilarious, it's one of those "You have to see it" moments. This is probably the most original Friday sequel, and many will say that this film does rip off Alien, but I don't think they are ripping off Alien, I feel that they were paying homage to a classic film. Overall "Jason X" is an excellent return to the big-screen for Jason, and credit is due to the cast and crew for creating an original Friday the 13th instead of staying in the woods. Kudos to New Line for going out on a limb with this film, I and many appreciate it. Hopefully this film will get "Freddy VS Jason" greenlight and lead to another Friday the 13th.

After the previous nine movies, I wasn't sure what to expect from this one, but I have to say I was shocked at how good it was!  It's funny, has some very inventive death scenes, and above all never takes itself to seriously!!Money has obviously been spent on it, and the script has some great one-liners.  The acting may not be the greatest, but the actors give everything, and that helps.  At least in this slasher movie, you actually want some people to survive!A shockingly good movie!

reviews.review_title: Ridiculous. Mostly in a fun way.
reviews.content: If a horror franchise is allowed to drag out to the double digits then sooner or later the killer is going to space. It's just going to happen. I'm a little disappointed that the Jaws franchise hasn't made it that far yet, I'd have liked to have seen that.This time, it's Jason Voorhees, who gets cryogenically frozen in a cold open set in the present day. At this point the franchise had already established that the authorities recognized Jason as a real unkillable threat, not an urban legend, so it makes sense in-universe that certain unscrupulous people would want to study him to find out how he's avoiding a permanent death. Lexa Doig is great as Rowan, the scientist who determines that the safest way to deal with Jason is to freeze him. Unfortunately due to interference from an opportunistic colleague, she winds up being frozen along with Jason. These sequences are actually pretty decent and don't look too cheap. Fast forward four centuries though, and welcome to some production values that look like an Asylum flick on the Syfy channel. A team of improbably dressed explorers finds the cryochamber, defies all common sense in opening it, and then proceeds to behave in such a reckless manner that someone gets his arm hacked off. This turns out to be a group of teens on a space field trip, being led by an instructor (Jonathan Potts in fine smarmy form) who turns out to be more interested in making a few bucks on the side than in their educational welfare. They take both Rowan and Jason aboard their laboratory vessel and just as soon as two of the teens frolic off to get busy, the whole ship is in trouble. The rest of the film is Rowan, the students, crew and their space marine escort trying to first contain Jason, and failing that, escape from the ship as it falls apart. Kind of like one of the more recent Alien movies, except it's Jason and the special effects are sometimes hilariously special. There's a lot of live ammo being fired in confined spaces, which seems like a really bad idea in a space ship. Then there's an Aeon Flux inspired sequence, which the actress (Lisa Ryder) carries off with winky aplomb. Peter Mensah is also great as the redoubtable Sergeant Brodski. Overall, this is one of the weaker entries in the series, but it's got a lot of cheese appeal. It's definitely worth at least one watch.

Having been a life-long fan of the series, I was in sheer horror when I found out that Jason's next outing was going to take place in the future, in space.  The first thing that came to mind was that little movie where the Leprechan went to space....In short, I was a little dissapointed with the concept.  Normally when a franchise character is sent to space, it's a pretty good indication that the film-maker's are starting to run out of ideas.  I was so discouraged, I skipped the theatrical run and waited for the dvd release.  Well, I just saw Jason X and I can happily say that I was surprised and I enjoyed the hell out of it.  You have to remember that this is coming from a guy who HATES sci-fi with a purple passion. 
From the opening credits to the final frame, this movie rocked.  In 2009, Jason dispatches half a dozen guys (all within the first five minutes) then he and a female scientist are frozen together.  Jump ahead to 2455, and a bunch of college-age kids find a very frozen Jason Vorhees and a female scientist.  Of course, Jason is brought back to their ship, thawed out, and the carnage starts.  In Jason X, there is no oscar-worthy performance, no strong character development, just all out FUN.  This entry has literally EVERY element that made the other nine movies so enjoyable and MUCH more to boot.  There is even a great showdown between Jason and a female android (the highlight). It's that kind of movie and fun stuff at that.Yeah sure, many of the purists already hated this movie before it was even released (much like I did) but if you sit through it and watch it for what it is (a Jason in space movie) I think you'll definitely enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: this movie achieved what its 80s contemporaries did, pure Friday the 13th murderous fun and a lil suspense
reviews.content: Being the 10th film in the franchise (Friday the 13th Part X), this film followed the exact same formula of its prior films. The difference was the change of scenery, last scene in Crystal lake (Part IX), before touring Manhattan for a Part VIII haha you'll definitely have to tune in for my review on that...i don't even want to call it a movie but i don't know what else to call it haha...Anyways Jason X mixes in a little history of Jason just to refresh everyone's memory of how brutally ruthless and maniacal this demon deformed man is. Another welcomed technique in this installment is how it remedies and takes pokes at the stupidity and simplicity of the 80s genre itself. I found this film very entertaining and although its not overwhelmingly scary by any means, it delivers and exciting and fun-filled horror film starring one of the stable mass killers of the 80s. If you enjoyed this, then you can catch more of Jason as he battles Freddy in Freddy V.s. Jason, in which its story plays out in similar style to Jason X rather than Freddy's most recent Film New Nightmare (1994). See this movie you'll appreciate it for what it was meant to be, a reminder that we haven't forgotten about Jason Voorhees and the minions of sex, drugs, and rock n roll teens hes decimated.

*major spoiler!*It had to happen sooner or later. "Jason X," the tenth installment in the undying "Friday the 13th" series puts the masked killer in the 25th century. After being frozen for hundreds of years, he is revived aboard a interstellar craft, where he calmly picks up a machete and goes about his usual work. It sounds like a fan geek's dream, but that doesn't negate the fact that it's a pretty stupid movie. To be honest, it's also kind of dull up till the last act, more on that in a minute. Director James Isaac opens the film with a stylish credit sequence and sets up the story in a fairly interesting way, at least for a slasher. There is even a cameo by cult favorite David Cronenburg. However, as it goes on, it's clear that he has no real sense of pacing, nor does he often demonstrate the ability to scare us. To be fair, that would be hard to do with such flimsy material. It doesn't help that there are a couple of groan-inducing bits regarding severed body parts.The production values are just so-so, betraying its low-budget origins. I would have been much more forgiving in this area if treated to a good story, but it was not to be. The special effects are sometimes adequate, sometimes blatantly fake-looking. I wasn't expecting anything as good as Ridley Scott's "Alien," but at the very least, they should have tried to make it swift and entertaining. The sixth, seventh, and eighth entries were fun to watch in a cheesy sort of way. They were pretty silly, but certainly diverting. "Jason X" is just plain bad. However, at least the third act picks up a bit, as an android crewmember apparently finishes the killer off--until he is revived as a cyborg. Still stupid, but more watchable.Needless to say, the acting is mediocre at best, but what could these performers have done with such poor material? At least Kane Hodder, as Jason, seems to be enjoying himself. One cast member in particular is as awful as Carrot Top, but he is thankfully dispatched early on. Lexa Doig, as the heroine, has some appeal, but there wasn't much she could do here. Most of the other actors are ineffectual at best, annoying at worst. I guess most slasher movies will always suffer these faults to a degree. This one certainly doesn't miss an obligation: the door is left open for a sequel.*1/2 (out of ****)Released by New Line Cinema

reviews.review_title: Jason X was one of the most fun movies i have seen in years!!!
reviews.content: Jason X, is by far, the most fun, fast, entertaining, amazing movie i have seen. Jason X keeps you on the edge of your seat the whole time. It never fails to be entertaining!! Its action packed with GREAT special effects. Some of the best explosions i have seen before. This movie is suited for lovers of all genres. I believe everyone can enjoy this movie. I recommend this movie to anyone. I am a non-horror fan, and i still LOVED IT. Thats very unusual. Even the trailer for this movie is the most entertaining i have ever seen. I urge everyone to go see this movie. YOU WONT REGRET IT!!! I loved this movie. If you love to go to the theatres to have fun, get a laugh, get scared, and just have an overall good time, this is the movie you should go see. ITS THE BEST!! 10 out of 10

"Jason X" finally reached theaters and to tell you the truth after waiting a couple of years for this film,I found that the wait wasn't worth it but who cares? I liked the film anyway.This film takes a different spin on the "Friday the 13th" series and was comical in some areas providing some corny dialouge that made me laugh rather than jump out of my seat."Jason X" reminded me of one of those popcorn fests that deal with the ubsurd and I found that part of it entertaining to me.This film is better than the last one which I thought was alright but it's not that good to the point where I'll recommend it to other people.At least the new chrome silvery mask looks pretty cool.

It's the year 2455 and they still have not invented the Ray gun or better yet a laser gun.  They are still using bullets.  Unlikely......This movie was really stupid.  All of the killings could have been prevented.  Same stupid grunts thinking they can kill anything moving.  But end up dead themselves.  This reeks of the Alien movies.

reviews.review_title: A series that was had by all, now reduced to this B-movie like type?
reviews.content: As a fan of Friday The 13th series, I must say I find this kinda of fun, however, I also find this disparaging, appalling, and a shame to the entire series. I mean it seems to want to put him in space, just like some of the old movies in the 50s or 70s. Well the New York one seemed okay, but in space, uggghhhh!PLEASE! It seems too lat, and too unfitting to make a space theme slasher, more of spaced out slasher to me. They really had to do it, really had to do it, really had to do it, really had to do it..........I recommend Jason vs Freddy, cause this does not fit in to the Friday the 13th series. I guess someone just had the thought or audacity to make a futuristic version and how Jason would survive it. Hopefully, they'd never make one again. Maybe. Wishful thinking!

reviews.review_title: Campy, but still very, very bad...
reviews.content: OK, I'm not a fan of the franchise, but I've seen most of the films. The one I like best is (I think) number six, which had quite a bit of humor in it. Jason X doesn't take itself serious either, aiming for in-jokes, and satire of the whole concept of the series. This could possibly have worked but unfortunately the end result is just too lame.The script (what little there is of it) is heavily "inspired" by Alien, and filled with corny one liners. The cast is amateurish at best, and the sets and FX look like they were borrowed from some TV sci-fi show. And as two of the cast also appear on TV sci-fi show Andromeda, I almost expected to see Kevin Sorbo showing up to save the day.I know you cannot expect much of a Jason-in-space-in-the-future film, but that's still no reason for the film to look as bad as it does, or a script that's unable too spoof such an easy target as the Friday franchise. There is one fun scene in the the film though, when Jason experiences a virtual reality trip back to Crystal Lake. See that bit, and skip the rest.
Though I wish it had a bigger budget and a bigger focus on scares, it's still a bloody good time.

With a plot outline that reads: "Jason Voorhees returns with a new look, a new machete, and his same murderous attitude as he is awakened on a spaceship in the 25th century." Do you really expect this to be any good? I sure hope not. This is easily one of the worst, if not the worst sequel in "Friday the 13th" franchise history. Who thinks this stuff up, honestly? How could sending Jason into space ever seem like a good idea? Not to mention the mere fact it takes place after the events of "Freddy versus Jason" really takes the surprise out of whether or not Jason loses in that movie. Which is too bad too, because "Freddy versus Jason" looks like "Lawrence of Arabia" next to this piece of garbage.The most ridiculous part is when "evil gets an upgrade" as the tagline so ridiculously puts it. Come on, this isn't necessary. Just because a "Friday" film is set in the future doesn't mean Jason has to change with the times, in fact he should be the only constant. It shouldn't matter what generation Jason is in, he should be able to be just as dangerous and effective a killing machine regardless of what he's wearing.This movie is guilty of countless crimes against the cinema. How this project ever got the green light is a complete and total mystery to me. At least when I saw it, someone else rented it, so I didn't have to spend my own money on it. Overall, I'd say this is not worth the rental, and it's barely worth watching even on television for free! It is an insult to the intelligent horror film fan.

Jason X is the tenth installment of the overrun Friday the 13th horror series. As with any movie series with 10 parts, it cannot and must not be taken seriously. The story for Jason X is as ridiculous as they come. Mass murderer Jason Voorhees is cryogenically frozen for 500 years from now when he comes back to life on a spaceship heading for Earth 2. Aside from the stomach churning acting in the film there are a few scenes that are worth watching. If you rent this film on DVD just go to the Jump To A Death feature to watch the hilarious killings that take place. Aside from the cool new upgrade Jason gets (to become Uber-Jason), this film is totally unmemorable. I would not recommend watching this film all the way through, it is not worth anyone's time.

Jason has been frozen with a women for many years. Then some foolish teens have resurrected the mad man yet again. Jason is brought on a ship,and makes the best of his situation. Using 25th century weapons to get the job done. The movie is a comedy/horror. These can be great. A lot of fun. It has a great plot. And the make-up effects for Jason were spectacular. I loved it! But it got half it's material from the alien series,which was it's only flaw. A lot of fun,rent it. New Line Cinema scores again!3.5/4

Bashers you have to except that this is a popcorn movie. It isn`t on The Acadmey`s List,but it`s fun.Jason is alway`s going to come back,the thing is your going to have to except a dumb plot. This one is clever,to renew interest in the series. It is awfully similar to Alien. Yet it`s good,not great but good.
3/4

D: Jim Issacs S: Kane Hodder, Lexa Doig, Lisa Ryder, Chuck Campbell, Jonathan Potts.Well, it's finally happened, they've taken Jason Voorhees and shipped him into outer space. I don't think I really need to explain much more, the only difference between this one and all of the other ones is that it's in outer space. I agree with many on this one, "For devoted slasher fans only!" I think they should hang that sign out in front of these and the Halloween Flicks.David Cronenberg appears briefly as Dr. Wimmer.Co-Starring: Peter Mensah, Melissa Ade, Philip Williams, Todd Farmer, David Cronenberg.

Well, you don't watch a film in the "Friday the 13th" series expecting logic, sense, or high production values. But if you like slasher films (as I do!) you do expect a measure of gory fun.Jason X, unfortunately, provides that only up to a point. Though some of the killings shown are imaginative, others are so casually, even carelessly, presented, that you're left saying "Huh?" rather than screaming in terror (or laughter). My favorite in this respect: when the soldier Sven is yanked backward and has his neck broken, the two highly trained (LOL) soldiers with him don't even notice for several minutes. When they do, one asks "Where the hell's Sven?" - and that's that. No attempt is made to find/contact him or avenge his death. If the characters don't care, why should the audience?Special effects, which might have redeemed this, are poor and the movie otherwise has all the flaws of the genre  idiotic plot, characters who are any or all of stupid/greedy/venal, and a villain who is improbable  nay, impossible  to say the least. The music is so pallid that they might as well not have bothered with any.If you're a fan of the series, you might enjoy this. Otherwise, forget it.Rating: 2/10.
I genuinely don't understand how this entry gets so much hate... There are so many movies out there that are 1000x worse. My only complaint is that I wish they had focused on scares a bit more.
This movie is very horrible. every actors and actress are so horrible

This is a film that proves that hollywood is only about money. Canyou imagine pitching this story? It's absolutely ridiculous! Anyonewho wastes time on this trash needs to get a life. 
                                                  Sincerely, Michael Myers

It's got all the usual horror/slasher cliches blended in nicely with a lot of the sci-fi ones but somehow it ends up quite watchable.Surprisingly how well it holds your attention with all that consideredIt will never win any awards but worth a watch if your trying to scroll through what's streaming.

reviews.review_title: The best part of the series up to date....
reviews.content: This movie really amazed me, not only did i think that this would be some f*cked up sciene fiction crap, but from the picture ive seen on "future jason" this movie seemed to suck big time. But when i finally got around to watch it i was amazed. This movie is a true masterpiece with all the right ingrediences that a true horror flick should have. And Jason in space is even cooler then jason on earth.

reviews.review_title: Not believable, not scary, not gross - not good!!
reviews.content: First, let me say that I am a big fan of the "Friday the 13th" movies though they just have not been very good since Part 4 - like a stupid fool, I still rush to the movies when a new one comes out. The reason the first four Fridays were scary was because they actually attempted to take themselves seriously, they didn't try to be funny and they didn't use corny one-liners - comedy has no business in a horror film. This latest entry is one of the worst (although 8 & 9 were also very bad). There are so many, many movies about space - why did director James Isaac choose to make a Friday the 13th film if his real inspiration was the "Alien" movies. I actually found myself yawning throughout this film and did not find one single scene to be scary. It wasn't scary, it wasn't gross (one gross killing out of 30 is not enough) - it wasn't good. I hope if New Line decides to put out a new Friday film, they will put Jason back in the woods where he belongs and where he is scary, and give him back his old look of hockey mask and dirty farm clothing - the Uber-Jason at the end of the film looked much more like a comic book villain than a serial killer.

SIGH. OK, I liked it. Look, we know its not an Oscar contender. We know how the Friday movies are. You couldn't possibly go into this thinking "will my life be forever changed watching these performances?" No. But taking it for what it is - serial killer gets frozen, taken aboard a ship centuries later and proceeds to kill - you couldn't possibly hate it. If it sounds preposterous to you, why would you even watch? The chicks are hot, the kills are bad ass, and its a perfect "what if..." popcorn movie. As long as they never follow up on this, its a pretty fun movie in my boat. Glad I spent 2.99 on it!!! And people harp on the "upgraded" Jason too much. He was in perhaps the last 10-15 minutes max. Similar to how the Dino's on Jurassic Park were taken to the US in part 2? Yea, it was only the last 10 minutes, so it's not a big deal. I'd actually like to see more "what if" types of Jason stories like this.

reviews.review_title: New Line Cinema is destroying Jason's character
reviews.content: New Line's acquisition of the Jason Voorhees name, trademark, what-have-you have proved to be a big mistake in my opinion. Between Jason Goes to Hell and Jason X (both New Line products) these two movies are a horribly naive attempt to cash in on a new idea of what a Jason/ Friday the 13th movie should be like in the modern world of today. Jason Goes to Hell was the better of the two but this movie (Jason X) was just utterly horrible. The characters are still composed of the traditional sex-crazed teenagers, with some adult authority kicking around. The new 'space-craze' phenomenon sucked in the Jason/Friday the 13th series and for some reason the director (whose name escapes me right now) must have had a perverse look at what it would be like in the year 2455. This is Flash Gordon meets Jason Voorhees type material, really pathetic. There is no time for character development at all, they die off too quickly for starts. The guy with his own personal robot was a little too icky for me, the sex-crazed couple, the corrupted leader who has his own issues with bondage. There is simply way too much stuff going on that doesn't need to be going on, big time although 'cheesy' special f/x and horrible dialogue really make for the most of the movie. Jason's appearance is still grotesque as always, there is the nutcase (supposedly) that knows of the Jason legend (sounds like Crazy Ralph to me) and then the new invention of the regeneration of dead tissue? C'mon! Jason is the only reason for seeing this, you probably already knew that. Good luck sitting through it!

reviews.review_title: If enough monkeys ... very minor spoiler
reviews.content: Not that they will, but the Jason series can quit now.  The idea and concept has produced the best it can.  Any shot at success is limited to the parameters set by its original idea.  Is this a good movie?  No, it sucks, like all the Friday the 13th siblings but then this was never intended to be a movie(s) like "The Sixth Sense".  These kinds of films (Nightmare on Elm Street, Halloween sequels, Hellraiser etc.) are cinematic junk food.  But, hey, junk food is good, it just ain't roasted pheasant or even a sirloin on the grill.  This is nachos and hot dogs and tater tots.  Scenes and ideas are delivered to viewers with meaty presence and the whole Jason mythology gets several centuries to reinvent itself and establish his "incredible rejuvinatory abilities", none of which has ever been explained.  Nary a supernatural footnote has touched this series though there have been overtones as different films tried to move the series in different directions.  I find it interesting to compare this latest Jason entry to the original Friday the 13th to see how far we've come.  From shock and gore, groundbreaking at the time, to a Playstation game as (MINOR SPOILER !!!!!!!!!though no one seeing a trailer or poster can be spoiled by this)evidenced by Jason's upgrade.  This is the crop's cream, coming at the hopeful end of a successful series as opposed to Halloween the Original (which IS in a class with "The Sixth Sense" and "Psycho") whose best came first. Still, I have a soft spot for Jason and have, often begrudgingly kept up with his exploits.  I think maybe he deserves one more shot.  The right story, the right director, a film called simply "Jason".  Pull all the stops, pretend there hasn't been a series and use the best of all the contradicting mythology to make one slam bang story, still junk food, that can sort of be Jason's opus; the film that should have started it all. Then Jason can move comfortably into the video game realm where his future is set. If you like to nosh on junk food, this is fine noshing.  If you like to slam this kind of pic go pick on somebody your own size.

reviews.review_title: A whole load of friday fun
reviews.content: Not many films can make it to there tenth outing and do it with this much style. Jason X is of course the big nineties (or should I say noughties?) remake of the series but its done with such loving care and such a good sense of humour that anyone who enjoys good silly horror fun will love it. It's not terrifying but it has great jump shocks, imaginative deaths (minor spoiler) especially the frozen head one, and great little jokes.  The film starts a few years from now in Camp Crystal Lake Research centre where Jason is being held.  Unable to execute him this is where Jason has ended up but then of course some government people who think they can contain Jason turn up, ignore the cute scientist warning and do what they want. Anyhoo without spoiling it too much Jason and the women scientist end up cryogenically frozen and are then found by a group of teenagers on an expidition led by their professor a few hundred years later.  The idea of putting Jason in space may sound silly but it is thoroughly enjoyable.  This film is cool. Trust me.

reviews.review_title: Just stop the franchise now...please...give us Jason Vs. Freddy!
reviews.content: The one pleasant surprise of Jason X' is a cameo by Cult Director David Cronenberg. Director James Isaac has worked on many of Cronenberg's films and plants his probable idol in the beginning sequences of this debacle of a film. One can contest the script, and even the pathetic dialogue, either way  one cannot contest the utter embarrassment of a film such as this.      Kane Hodder returns as the man behind the mask; Jason Voorhees, this time his killing spree is on a spaceship in the year 2455. Upon first encountering the film, I thought the filmmakers would finally have some fun with the killer and just let the story tell itself through blood and guts. Surprisingly, as compared to other Friday the 13th films of the past, this film lacks in the gratuitous violence department as in the gratuitous sex that always happened at the convenient time of Jason's decision to decapitate some young lovers.  Instead, writer Todd Farmer (who also has a supporting part in the film) demonstrates a love for the Jason films but does not include any surprising elements within the tenth film of the Jason Franchise. One liners' are bountiful as well as completely ridiculous sequences that force you to laugh.  The premise of this film is interesting but fails immediately following the revival of the cryogenically frozen Jason Voorhees. The film's introductory credit sequence displays an aortic sense of campiness that is followed through in the film on a regular basis. The musical score by Jason' veteran Harry Manfredini is his worst yet and adds no horror to a supposed horror film. It seems as if he knows he is wasting time and is repeating the same key on his 1980's synthesizer.     Our opening sequence demonstrates the power of our villain (or is he to some a Hero?) as he unleashes his affinity for mayhem. 400 years pass and we are made to understand that Jason Voorhees is a wonder of nature and as such must be studied as a specimen in order to extract all the information the scientists can obtain from him. Apparently his immediate reconstruction of tissue and cell is a wonder and the scientists want to study him for this purpose. Let us not forget, he has been drowned, electrocuted, stabbed, shot repeatedly, yet he always finds a way of resurrecting himself. In this film, he thaws himself out without any support. But the interesting pretext of science goes out the window as Jason once again unleashes his mayhem in outer space in a concept all too familiar of the original Alien' film.     Scripter Todd Farmer inserts some comedic one-liners at the expense of our current timeline. From the sport of hockey being banned in the year 2024 to DVD's being regarded as antiques, he tries to soften the film up with some tacky inserts but only degrades the story into complete disaster. Yet, the biggest criticism I reserve is for Director James Isaac who does not even make an attempt to make this film exciting or interesting. Fine, the script is laughable, yet as a Director it is your responsibility to make this film visually interesting at best. The sequences are shot as if they were done in a hurry and the casting of the majority of the young Canadian actors is a crime. The acting is just horrible and as aforementioned, no sense of heightened excitement is created by the Director's illogical sense of Direction. A point of observation is the finale in which Jason Voorhees gets booted up'. The film's tagline is EVIL GETS AN UPGRADE', that seems to be the selling point for the film's targeted audience. Yet when this creature does get an upgrade and becomes fiercer, more efficient and the most powerful killing machine of all time, the Director just frames the character as if it were any other scene.     The only difference is he introduces the audience to this new creation through the backlight of a silhouette shot and then continues on directing this miserable piece of film. At least some effort should be made to convey to us that the rest of the cast will eventually die due to an unstoppable creature, but when they do die, they are merely another number on his long list of victims. As one can see, there really is nothing new or interesting to see in this debauchery of a film. In our present technological age, I was at least expecting a film that had some grain of effort put into it. Instead, we are subject to prophetic campiness, a central character that does not frighten us any more, some horrible acting, horrible special effects and they even have the audacity to end this film with the possibility of creating another film in this series of film that should have ceased to exist a long time ago.Giancarlo's rating: BOMB

reviews.review_title: Why Did They Turn This To A Dark Comedy??
reviews.content: Contains SpoilersI Am ENORMOUS Friday The 13th Fan. I've watched all of them a few times, and now it's newest addition to the pathetic "JASON GOES TO HELL" hits the big screens here in Australia. Well in one word, all i can say is that i'm really DISAPPOINTED.There are numerous reasons as to why this film was a disappointing run in the series. Firstly, it is set in space. How can they damage the series so much by setting it 450 years into the future? Weren't they thinking? They have permanently scarred the Friday series- I think to a point, that it's too late for a "Come Back".There were many CONS in this film, that i will list first. (**MINOR SPOILERS**)Second Con- This film isn't CAMPY, the series used to have this feeling to it, that not many films did. The creepy atmosphere of the lakes, cabins, woods. It was great. Now we are thrown into space - something that resembles Star Trek. There is no "Astmosphere", the film is REALLY Cheesy, but it's not Campy, and thats what i miss most about the series.Third Con- the acting was DISMAL, by the Entire cast. Not one member of the cast proved themselves to be talented actors/actresses. Though i will admit that NO Friday film had much "Talent"- Yet this had to have the worst.Fourth Con- why the HELL is this film funny? Why have they taken the "edge" off the Jason Films? They have plagued this script, with INSANE one liners, they have made the mistake of what happened to the NIGHTMARE ON ELM STREET SERIES from part 4- It's comical. People want to be scared, this didn't serve up as a horror film to me. Im sure MILD humor is appreciated in a horror film, but they honestly stretched it here, it came to the point where EVERY CHARACTER in the film said some STUPID line before they were killed by Jason.Fifth Con- The plot, in a way it is Original. Yet was THIS the only thing they could come up with?? Jason in Space? Original? Sure... ACCEPTABLE? HELL NO! Jason should be in the woods, thats where he belongs, all this "Body Freezing" - "Time Warping" and Star-ships were making me sick.Sixth Con- The Ending.Most Jason films had a cool ending, which would leave you "Grasping" for the next sequel. the Ending to JASON X was really lame. It was a Conclusive ending, so there wasn't really an End. It was really dumb how Jason and the Space dude, flew down from space to earth and Landed EXACTLY at Crystal lake? Its funny how they didn't discintegrate on their way down. It's also funny how those two lovers at the end, point to Jason and that Space Dude flying down from the air and say "Look- it's a flying star"...Ohhh it's SUCH a fairy-tale ending.Seventh Con- The Music. I REALLY Disliked the musical score of Jason X, it's the worst musical score since FRIDAY THE 13th PART 3. It was very repetative, and didn't have any build-up.Eighth Con- Special Effects. Seeming this was shot in "Space"- Special Effects are a very vital form to this movie- and the Special Effects were cheap and corny. The "Space-ship Section" looked like a floating webcam- im serious. When the ship would get VERY damaged and crash into citys, landing bays, docks, and other Ships, it explodes from the outside, and inside all the people are just holding on as the camera shakes a little bit- like in the power rangers. If they HAD to make this film in space, they could have at least TRIED to make the Special Effects look good.HERE ARE THE FEW PROS IN THE MOVIE.First Pro- Jason "New look". For the fast hour, Jason is plain old Jason, with the hockey mask, and hey thats cool. After getting his head blown off, he re-transforms, and has a new "Metal" mask, and i think it looks cool. Jason looks pretty creepy, and his "Body-guard" looks VERY good.Second Pro- Kane Hodder. The Man BEHIND Jasons mask. He plays his parts very well, although not his best, he does look like he usualy does, really big-stocky and strong. He is the BEST Jason, thats for sure.Third Pro- The Death Scenes. Jason is quiet "Original" with his deaths, he kills with creativity, and thats what i like. A girl gets her face frozen, and he smashes her face on the wall. Also a man falling into a "Giant" screw, and a FUNNY death is when Jason is smashing one girl into another girl. Very well done in this part.Fourth Pro- Attractive Cast. Wow the women were reallt stunning this film. This ALWAYS help a friday film by a few percent. Unfortunantley watching them die off aint so pretty.Fitfth Pro- Good Flashbacks. For a Brief moment in JASON X you are sent "back" or JASON is Sent back to Crystal Lake. It looks so cool how they did it, one VERY funny thing is that Jason is asked by two attractive 80's girls, if he wants to smoke pot with them and have Pre-marital sex because "They love it". Jason teaches them a thing or two after that. It was nice to see that glimpse of Crystal Lake- Oh how it will be missed.Thats my conclusion. I am a BIG Jason Fan, and i must admit JASON X has lowered my faith in the series. Yet this isn't the WORST of the series. It is better than parts (5,8 & 9) .So it's basically one of the worst Jason flicks, but i think its unfair to skip it. Especially if you are a fan, there are SOME redeeming qualities in the film. So i advise you check it out, dont expect anything great at all, and try to come with a "Comical" sense, instead of a Serious one. There were only TEN people in the Cinema watching this film and 3 people walked out, i find NO reason to walk out of this film. But i think its only "Normal" to leave the cinema with a feeling of "Disappointment"** (2 stars) - out of 5.

in my own opinion Jason X was the coolest movie i have seen this year that is a horror flick. the effects were awsome and all the graphics everything was just so cool. the only thing i didnt like about the movie was that he wasnt superjason for very long. the costume of jason when he was upgraded was cool and so was his new hockeymask. he was also a little more stealthy than he usually is. but all around it was an awsome movie. cant wait for Jason XI.

reviews.review_title: Remember when Friday the 13th movies used to be scary?
reviews.content:
I saw Jason X at a special screening at the Mann's 6. The theatre was small, and the best seats were reserved for people who worked on the movie. But hey, I get to see it for free. I got a mini poster of Jason X. And I got to see what Jason really looks like. Good ole Kane Hodder introduced the movie. He looks just like a regular guy you'd see at the gym. Who knows, you could be working out right next to him!As for the movie, it was better than I thought (although I had way low expectations).The good: Jason wears his hockey mask through most of the movie. There's a lot of good kills. There is nudity.The bad: Acting is pretty weak. Story is pretty weak. Jokes are groaners. The fact that they keep cracking jokes after witnessing all of Jason's killings. I'm nostalgic for the shocked state of that chick at the end of Friday the 13 part 3. Towards the end they're really making a joke of Jason. The actresses act like they're in a Saturday Night Live skit.Things to note: They start off the movie with Jason about to be frozen at the Crystal Lake Research Lab (pretty gay, huh?). There's no explanation as to how he got there.They do set up for a sequel. But it's not a set up for another space thing.
What was great about Friday the 13th and it's early sequels was that they played it seriously. It's sad that a lot of filmmakers think that horror fans want a movie filled with bad jokes and winks to the audience. If the characters in the movie aren't afraid of Jason, then why should we be?

"The year is 2455. The Place is Old Earth. Once the shimmering blue jewel of the galaxy, Old Earth is now a contaminated planet abandoned for centuries. Yet humans have returned to the deadly place that they once fled. Not to live, but to research the ancient rusting artifacts of the bygone civilizations that caused this environmental disaster. And little does the most recent landing party of intrepid young explorers realize the fate that awaits them."Understandable this part has nothing to do with the Friday the 13th franchise collection its basically a new idea but creation it wasn't well maded.

reviews.review_title: I just ended up laughing at the deaths and screaming at how stupid it was.
reviews.content: Another pointless sequel to countless other "Friday the 13th s", this film offers little in the areas of suspense and terror. It's not going to have you jumping out of your seat or hiding behind a pillow, because it uses the age old method of scaring you with gore. nowadays, this just isn't enough to scare an audience of horror fans who have seen it all before. There are some original ideas, such as the first "single" death, which in my opinion, is the best in the entire series, but in the end you just get annoyed at how Jason is absolutely invincible. It is one of the better sequels, but in the end I just ended up laughing at the deaths and screaming at how stupid it was.

The plot of this movie doesn't make any sense especially since Jason was dragged to hell at the end of Jason goes to Hell but whatever.. if you want to watch a fun Sci fi/ horror movie then this is for you.

reviews.review_title: Finally, a recent film with real gore!
reviews.content: Jason X is, like the other Friday the 13th movies, a real cheesy thing. And I guess it was meant to be like that.  I've not seen all of them, but enough to say that they are all pretty much the same thing (Jason comes back to life and murders many people at Crystal Lake).    Well, in this film, Crystal Lake has become a military research center (???).  This element was brought up simply to keep some of the older Jason movies' roots, but in that point, I think they failed.  Actually, in one way, it's really pointless, because a summer camp that becomes a research center in such a short period of time (since the last Friday The 13th film, which was released in 1991, I think, and Crystal Lake, in 2010 is a research center...huh?).   But it seems that the director wanted to keep some more fundamental roots; the bad acting.  I don't know how he could pay actors that were that bad...really, especially the girls...They are stupid, stereotyped, and, the most pointless thing, they are wearing some really fashioned, tight and "show everything" clothes.  I know this can be attractive for the male viewers, but really, this was pointless.  The actresses are so superficial, so lame, this director must have had something against women, because this film really shows them bad.  Lexa Doig, probably the worst in this film, says her lines too fast, she answers to the other character's questions like a machine...she's really bad, and the other blonde (Spoilers) that gets her face frozen and smashed is pretty awful too.    The futuristic aspect is just an excuse to bring Jason back to life.  The whole movie happens in spaceships, which could have been interesting (but, knowing that it's a Jason movie, I didn't really had sincere hopes of having something interesting), but the atmosphere is not really there...I'll still have to admit that this film keeps the old dark, "almost (and that's being generous)scary" mood of the Jason movies.    But there comes the part I really enjoyed...the gore!  If you've seen the previous Friday The 13th movies, you'll know that they are sometimes pretty gory.  This one has a surprisingly high gore level.  (Spoilers) A cop is sliced in half, many people are dismembered, killed with Jason's machete, many people are impaled...but that's nothing compared to what Jason gets...he gets shot like 300 times during the whole movie, and there's one place, where a female humanoid shoots him with a pretty powerful gun...Jason gets a leg, an arm and finally his head blown into pieces...and guess what...he still survives, not in the usual way, but you'll see what I'm talking about when you watch it.  the gore is abundant, and FINALLY! a recent movie that has some REAL gore.  What I mean by REAL gore is bloody special effects that are not made by computer...I'm really, really tired of that...computer-made gore does not and cannot look as good as the old fashioned way to make a bloody scene...with some real red liquid, with some real fake brains, I mean, with movies with really bad-looking gore such as Resident Evil and Blade, all directors should have realized that it simply doesn't work.  Gore made by computer is for me what Jar Jar Binks was for the Star Wars fans: BULL...you know the rest.  And, at least, Jim Isaac, Jason X's director understood that.  There are some scenes where the gore is made by CGI, but they have the excuse that it was in a video game (you'll understand if you see it).  This has some really nice gore.  Now, the killer.  Jason, the one we've known, is still the same...really, except for these short 5 minutes where he's "upgraded", but don't worry about that, it's nothing very important.  The whole movie puts its emphasis on Jason, who's butchering many characters, that have two functions: looking good on the screen, and getting killed.  I mean, most characters in this film are there to be slashed, really.  They're just cattle, human meat...that's it...And that's how it's always been, and that's how it still is.    The film is very repetitive.  It's always a couple of people, sometimes with weapons, that are trying to either kill or escape from Jason Voorhees. It's an hour and a half of that.  But for the Friday The 13th fans, this should be a great deal, and probably one of the best Jason movies.  It's lame, stupid, gory, and has some good-looking girls, that's all it's ever been, and that's all it still is.  Personnally, there's only the gore factor that really satisfied me, and I'd say that for gore fans, this is a nice deal too.  It's even gorier than many of the older films!  And it's funny to see how Jason would react in a futuristic world...  My lust of gore was satisfied, but if I had had the lust for a nice scenario...OUCH!  I would have wanted a refund!  Good gore, bad movie... I give it 4 out of 10.

The only thing I liked about this film were some of the creative death scenes. I mean some of these kills were just great and by 2001 the MPAA sort of took their shades off that have been on since 1986's Jason Lives. This film is so ridiculous and really marked the end of the series and the ideas had just dried out. I mean why not Pinhead, Predator and Leprechaun were in space so lets explode Kane Hodder to the outer regions of experience. Just awful in every department and its no wonder why two years later they paired Jason and Freddy up since every idea had been exhausted. Terrible film but not as bad as the previous Jason Goes to Hell, that takes the cake for worst film in the franchise.

I don't have much to say about this movie other than if you are an old school horror fan, than this movie is for you.  There were more cleverly created kills in this movie than any horror or action movie that I've ever seen.  The dark comedy throughout was perfect and not at all meant to be taken seriously, just as the movie was.  The "Crystal Lake" recreation was without a doubt the funniest part in the movie.  It almost lost a point for the ending, but even the ending was what I almost expected and was done more for yet another laugh than anything else.  Here's hoping you go out and see this movie, because it sure beat going to see The Scorpion King.Rasmin

Yeah, there's Jason Voorhees, so that means more graphic ways to kill people.  But this one is a poor rip-off of the "Alien" movies.It was also filmed in Toronto.  So that's why Jason wears a hockey mask, he's Canadian!

"Jason X" is basically the same as the nine previous "Friday the 13th" movies, except that Jason has been resurrected from cryogenics in the year 2455, and is going on a rampage on a spaceship instead of Camp Crystal Lake. That said, this is one of those rare sequels that's much better than the original. In fact, this movie is light-years better than all the others in the franchise. Why? Because this is the first "Friday the 13th" movie that finally figured out what everyone else already knew, "You know what? We're not producing an Oscar-winner here, so let's just have fun with it and see what develops." For example, Jason has Rowan (Lexa Doig) and two of her shipmates trapped in a sealed-off corner of the spaceship and is about to go in for the kill. That is, until Tsunaron strolls in behind Jason with a turbo-powered Kay-Em and gets Jason's attention by shouting, "HEY SLAPPY!!!" I was rolling on the floor laughing! The last thing I would think of saying to a homicidal maniac who's about to slice and dice me is, "Hey Slappy!" Yet that's what makes this movie so entertaining. People are about to be chopped into bits, and they're cracking jokes to get through their misery. You have two Virtual Reality Girls -- part of a throwback scene as the crew tries to divert Jason -- watching 'Ol Hockey Mask make a beeline toward them with his machete, and instead of running and screaming they ask him if he'd like to smoke some pot, take off their shirts and just stand there topless for him. And unlike earlier "Friday the 13th" movies, where you feel like the director would throw a punch at you in anger if you laughed during the movie, here you get a vibe that the folks who put together "Jason X" want you to laugh just as much as they want you to be scared. It's almost as much a dark comedy as it is a horror movie. Of course, the girls are the other great thing about this movie. Lexa Doig is HOT, Kay-Em is the hottest android around, Gekko (one of the commando grunts who got her neck slashed about halfway through the movie) is hot and most of the other girls in this movie are good-looking. Even the two Virtual Reality girls were hotties. They somehow made '80s hairstyles look good again. I wouldn't give any other "Friday the 13th" movies -- except MAYBE "Freddy vs. Jason" -- higher than a 4, and most quite frankly deserve a 1 even if you're simply watching them for the gore value. But "Jason X" is worthy of a solid 7. Probably the best movie ever made in the homicidal-maniac family of horror movies.

reviews.review_title: Probably the best since the first Friday the 13th
